questions.text: A peripheral smear of a 40-year-old female with chronic anaemia and gall stones is as seen below. The patient develops a sudden worsening of anaemia requiring transfusion. What is the most likely Etiology?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows many spherocytes classically described in hereditary spherocytosis.

  • The generally stable clinical course of hereditary spherocytosis is sometimes punctuated by an aplastic crisis, usually triggered by an acute parvovirus infection.
  • Parvovirus infects and kills red cell progenitors, effectively causing red cell production to cease until an immune response commences, generally in 1 to 2 weeks.
  • The reduced life span of HS red cells + cessation of erythropoiesis → leads to a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Transfusions may be necessary to support the patient until the immune response clears the infection

questions.text: Identify this condition.
questions.solution:
The given specimen depicts a monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancy as:

  • 2 umbilical cords are arising from 1 placenta (monochorionic)
  • No intervening amniotic membrane is attached to the placenta. This means that both fetuses must have been inside a single amniotic cavity (monoamniotic). 

Option B: In Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy, on gross examination, there will be 1 placenta and intervening 2 layers of amnion attached to the placenta. In this type of pregnancy, each fetus will have its own amniotic cavity (diamniotic) with a shared placenta (monochorionic). This is seen if the fertilized zygote divides into 2 between 4-8 days.

The below given gross image of monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy shows two umbilical cords arising separately from the placenta with the intervening amniotic membrane held by the forceps.

Option D: In dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy each fetus has it’s own amnion & chorion. The placentas here may be fused or separate. This is seen in dizygotic twins as well as monozygotic twins that divide within 0-4 days.

Option A: Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)  most commonly complicates monochorionic (single placenta) twin pregnancy. In TTTS blood is transfused from the donor twin to the recipient twin through the abnormal vascular connections within the placenta leaving the donor anemic while the recipient becomes polycythemic.

questions.text: The Local anesthetic of choice for labor analgesia is?
questions.solution:
Bupivacaine and ropivacaine are preferred over lidocaine and chloroprocaine for labor analgesia because of their differential blockade  (they produce less motor blockade as compared to sensory blockade). This preferred motor function is useful as voluntary push down efforts by the patient may lead to better delivery outcomes

Bupivacaine is preferred because of its long duration of action

Ropivacaine and levobupivacaine were introduced to reduce the cardiotoxicity associated with bupivacaine. But since bupivacaine is used in small doses for labor analgesia, cardiotoxicity usually does not manifest

The doses of local anesthetics can be reduced by a combination of local anesthetics with lipid-soluble opioids like fentanyl or sufentanil. The greater the concentration of opioid used, a lesser concentration of local anesthetic is required. The lesser concentration of local anesthetic used leads to greater preservation of motor function and makes ambulation of the  patient possible(walking or mobile epidural)

Concentrations used for epidural:

  • Without opioid: bupivacaine: 0.25%, ropivacaine, 0.2%
  • With opioid: bupivacaine (0.0625% to 0.125%), ropivacaine (0.0625% to 0.2%)

questions.text: Which of the following is a superadded permanent tooth?
questions.solution:
The 6 molars are called superadded teeth.

Permanent dentition refers to the teeth which begin to erupt from 6th year of age and remain throughout the life. They are totally 32 in number. The tooth distribution in each jaw is as follows:

  • 4 incisors
  • 2 canines
  • 4 premolars
  • 6 molars.

Thus, each jaw has 16 teeth. Among these 4 incisors and 2 canines and 4 premolars are called as successional teeth, which erupt in the place of predecessor deciduous teeth.

The remaining 6 permanent molars (1st, 2nd, and 3rd molar teeth) erupt independently without any predecessor teeth. Hence they are called superadded teeth.

questions.text: The structure (Red Arrow) shown in the image develops from _______
questions.solution:
The arrow depicts the neurohypophysis which develops from the diencephalon.

The pituitary has two major parts, the neurohypophysis and adenohypophysis, which differ in their origin, structure and function.

The neurohypophysis is a diencephalic downgrowth connected with the hypothalamus.

The adenohypophysis is an ectodermal derivative of the stomatodeum.

questions.text: Modified Goeckerman regimen is _____________.
questions.solution:
Coal tar + Narrowband UVB (311–313 nm) is known as Modified Goeckerman regimen. It is the recommended first-line therapy for most patients with moderate to severe psoriasis.

Coal tar + Broadband UVB (290–320 nm) was used for nearly 100 years as part of the Goeckerman regimen. The optimal wavelength for treating psoriasis was found to be 312 nm. Hence, the modified regimen is preferred as it is more efficient and better tolerated.

Psoralens and long‐wave ultraviolet radiation (UVA 320–400 nm) is also called PUVA. The efficacy is comparable to Modified Goeckerman regimen. However, it is not preferred as the first line due to its side effect profile. Side effects include erythema, blistering, neurogenic itch (PUVA itch- crawling sensation underneath the skin) and increased risk of non-melanoma skin cancers. Psoralens are teratogenic.

Topical calcipotriol is used in the treatment of mild plaque psoriasis. Calcipotriol ointment enhances the efficacy of PUVA and UVB phototherapy. it is recommended that calcipotriol is not applied immediately prior to phototherapy exposures.

questions.text: The stain done on a section of liver shown below is:
questions.solution:
The above stain demonstrates reticular fibers of the liver and hence has to be reticulin stain.

Reticulin stain

  • Stained by 2 procedures, Gordon and Sweet’s reticulin stain (most common) and Gomori reticulin stain.
  • They demonstrate reticulin fibers and basement membrane.
  • Reticulin fibers: thin, type 3 collagen, widespread in connective tissue
  • Basement membrane: type 4 collagen fibers and laminin.

Reticulin stain is used to shows the normal architecture of the liver and thereby help detect disrupted architecture in hepatocellular carcinoma and hepatocellular proliferation.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false regarding ASHA workers?

choices.text: Few of their responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers
They should have formal education at least up to class 10
A population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA
They have to procure ORS, OCPs, IFA tablets from CHC

questions.solution:
Accredited social health activist (ASHA) workers do not need to procure supplies from CHCs. They only act as depot holders for certain essential supplies so that they are readily available to their community.

These essential supplies may include ORS, contraceptives, iron-folic acid tablets, chloroquine, disposable delivery kits, oral contraceptive pills, condoms, etc. 

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: As a medical officer involved in the sentinel surveillance for HIV under the National AIDS Control Programme, your duties include all of the following except:

choices.text: Estimation of total infection in the community
Estimation of total cases in hospitals

questions.solution:
As a medical officer involved in the sentinel surveillance, the estimation of total cases in hospitals is not included in the sentinel surveillance for HIV under National AIDS Control Programme (NACO).

The aims of the HIV sentinel surveillance include:

  • Determine the level of HIV infection in the community.
  • Understand the trends of HIV epidemic.
  • Understand the geographical spread of HIV infection and classify districts according to epidemiological and vulnerability criteria.

These objectives are achieved by conducting annual cross-sectional surveys of the risk group in the same geographical place.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about the device shown in the image below?

choices.text: Smaller ones are given to PHCs and the larger ones to district vaccine stores
They have temperature zones for different vaccines
Kata thermometer is used to record temperature inside this device
These devices are provided with baskets to store vaccines

questions.solution:
The image shown in the question is of an ice-lined refrigerator (ILR). Dial or digital thermometers are used to record temperatures inside an ice-lined refrigerator.

ILRs are the main method of vaccine storage in primary health centers. They are an important part of the cold chain and they maintain a temperature of 2 to 8 °C for the storage of vaccines.

They have different temperature zones for different vaccines. The upper zone is for freeze-sensitive vaccines like cholera, hep B, rotavirus(liquid), etc while the lower zone is for heat-sensitive vaccines like OPV, measles, etc.

All vaccines are kept in the basket provided with ILR. Vaccines like OPV, BCG, measles, and JE can be kept at the bottom of the basket while, DPT, TT, Hep B, IPV, and pentavalent vaccines and diluents are kept in the upper part of the basket.

questions.text: An epidemiologist has determined five independent factors influencing the outcome of a particular disease. Which of the following statistical methods can he use to compare these factors?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the outcome to be determined (dependent variable) is the occurrence of the disease, which is categorical (qualitative) in nature. Logistic regression can be used when a categorical dependent variable is being compared with either a categorical or numerical independent variable.

Linear regression is used when the outcome is numerical.

Independent variable 

(risk factors, exposure)

  

Qualitative (categorical)

Quantitative (numerical)
Qualitative (categorical)

Logistic regression

ANOVA 
Quantitative (numerical) Logistic regression  

Linear regression

 

Related Pearl: Regression

When two variables are correlated, the value of one of the variables can be predicted from the value of the other using regression techniques.

  • Independent variable: The variable from which the other variable is calculated.
  • Dependent variable: The variable for which the value is calculated.

Types of regression:

1. Simple linear regression

  • In this, the value of one variable (y) is used to predict the value of another variable (x).
  • The regression equation is used for this purpose. It gives a straight-line relationship between the two variables.
  • It is given by the equation y = a + bx, where, a is a constant called the intercept constant and b is the regression coefficient.
  • The intercept constant is the point where the Y-axis is intercepted by the regression line. 

 2. Multiple linear regression

  • In this, more than one variable is used to predict the expected value of another variable (y).
  • Here, the expected value of y = a + b1x1 + b2x2…..bnxn where b1 and b2…..bn represent different regression coefficients and x1, x2…….xn represents the known variables.

 3. Logistic regression

  •  In some situations, we are not interested in a numerical outcome (like risk, etc) but we want a nominal or categorical one (like death/survival, developing a disease/not developing a disease)
  • Here, the relationship between the variables will not be a linear one as the outcome from survival to death in relationship with the risk factor can change suddenly. Thus these outcomes are represented by 0 and 1.
  • Using a mathematical logistic function we can transform linear regression data, such that the values of a variable y are limited to the range of 0 to 1, which would give us the probability of y occurring for the given values of variable x.

questions.text: Which of the following is the principle of PET scan?
questions.solution:
PET scans are based on the principle of production of a dual photon peak at 511 keV.

To perform a PET scan, a radionuclide tracer (labeled to FDG molecules) is used. These molecules decay in the body with the release of a positron. The positron travels a short distance and annihilates with an anti-particle (electron). This annihilation reaction results in the formation of two high-energy photons that travel in opposite directions. Each photon has an energy of 511 keV, making this a dual photon peak at 511 keV.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhea, loss of appetite, and loss of weight. On examination, the patient had peripheral edema and ascites. Laboratory studies showed decreased serum albumin but normal serum levels of transaminases and gastrin. Upper GI endoscopy showed the following appearance of the stomach. Which of the following is true about the condition?

choices.text: Gastrectomy is the treatment of choice in severe cases
Caused by overexpression of TNF alpha

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing the presence of hypertrophied gastric mucosal folds are characteristic of Menetrier’s disease. Gastrectomy is the treatment of choice in severe cases of Menetrier's disease.

Menetrier's disease is a premalignant condition. The disease seems to be caused by overexpression of transforming growth factor-alpha i.e., TGF-alpha (not TNF-alpha), which stimulates the EGFR pathway, resulting in increased proliferation of mucus cells/foveolar hyperplasia. This results in gross hypertrophy of the gastric mucosal folds, mucus production, and hypochlorhydria. The antrum is usually spared.

There is a loss of albumin (up to 10 g/day), across the gastric mucosa leading to hypoproteinemia. Secondary symptoms include weight loss, diarrhea, and peripheral edema.

Histologically, it is characterized by hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells. The glands are cystically dilated and elongated with a corkscrew-like appearance as shown in the image below.

Cetuximab, an EGFR inhibitory antibody, is now considered the first-line treatment for Menetrier's disease, leaving total gastrectomy for severe disease with persistent and substantial protein loss refractory to cetuximab.

Related Pearl: Risk factors for carcinoma stomach

Risk factors for carcinoma stomach:

  • Dietary
    • Low fat or protein consumption
    • Consumption of salted meat or fish with high nitrate content
    • High complex carbohydrate consumption
    • Smoking, alcohol consumption
    • Spicy food, high salt diet
    • Lack of fresh fruits and vegetables
    • Dietary anti-oxidant deficiency
  • Genetic and familial
    • E cadherin – hereditary diffuse type of gastric cancer
    • Blood group A
    • FAP
    • Li-Fraumeni syndrome
    • HNPCC
    • BRCA 2 mutation
  • Premalignant lesions
    • Chronic atrophic gastritis
    • Adenomatous polyp (FAP)
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Intestinal metaplasia (H. pylori)
    • Menetrier’s disease
    • Stump carcinoma from stomach remnants in Billroth II GJ or vagotomy GJ
  • Others
    • Low socioeconomic status
    • Male gender
    • Rubber and coal workers
    • EBV infection

questions.text: An infant is brought to the pediatric OPD with clinical findings as shown in the image. Further examination shows that the child has a loss of developmental milestones, truncal hypotonia, and failure to thrive. Which of the following enzymes is defective in this child?
questions.solution:
The given image reveals an infant with sparse and kinky hair. This, along with loss of developmental milestones and truncal hypotonia, strongly suggests a diagnosis of Menkes disease, which is caused by defective lysyl oxidase. 

Menkes disease results from a deficiency of lysyl oxidase co-factor i.e copper. This is due to a defect in the ATP7A gene, which prevents the absorption of copper from the intestine.

Note :

  • ATP7A mutation: Menkes disease - X-linked recessive
  • ATP7B mutation: Wilson's disease - Autosomal recessive

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: Which of the following autoantibody isotype is involved in the pathogenesis of Guillian-Barre syndrome?
questions.solution:
IgG isotype of autoantibody is involved in the pathogenesis of GBS.

IgM isotype autoantibodies are known to play a role in some types of chronic immune neuropathies.

questions.text: Which of the following  is a correct statement regarding the given condition?

choices.text: Antibiotics are the first line treatment

questions.solution:
The image shows pearly, penile papules. These are exclusively found in males. They consist of flesh-coloured, smooth papules most commonly on the coronal margin of the glans penis. They are benign and asymptomatic and treatment involves reassuring the patient. 

*Note: Pearly, penile papules are commonly mistaken for Fordyce spots (Tyson's glands). Fordyce spots are commonly seen on the shaft of the penis and are ectopic sebaceous glands. Image below depicts Fordyce spots on the penile shaft: 

Related Pearl: Fordyce Spots

Fordyce spots/Fordyce granules:

  • The Fordyce spots are heterotopic sebaceous glands wherein the duct is connected directly to the overlying skin or mucosal surface unlike other sebum glands which open into the follicle.
  • They are called ectopic/free-lying sebaceous glands.
  • They occur commonly on the vermilion border of upper lip(m/c), buccal mucosa, skin over penile shaft and areolar of the breast.
  • They are commonly multiple and appear as symmetrical discrete yellow papules.
  • Fordyce spots on penis are called Tyson glands.
  • They are asymptomatic.
  • Treatment ladder
    • First line: Reassurance
    • Second line
      • Local destruction with superficial cautery or electrodessication
      • Topical trichloracetic acid 

Image: Fordyce spots on the vermilion border of both lips in A, upper lip in B, and buccal mucosa in  C.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding management considerations in a patient with submandibular gland stones?

choices.text: Surgical gland excision is the treatment of choice if patient is unresponsive to conservative management
Associated chronic sialadenitis is a contraindication for sialendoscopy
Conventional radiography is mostly useless as more than 80% of submandibular stones are radiolucent
Stones proximal to the lingual nerve can be removed via an intra-oral approach

questions.solution:
If the stone is proximal to the lingual nerve, stone retrieval can be done via an intraoral surgical approach under general anesthesia.

80% of submandibular stones are radio-opaque. Conventional radiography is useful in the initial workup of salivary stones, but ultrasound, CT, MRI, and sialendoscopy are required for accurate diagnosis and localization (especially for smaller and parenchymal stones).

The only contraindication for sialendoscopy is acute sialadenitis. This is because sialendoscopy and ductal dilation is more difficult in the setting of inflammation and there will be a greater likelihood of ductal trauma and potential spread of infection.

Management of sialolithiasis should begin with conservative measures, oral hydration, analgesia, massaging of gland, sialogogues, and antibiotics (if there are signs of infection). If unsuccessful, the next step is based on the sialolith's size, number, and location:

  • Small stones (<4mm) - endoscopic removal using Dormia basket.
  • larger stones - external shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) + fragment removal or  Open surgery and stone removal
  • Surgical excision of the gland should always be a last resort

If distal to lingual nerve: Make a longitudinal incision over the duct. Remove the stone. Suture the duct using absorbable suture.     

If proximal to lingual nerve: intraoral approach  

The image below shows a stone in the submandibular salivary duct.

questions.text: False about polyarteritis nodosa is __________

choices.text: It is associated with chronic hepatitis B
It is a disease of medium sized arteries

questions.solution:

questions.text: A patient with bronchogenic carcinoma presents to your OPD complaining of hoarseness of voice. On laryngoscopy,  you ask him to phonate and notice that the left vocal cord does not abduct. Which of the following muscles is involved?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is of unilateral vocal cord palsy secondary to bronchogenic carcinoma. The posterior cricoarytenoids are involved here (marked as 3), as they are paralyzed since the tumor invades unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve.

Other structures:

1. Lateral cricoarytenoid muscle - closes the ligamentous part of rima glottidis

2. Transverse arytenoid muscle - closes the inter cartilaginous part of the rima glottidis

4. Cricothyroid muscle - it is a tensor of the vocal cord.

questions.text: A pathologist observed Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies on microscopy in a biopsy specimen taken from the nose. Which of the following is a false statement regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: Medical management include streptomycin and tetracycline.
Surgery is the treatment of choice for this disease

questions.solution:
Biopsy findings of Mikulicz cells and Russell's bodies are characteristic findings in rhinoscleroma. Medical management is the mainstay treatment for rhinoscleroma. Streptomycin(1 g/day) and tetracycline (2 g/day) are given for a minimum of 4-6 weeks and continued till 2 consecutive biopsies are negative. Surgery is reserved to establish airway or correct deformity.

Biopsy in the case of rhinoscleroma shows infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells, and Russell bodies. 

Mikulicz cells are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing causative bacilli.

Russell bodies are homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies found in the plasma cells. They occur due to the accumulation of immunoglobulins secreted by the plasma cells.

The following image shows rhinoscleroma with Mikulicz cells.

H&E showing a mixture of plasma cells (arrow), lymphocytes (short arrow), Miculikz cells which are vacuolated macrophages containing causative bacilli (double arrow).

Option A: Rhinoscleroma is endemic in several parts of the world. In India, it is seen more often in the northern than in the southern parts. 

Option D: Organism can be cultured from biopsy material.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain, which is worse during menstruation. Laparoscopic examination of the pelvis demonstrates multiple small brown spots on the surface of pelvic structures and extensive fibrous adhesions between tubes, ovaries, and other structures. A biopsy is done and microscopy is as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Microscopy shows glands resembling endometrial glands surrounded by endometrial stroma in the ovary. The most likely diagnosis is endometriosis. 

Endometriosis is defined by the presence of ectopic endometrial tissue at a site outside of the uterus. Includes both endometrial glands and stroma, but may consist only of stroma in some cases. 

It occurs in the following sites, in descending order of frequency

  • Ovaries
  • Uterine ligaments
  • Rectovaginal septum
  • Cul de sac
  • Pelvic peritoneum
  • Large and small bowel and appendix
  • Mucosa of the cervix, vagina, and fallopian tubes
  • Laparotomy scars.

It is principally a disease of women in active reproductive life, most often in the third and fourth decades. It causes infertility, dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation), pelvic pain, and other problems. Endometriotic lesions bleed periodically in response to both extrinsic cyclic (ovarian) and intrinsic hormonal stimulation.

The diagnosis is readily made when both endometrial glands and stroma are present with or without the presence of hemosiderin. In rare cases, only the stroma is identified.

Atypical endometriosis, the likely precursor to endometriosis-related ovarian carcinoma, has two morphologic appearances. One consists of cytologic atypia of the epithelium lining the endometriotic cyst without major architectural changes. The second is marked by glandular crowding due to excessive epithelial proliferation, often associated with cytologic atypia, producing an appearance that resembles complex atypical endometrial hyperplasia.

Other options

Option A- Adenomyosis is characterized by foci of the endometrium deep in the myometrium.

Option B- Chronic endometritis is a chronic inflammation of the endometrium.

Option C- Metastatic endometrial carcinoma would be characterized by abnormal glands and cytologic atypia.

questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in Jharkhand, which is endemic to the disease transmitted by the vector shown below. Which of the following agents would you prefer to control this vector in view of resistance to commonly used agents?
questions.solution:
The image given is that of a sandfly, which is the vector for kala-azar. In endemic states with increasing resistance to commonly used agents like DDT, synthetic pyrethroids are preferred now.

The four states endemic for kala-azar are Bihar, Jharkhand, West Bengal and Uttar Pradesh.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

questions.text: Which among the following is not seen in leprosy?
questions.solution:
Proprioception and vibration sense is not impaired in leprosy.
Nerve involvement in leprosy causes motor palsy leading to an abnormal EMG.

Other options:
Voluntary muscle wasting is seen in leprosy.
Decreased sensations are classically seen in leprosy.
However, an increased tactile response is seen in Type I Lepra reaction with hyperesthesia.

questions.text: An X-ray skull of a patient with marked hypercalcemia is shown below. Which of the following laboratory parameters is consistent with his diagnosis?

choices.text: High alkaline phosphatase and normal ESR
High alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR
Normal alkaline phosphatase and normal ESR
Normal alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR

questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, hypercalcemia along with the skull demonstrating typical 'punched out' lesions is characteristic of multiple myeloma. Normal alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR are consistent with multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. It is associated with an increased osteoclast activity with suppression of osteoblast activity, causing punched-out lytic lesions in the bone and hypercalcemia.

Signs and symptoms:

  • Bone pain is the most common symptom
  • Pathologic fractures
  • Recurrent bacterial infections
  • Renal failure
  • Normocytic normochromic anemia, elevated ESR, hypercalcemia, normal ALP (ALP is a marker of bone growth and hence is not increased in multiple myeloma)
  • Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray. The lesions are purely osteolytic with little or no osteoblastic activity. Hence alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is normal. The most common site of lytic lesion in multiple myeloma is the vertebral column.
  • Electrophoresis: M spikes
  • Urinalysis: Bence Jones proteinuria
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Plasma cells

questions.text: Identify the surgical procedure shown below.
questions.solution:
The procedure illustrated in the image is Billroth II gastrectomy. Following resection, the distal end of the stomach is narrowed by the closure of the lesser curve aspect of the remnant. The greater curve aspect is then anastomosed, usually in a retro-colic fashion, to the jejunum.

Option A: In Billroth I gastrectomy, the lower half of the stomach is removed, and the cut end of the stomach is anastomosed to the first part of the duodenum.

Option C: Braun modification of classical Billroth II gastrectomy is Billroth II reconstruction with jejunojejunostomy.

Option D: Roux-en Y gastrojejunostomy is a gastric bypass surgery where a loop of jejunum is anastomosed to a proximal gastric pouch.

questions.text: Dupilumab is _____

choices.text: Anti IL 17 A receptor antibody approved for treatment of plaque psoriasis
Anti IL 23 monoclonal antibody approved for treatment of plaque psoriasis
Anti IL 4 receptor alpha antibody approved for treatment of atopic dermatitis
Anti IL 6 monoclonal antibody approved for treatment of rheumatoid arthritis

questions.solution:
Dupilumab is an anti IL 4 receptor alpha antibody approved for treatment of atopic dermatitis.

Other options:

A. Brodalumab: Anti IL 17 A receptor antibody approved for treatment of plaque psoriasis.

B. Guselkumab: Anti IL 23 monoclonal antibody approved for treatment of plaque psoriasis.

D. Sarilumab: Anti IL 6 monoclonal antibody approved for treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, and diarrhoea. He gives a history of consuming raw refrigerated cucumbers the previous day. What is the most likely etiologic organism?
questions.solution:
Fever, headache, abdominal pain, diarrhoea following consumption of refridgerated food is suggestive of food poisoning caused by Listeria monocytogenes.

Listeria monocytogenes can survive at refrigerator temperatures (4°C), under conditions of low pH and high salt. So it is able to overcome food preservation and safety barriers, making it an important foodborne pathogen. 

Healthy persons exposed to L. monocytogenes in food may develop a mild, self-limiting febrile gastroenteritis lasting 1–3 days. This develops after an incubation period of 6–48 hours. Symptoms include fever, chills, headache, myalgias, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Immunocompromised individuals can develop meningoencephalitis, bacteremia, or focal infections.

The drug of choice is high dose intravenous ampicillin.

questions.text: Which muscle is attached to the area marked in the diagram below?
questions.solution:
The image above shows the radius, identified by the radial head at the elbow joint. The arrow points to a raised area, which is the radial tuberosity. Biceps brachii is attached to the radial tuberosity.

The short head of the biceps brachii originates from the apex of the coracoid process and the long head arises from the supraglenoid tubercle of the scapula. Both the tendons end in a flattened tendon and are attached to the radial tuberosity. The nerve supply is by the musculocutaneous nerve (C5, C6).

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is not present in the mitochondrial matrix?
questions.solution:
ATP synthase is located on the inner mitochondrial membrane, not mitochondrial matrix.

Note: In contrast to the other enzymes of citric acid cycle, succinate dehydrogenase is bound to the inner surface of inner mitochondrial membrane. Succinate dehydrogenase functions as complex II of electron transport chain.

questions.text: In patients with ADPKD, cysts are least likely to be present in which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
In patients with ADPKD, cysts in the lungs are very rare. 

There are very few case reports with lung cysts in ADPKD patients, but the association between ADPKD and lung cysts has not been proved. However, there is a three-fold increase in the incidence of bronchiectasis in ADPKD patients.

The common extrarenal manifestations of ADPKD include: 

  • Hepatic cysts (50-70%) - most common 
  • Seminal vesicle cysts (40%) - can result in infertility
  • Arachnoid membrane cysts (8%) - usually asymptomatic, may increase the risk of subdural hematoma
  • Pancreatic cysts (7-36%)
  • Splenic cysts

questions.text: The type of knot seen in the image is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the suture material exiting the knot is on the same side as the entry i.e no cross-over is seen. This is seen in a reef knot.

A knot is a fastening made of threads intertwined together or on themselves. Each knot consists of- 2 half-hitches placed in sequential throws. Squaring refers to tightening the knot/half-hitch in a manner that the threads lay flat due to the alternating direction of half-hitches in adjacent layers.

Types of knots:

  1. Granny knot: half-hitch over a half-hitch in the same direction. It has better-holding power than half-hitch
  2. Reef knot: half-hitch followed by a second half-hitch after squaring. 
  3. Triple throw knot: Reef knot with another half-hitch knot for added security. Knots made with prolene sutures require 6-8 throws to prevent slippage.
  4. Surgeon’s knot: Modification of the reef knot with two half-hitches in the first layer.
  5. Slip knot: Modification of either granny/reef knot formed when one end of the thread is kept taut while tightening the knot.

questions.text: Which of the following drug combinations is not contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Emtricitabine and tenofovir (brand name Truvada) is an FDCapproved combination for the treatment of HIV.

All the other combinations are contraindicated.

  • Combining Stavudine with Didanosine leads to increased risk and severity of peripheral neuropathy and potentially fatal pancreatitis.
  • Stavudine and Zidovudine compete for intracellular phosphorylation and should not be used concomitantly.
  • Tenofovir and Didanosine should not be used together. Tenofovir increases the plasma concentration of Didanosine when plotted against time.(Area under curve is increased)

questions.text: A 25 year old female presents with a neck swelling. Isotope scan of her thyroid gland shows a “cold” nodule. This nodule is removed and microscopy is as seen below. All are true about the tumour except:

choices.text: Follicular variant is the most common variant
Diagnosis can be made based on nuclear features, even in the absence of typical architecture
Associated with previous exposure to ionizing radiation

questions.solution:
The image shows papillary carcinoma of thyroid with papillae lined by cells with overlapping and clearing of nuclei and inclusions. Involvement of blood vessels by tumor cells is relatively uncommon but metastases to adjacent cervical lymph nodes occur in up to half of the cases.

  • Presents as painless nodule or mass in the neck or cervical node in women of reproductive age.
  • Usually cold nodule on a scan
  • Branching papillae and follicles with fibrovascular stalk
  • Nuclear changes  - Optically clear -  Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei, pseudo-inclusions, nuclear grooves
  • Risk factors – Exposure to ionizing radiation, Hashimoto thyroiditis
  • Diagnosis can be made based on these nuclear features, even in the absence of papillary architecture
  • Psammoma bodies are often present
  • Most common variant of papillary carcinoma is the follicular variant
  • Tall cell variant – increased frequencies of vascular invasion, extrathyroidal extension, and cervical and distant metastases.
  • Excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%

questions.text: Pegloticase is a pegylated form of the following enzyme:
questions.solution:
Pegloticase is a pegylated form of the enzyme urate oxidase (uricase).

It catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin which is a more water-soluble and inactive metabolite.

It is indicated in severe, treatment-refractory gout or when other urate-lowering agents are contraindicated.

questions.text: Balanced resuscitation means

choices.text: Simultaneous management of Airway, Breathing, Circulation
Use of equal amount of Crystalloids and Colloids
Restrictive use of fluids and blood products

questions.solution:
Balanced resuscitation means restrictive use of fluids and blood products.

Balanced resuscitation has 2 components:

  • Hypotensive resuscitation
    • Here, the resuscitation of hemorrhagic shock is done using fluids in such a way that the blood pressure is not targeted to reach the normal. (The target Systolic BP here is 80-100mmHg) The reason being, if the pressure is increased suddenly, then the tamponade effect of hemorrhage is lost due to dislodgement of blood clots and increase in blood pressure will lead to further bleeding.
  • Hemostatic resuscitation
    • Provides resuscitation with blood components resembling whole blood with the aims of maintaining circulating volume, limiting ongoing bleeding, and preventing the lethal triad of hypothermia, acidosis and acute coagulopathy of trauma.
    • Involves blood component ratios of 1 RBC: 1 FFP: 1 Platelets

questions.text: Choose the correct order of suctioning during neonatal resuscitation.
questions.solution:
During neonatal resuscitation, the mouth is suctioned first and then the nares, in order to decrease the risk of aspiration. A 12 or 14 French suction catheter is used, with the suction pressure kept between 80-100mmHg.

Routine suctioning of the trachea during neonatal resuscitation is not recommended. The suctioning of the esophagus and stomach is avoided if not indicated specifically, as it can produce a vagal response due to stimulation in the posterior pharynx, resulting in apnea and/or bradycardia.

The steps in neonatal resuscitation follow the ABCs, Airway, Breathing, and Circulation.

The neonatal resuscitation algorithm is given below:

Chest compression should be initiated over the lower third of the sternum at a rate of 90/minutes. The ratio of chest compression to ventilation is 3: 1 (90 compressions: 30 breaths). The thumb technique (preferred) and 2 finger technique are the two different techniques used for performing chest compression. Umbilical vein cannulation is the preferred method for the administration of medications.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with pain and deformity of his toes. The clinical findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical image showing dactylitis, nail changes and telescoping of toes is suggestive of psoriatic arthritis. 

Clinical features of psoriatic arthritis include:

  • Psoriatic nail changes- yellowing and hypertrophy 
  • Dactylitis- inflammation of the toes
  • Telescoping (shortening) of toes due to osteolysis
  • Severe deformity- suggestive of arthritis mutilans
  • Enthesitis- heel pain at the sites of ligament or tendon attachment

Psoriatic arthritis of the hands commonly involves proximal and distal interphalangeal joints (PIP, DIP) and metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP). The image below shows psoriatic arthritis of the hands:

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with skin lesions as shown below. How is the diagnosis of this condition typically made?
questions.solution:
Pink pearly umbilicated lesions suggest a diagnosis of molluscum contagiosum. Its diagnosis is made based on clinical appearance.

Molluscum contagiosum is a benign epidermal tumour. It manifests as pink pearly wart-like lesions with a characteristic dimple at the centre (umbilicated) and is not associated with inflammation and necrosis. The lesions as seen over the face, arms, back and buttocks. The molluscum contagiosum virus is a poxvirus resembling vaccinia virus. 

Options B and C: Skin biopsy or smear of expressed material shows characteristic inclusion bodies. PCR for viral DNA can also be done. However, these tests are necessary only when the diagnosis is uncertain.

Option A: Viral culture is not used for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents with dry eyes,  dry mouth, and difficulty swallowing solid food. Examination reveals enlargement of parotid glands and dryness of buccal mucosa. Laboratory examination shows the presence of both SS-A and SS-B antibodies. The histopathological image of the salivary gland is given below. All are true about this condition, except ______.

choices.text: About 75% of patients have rheumatoid factor
Patients are at high risk for development of B-cell lymphomas
Lacrimal and salivary glands are mainly involved

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is a 55-year-old female patient with dry eyes, dry mouth, difficulty swallowing solid food, and the findings such as enlarged parotid gland, dry buccal mucosa, and antibodies positive for SS-A and SS-B is Sjogren's syndrome.  The histopathology shows the focal lymphoplasmacytic infiltration in the minor salivary gland. Glomerular lesions are extremely rare in Sjögren syndrome.

Sjögren's syndrome is a chronic disease wherein the lacrimal and salivary glands undergo immunologically-mediated destruction. This leads to the characteristic features of dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia). It can manifest as primary or secondary. Primary is an isolated form known as sicca syndrome. It is characterized by decreased tears and saliva. The salivary glands and lacrimal glands get infiltrated with lymphocytes and undergo fibrosis. The secondary form is associated with other autoimmune disorders. 

Clinically, it is more common in women between 50-60 years. They present with a blurring of vision, burning, itching of the eyes, difficulty swallowing solid foods, dryness of the buccal mucosa, and parotid gland enlargement. 

Antibodies directed against two ribonucleoprotein antigens- SS-A (Ro) and SS-B (La) are detected in almost all patients with Sjogren's syndrome. Rheumatoid factor is seen in about 75% of the patients. ANA is also often detected on immunofluorescence assay. A labial biopsy is useful and histology of salivary glands shows lymphocytic infiltration. 

Patients are at high risk for the development of B-cell lymphomas.

Related Pearl: Extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome

The extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are as follows:

  • Non-specific
    • Arthralgia or arthritis - It is the most common extraglandular manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jacoud’s arthropathy
    • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Accumulation of peri-epithelial lymphocytes
    • Interstitial lung disease - Most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
    • Renal tubular acidosis - Distal (type 1) RTA
    • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Immune complex-mediated
    • Small vessel vasculitis - Presents as cutaneous palpable purpura
    • Glomerulonephritis with cryoglobulinemia
    • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Lymphoma
    • Extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue (MALToma).

questions.text: You see a resident use the following instrument to grasp the anterior lip of the cervix in a patient posted for a vaginal hysterectomy. What is this instrument known as?
questions.solution:
The image shows vulsellum forceps. It is used to grasp the cervical lip and steady the cervix during vaginal surgery. It is a long instrument with a gentle curve so that the line of vision is not obstructed.

Option A: Allis forceps can be identified by continuous teeth, equal on both ends. It is used to hold structures with a firm grip.

Option C: Kocher's artery forceps are non-traumatic with a single tooth at the tip. They help in achieving hemostasis by firm pressure.

Option D: Lahey's tissue grasping forceps has teeth similar to dinner forks. They are used to hold fibrous tissue and they give a firm grip without slippage.

questions.text: The structures marked as “1” and “2” in the image below are developmentally derived from _______ and _______, respectively.
questions.solution:
The structure marked “1” is the outer annulus fibrosus and "2" is the inner nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral disc. They develop from the sclerotome and notochord, respectively. 

The vertebral bodies and the annulus fibrosus (peripheral part of the intervertebral disc) are derived from the mesenchymal cells of the sclerotome.

The nucleus pulposus is a remnant of the notochord. The notochord regresses entirely in the region of vertebral bodies, but it persists in the central part of the intervertebral discs as the nucleus pulposus.

questions.text: All of the following are components of Manning score except ______.
questions.solution:
The oxytocin challenge test is not a component of Manning score. 

Earlier, oxytocin challenge test/contraction stress test was done after a non-reactive NST to confirm the diagnosis of hypoxia. However, it is associated with the risk of initiating labor and is hence not done.

Biophysical profile (BPP)/Manning score components: (Mnemonic: BATMaN)

  • Breathing movements of the fetus
  • Amniotic fluid voulme
  • Tone of fetus
  • Movements of fetus
  • Non-stress Test (NST)

Normal score: 8-10; Abnormal: <5

Modified Biophysical score:

  • VAST (Vibroacoustic stimulation test)/NST
  • Amniotic fluid index

A score <4 indicates the need for urgent delivery.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding excitation-contraction coupling in smooth muscle?

choices.text: Sustained contraction occurs with high calcium concentration
Phosphorylation of actin is required for contraction
Cellular calcium concentration is essential to cause contraction

questions.solution:
Increased cytosolic Ca2+ is essential for contraction of smooth muscles.

Events in Excitation Contraction Coupling in Smooth Muscles.

A unitary smooth muscle is unique in that it can contract when stretched even in the absence of any extrinsic innervation. Stretch is followed by a decrease in membrane potential and an increase in the tone of the muscle.

 

Other options:

Option a: Troponin is absent in smooth muscle.

Option b: Sustained contraction of the smooth muscle occurs even when the calcium concentration falls. This is mainly because of the latch-bridge mechanism where the myosin cross-bridges remain attached to the actin. This mechanism allows for maintaining the contraction with less expenditure of energy and is particularly important in the vascular smooth muscle.

Option c: Unlike skeletal muscle where troponin binding is essential for contraction, the smooth muscle contraction requires phosphorylation of myosin (not actin).

questions.text: How long should a child be isolated after being diagnosed with bacterial meningitis to prevent further transmission?
questions.solution:
Isolation of the child is recommended until 24 hrs after the initiation of effective therapy after being diagnosed with acute bacterial meningitis to prevent further transmission.

Droplet precautions are recommended for patients with Neisseria meningitides and Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) meningitis until they have received 24 hours of effective therapy. Patients should be in private rooms, and hospital personnel should wear a face mask when they are within 3 feet (1 meter) of the patient.

The child with meningitis shows nonspecific symptoms like fever, anorexia, poor feeding, headache, myalgia, hypotension, petechia, purpura, or a rash. Meningial irritation is indicated by nuchal rigidity, back pain, and Kernig, and Brudzinski signs (usually not seen in infants). Seizures and altered mental status may be present. 

The recommended empirical antibiotic regimen in a suspected case of meningitis outside the neonatal period is vancomycin combined with a third-generation cephalosporin. Patients allergic to penicillin or cephalosporin can be treated with meropenem, fluoroquinolones, or chloramphenicol. 

Chemoprophylaxis with rifampicin/ceftriaxone/ciprofloxacin is recommended for all close contacts with meningococcal meningitis regardless of age or immunization status. Rifampicin prophylaxis should be given to all household contacts of patients with invasive disease caused by Haemophilus influenzae type b, if an immunocompromised child of any age resides in the household or close family member younger than 48 months has not been fully immunized.

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV-positive male presents with raised violaceous plaques. Microscopy shows a lesion in the dermis lined encompassing small vessels and slitlike spaces containing red cells with marked hemorrhage, hemosiderin pigment, and mononuclear inflammation. Mitotic figures are also seen. Which organism is associated with this tumor?
questions.solution:
Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a vascular neoplasm caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) a γ-herpesvirus that is highly associated with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).

Four forms of KS based on population demographics and risks:

  • Classic KS - Older men of Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, or Eastern European descent. It can be associated with malignancy or altered immunity but is not associated with HIV infection.
  • Endemic African KS -  Typically occurs in HIV-seronegative individuals younger than age 40 and can follow an indolent or aggressive course, with prominent lymph node and visceral involvement, occurs in prepubertal children; the prognosis is poor, with an almost 100% mortality within 3 years.
  • Transplant-associated KS occurs in solid organ transplant recipients in the setting of T-cell immunosuppression. Characteristically involves lymph nodes, mucosa, and viscera; cutaneous lesions may be absent.
  • AIDS-associated (epidemic) KS is an AIDS-defining illness - it represents the most common HIV-related malignancy. AIDS-associated KS often involves lymph nodes and disseminates widely to viscera early in its course.

The given images show coalescent red-purple macules and plaques of the skin and the histologic appearance of Kaposi sarcoma, demonstrating sheets of proliferating spindle cells.

Other options-

Option B: Epstein Barr virus causes Burkitt’s lymphoma, Hodgkin’s lymphoma, Post-transplant lymphoproliferative disease, and Nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Option C: Bartonella henselae causes bacillary angiomatosis especially in immunocompromised patients and is characterised by proliferating cystic blood filled spaces surrounded by a fibromyxoid matrix containing the bacteria. Circumscribed lesions with lobular capillary proliferation and round, open vessels with cuboidal endothelial cells protruding into the vascular lumen are also seen. Mitotic figures are not seen.

Option D: Human papillomavirus type 16 and 18 causes cervical cancer due to mutation in RAS gene.

questions.text: What is true regarding the mirrors used at two ends of the instrument given in the image?

choices.text: Plane at one and concave at other end
Plane at one and convex at other end
Convex at one end and concave at other

questions.solution:
The image is of the Priestley-Smith retinoscope. It is a mirror retinoscope and has a plane mirror at one end and concave at other.

It has a central hole of about 2.5mm anteriorly and 4mm posteriorly.

Retinoscopy is also called a skiascopy/ shadow test. It is used to estimate refraction objectively. The instruments used are:

  • Priestley-Smith retinoscope
  • Streak retinoscope: It is self-illuminated and projects a streak rather than a circle of light.

questions.text: What clinical test is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
The clinical test depicted in the image is Cottle’s test where the cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. 

This test is used to assess the patency of the nasal valve in patients with a deviated nasal septum. If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve on that side.

Option A: Epley’s maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV.

 

Option B: Heimlich manoeuvre is used in the treatment of accidental inhalation of foreign body. Procedure: Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs can dislodge the foreign body providing some airway.

 

Option D: Trotter’s method is used in the treatment of epistaxis. In Trotter’s method, the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood. He should pinch the nose firmly for 5 to 10 mins and breathe quietly from the mouth.

questions.text: An ENT resident is performing the following maneuver in a patient as shown in the image. Which of the following is false regarding the same?

choices.text: It builds negative pressure in the nasopharynx

questions.solution:
The given image depicts the Valsalva manoeuvre and it builds up positive pressure in the nasopharynx and not negative pressure.

In this test, the patient is asked to close the mouth and nostrils and blow. This produces positive pressure within the nasopharynx which opens the patent eustachian tube and is confirmed by the tympanic membrane bulge via otoscopy.

It is used to assess the Eustachian tube patency and to auto-inflate the middle ear.

It is contraindicated in:

  • Atrophic tympanic membrane as it might get ruptured.
  • URTI as the infection can spread into the middle ear.

questions.text: What is the following instrument used to measure?
questions.solution:
The image given is that of an Assmann psychrometer which is used to measure humidity.

They consists of two thermometers each inside a double tube for minimizing radiative heating.

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers

questions.text: A patient is admitted for myocardial infarction complicated by severe mitral regurgitation. He suddenly develops shortness of breath, decreased urine output, and drowsiness. Blood pressure is 86/40 mmHg, pulse 120 bpm, and respiratory rate 24 per minute. Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Up to 40% of cardiac output may be distributed to the respiratory muscles
Patient will develop type 2 respiratory failure
Intubation and mechanical ventilation are treatment of choice
Batwing appearance can be expected on an x-ray

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cardiogenic shock. He is likely to develop type 4 respiratory failure, not type 2. 

Patients in cardiogenic shock often have respiratory distress secondary to acute pulmonary edema (batwing appearance on x-ray). This increases the requirement of oxygen delivery to the respiratory muscles from <5% to up to 40% of cardiac output.

Hypoperfusion and increased oxygen requirement lead to inadequate perfusion of respiratory muscles which causes type 4 respiratory failure.

Intubation and mechanical ventilation are the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 26-year-old batsman was rushed to the ER when he fell unconscious after a cricket ball hit his head. He regained consciousness later but started to deteriorate rapidly. A plain CT of the patient is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of lucid interval in this patient and the CT image are suggestive of extradural hematoma. The above CT scan shows a large extradural hematoma (hyperdense biconvex/lentiform shape) with a mass effect.

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH) is the accumulation of blood between the skull and the dura. It usually results from arterial disruption, especially of the middle meningeal artery. It lies behind the pterion, which is the thinnest part of the skull. 

In EDH, the patient is initially unconscious from the concussive aspect of the head trauma. The patient then awakens and has a “lucid interval,” while the hematoma sub-clinically expands. As the volume of the hematoma grows, intracranial pressure (ICP) increases, and the patient rapidly becomes lethargic and herniates.

Uncal herniation from an EDH classically causes ipsilateral third nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for the treatment of chronic SIADH?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for the treatment of chronic SIADH is tolvaptan.

Vaptans are selective V2 receptor antagonists that act by increasing urinary water excretion by blocking the antidiuretic effect of AVP.

Treatment options for chronic SIADH include:

  • Restriction of fluid intake to below the level of urine output - This is considered the mainstay of treatment. But it also has certain disadvantages as stated below, and hence adding on a drug like vaptan is necessary in most cases.
  • Tolvaptan
  • Demeclocycline
  • Fludrocortisone

Advantages of vaptans over fluid restriction:

  • Fluid restriction is usually a burden to the patient, unreliable, impractical, and slow to work.
  • Increased thirst is a frequently observed characteristic of hyponatremia in SIADH, and is particularly difficult to suppress. Hence, water restriction in SIADH frequently leads to non-compliance in the long run.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission?

choices.text: Government provides health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year
The limit of the family size that is covered is up to 7 members
All pre-existing diseases of the individual are covered
It covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization

questions.solution:
There is no cap on family size or the age of the members. All the families listed under the Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC) database are covered as per the defined criteria.

The following are the benefits provided under this program:

  • Health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year.
  • All families listed in the SECC database, as per the defined criteria, will be covered. There is no cap on family size and age of members.
  • Free treatment is available at all public and empanelled private hospitals
  • Both secondary and tertiary care hospitalization is covered.
  • All pre-existing diseases are covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment.
  • To control costs, the payments for treatment will be done on a package rate (to be defined by the Government in advance) basis.
  • Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services.

questions.text: A patient presented with serous discharge from an opening located in the perianal region. On examination, the location of the external opening was at 8’O clock position. According to Goodsall's rule at what position from the dentate line will the internal opening be palpated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of fistula-in-ano with external opening at 8’O clock position which implies that the external opening of the fistula is lying posterior to the midline. According to the Goodsall rule, fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline. Hence, the fistulous tract opens internally at a 6’O clock position.

A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue and that connects a primary opening inside the anal canal to a secondary opening in the perianal skin.

Goodsall’s rule:

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

However, exceptions to this rule often occur. Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline

questions.text:
As a surgery resident, which of the following will you perform in a patient with suspected breast malignancy as part of the triple assessment?

1. History
2. Clinical examination
3. Radiological investigations
4. Histopathological examination
questions.solution:
Triple assessment in relation to breast carcinoma includes the following:

  • Clinical assessment includes both history and clinical examination
  • Radiological imaging, including ultrasonography (USG) and/or mammography
  • Histopathological examination (HPE), including fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) and/or Tru-Cut biopsy

The positive predictive value of the triple assessment is 99.9%.

Note: Bailey & Love 27th Ed mentions that clinical assessment, radiological imaging, and HPE constitute triple assessment. However, clinical assessment includes both history and clinical examination. Hence, history is a part of the triple assessment.

questions.text: All of the following hormones act via the given pathway except ______
questions.solution:
Estrogen acts through nuclear receptors.

The rest of the hormones in the options act through GPCRs via the cAMP second messenger pathway, which is seen in the image. 

  • The image shows binding of the hormones with the receptor which allows the coupling of the recep­tor to a G protein, leading to activation of adenylate cyclase. 
  • Activated adenylate cyclase then catalyzes the conversion of ATP to cAMP (2nd messenger). 
  • cAMP then activates cAMP-dependent protein kinase A which phosphorylates certain proteins leading to a physiological response.

Hormones using cAMP as the second messenger:

  • CRH, ACTH, Catecholamines (β1 and β2 receptors)
  • Parathyroid Hormone (PTH), calcitonin
  • Growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH)
  • FSH, LH, hCG
  • TSH
  • ADH (V2 receptors)
  • Glucagon
  • Somatostatin
  • Secretin

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features will be most likely seen in a patient with an anterior hypothalamic lesion?
questions.solution:
Lesions involving the anterior and preoptic hypothalamic regions cause paradoxical vasoconstriction, tachycardia, and hyperthermia.

The anterior hypothalamus activates mechanisms of cooling the body when the temperature increases via the reflex response.

Stimulation of the anterior hypothalamus causes cutaneous vasodilation and sweating, thereby cooling the body. Lesions in this region cause hyperthermia, with rectal temperatures sometimes reaching 43°C (109.4°F).

questions.text: Plateau of oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve signifies ______

choices.text: No Hb is available to bind
No oxygen is available for binding

questions.solution:
• The plateau of oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve (OHDC) corresponds to almost 100% saturation of hemoglobin, with all heme groups bound to O2, and affinity for O2 at its highest value due to positive cooperativity.
  • OHDC is sigmoid with the upper end, between a blood Po2 of 60 mm Hg-100 mmHg, the curve flattens off, or plateaus. (refer figure).
  • The plateau portion of the curve is in the blood Po2 range at the pulmonary capillaries where O2 is being loaded onto Hb. (where Po2 and affinity are highest).
  • The steep portion of the curve between 0 and 60 mm Hg is in the blood Po2 range at the systemic capillaries, where O2 is unloaded from Hb. (where Po2 and affinity are lower).

questions.text:
Type II MSUD results from the mutation in the genes encoding _____.

MSUD - Maple syrup urine disease
questions.solution:
Type II maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) results from a mutation in the genes encoding dihydrolipoyl transacylase.

There are 4 known types of Maple Syrup Urine Disease:

  • Type IA and IB MSUD arise from mutations in the E1α and E1b genes, which encode the enzyme α-Ketoacid decarboxylase.
  • Type II arises from mutations in the E2 gene, which encodes dihydrolipoyl transacylase.
  • Type III arises from mutations in the E3 gene, which encodes Dihydrolipoamide dehydrogenase.

questions.text: The dose-response curve is plotted for drug A both in the presence and absence of drug B.  What type of effect does drug B have on drug A?
questions.solution:
Drug B has a competitive antagonistic effect on drug A.

In competitive antagonism, DRC shows a parallel rightward shift. Competitive antagonism occurs when the agonist and antagonist compete for the same binding site on the receptor. The response curve for the agonist shifts to the right in a concentration-related manner by the antagonist.

In non-competitive antagonism, there is flattening of the agonist DRC. Non-competitive antagonism effects occur when the agonist and antagonist bind to different sites on the receptor. ( allosteric site) and inhibits the response. The response curve progressively shifts in a right and downward direction until it reaches a limiting value when the allosteric site is fully occupied.

In competitive agonism, the curve shifts to the left.

In partial agonism, the partial agonist which has an affinity for the same receptor, also competes with and antagonizes a full agonist, while producing a submaximal response.

questions.text: Identify the flap shown in the image used for breast reconstruction.
questions.solution:
The image shows a deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap. It is a free flap and a variant of TRAM flap where only the skin and fat are moved to the chest.

Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous (TRAM) flap is either based on the superior or inferior epigastric artery or both (supercharged TRAM). In a TRAM flap, the skin, fat, and rectus muscle are moved to the chest. 

If robust DIEA perforators are identified with a good caliber and dissection can be performed without dividing the muscle, a DIEP flap is preferred. Otherwise, if small-caliber perforators are encountered and not aligned over the medial or lateral row, a TRAM flap is performed to ensure flap viability.

Option C: Latissimus dorsi (LD) flap is an axial flap based on the thoracodorsal pedicle.

DIEP flap, TRAM flap, and LD flap are autogenous tissues used in breast reconstruction.

questions.text: Accommodative esotropia is more common in ______________
questions.solution:
Accommodative esotropia is more common in hypermetropia. But it may also occur in Anisometropia>1D

Accommodative esotropia is inward deviation of the visual axes caused by high hyperopia or a high accommodative convergence-to-accommodation ratio, or both.

Accommodative esotropia has an average age of onset of 2½ years (usual range, 1 −7 years). 

The esotropia usually occurs when the child first becomes interested in viewing near objects. It is frequently first seen by the parents when the child is tired or not feeling well; in fact, the onset may be precipitated by a febrile illness.

As many as half of all children with esotropia either obtain normal ocular alignment or obtain a significant but not complete reduction of the esotropia when wearing an optical correction for hyperopia.

Esotropia begins as intermittent strabismus. When treatment is delayed or not provided, many deviations become constant, and sensory adaptations such as amblyopia, suppression, and anomalous retinal correspondence may develop with loss of binocular vision.

questions.text: In a rice processing factory, paddy is soaked in hot water.  After this, the water is drained and the paddy is steamed and dried. Which of the following statements is false about the above process?

choices.text: This method is used for partial cooking of rice
It makes the rice grains resistant to insects
Vitamins and minerals are driven into endosperm during this process

questions.solution:
The procedure mentioned above is parboiling. It hardens the rice grains.

Parboiling is the process of partial cooking of rice in steam. It is done by the hot soaking process that was initially developed by the Central Food Technological Research Institute (CFTRI), Mysore.

The advantages of parboiling are:

  • Preserves nutritive quality by driving the vitamins and minerals into the endosperm.
  • Hardens the grains and makes them insect resistant.

questions.text: A person is brought to the emergency department following a blast. On investigation, a small metallic foreign body is found entrapped in the lens of his right eye. What is the best treatment option?
questions.solution:
For a patient with a foreign body in the lens, the best treatment option is complete removal of the lens.

If a foreign body lies within the lens, it is better to treat such particles as if they were non-magnetic or to remove the lens as a whole. For a non-magnetic foreign body:-

  • The foreign body on iris it can usually be picked out by an iris forceps through a suitably placed keratome incision. If entangled an iridectomy is performed.
  • If the foreign body is in the lens, a few days should be allowed to elapse for the aqueous to act upon the lens fibers. Aspiration is then performed and the foreign body is removed with the lens matter.
  • If the foreign body lies on the retina, and if accurate localization has been attained, it is removed directly by intra-vitreal forceps as part of a complete vitrectomy. Laser photocoagulation of the surrounding retina is also done to prevent a late retinal detachment.

questions.text: A medical student receives a booster dose of Hepatitis B vaccination. A few hours later, she develops weakness in the abduction and lateral rotation of that arm. Which nerve is most likely to have been injured?
questions.solution:
The axillary nerve or surgeon's nerve is frequently injured during inadvertent intramuscular (IM) injections. 

The course of axillary nerve:

  • It is a branch of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus in the axilla
  • It exits the axilla through the quadrangular space to enter the arm
  • In the arm, it winds around the surgical neck of the humerus and gives cutaneous supply to the lower part of the deltoid (upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm)

Injuries to the axillary nerve can be caused by:

  • Fracture of surgical neck of humerus
  • Inferior dislocation of the humerus
  • Inadvertent IM injection

Test for axillary nerve involves testing sensations of skin over the lower part of the deltoid. In the case of axillary nerve lesions, there is a loss of sensations over this region. It is called regimental badge anesthesia.

Named nerves of the upper limb are:

  • Laborer’s nerve - median nerve
  • Musician’s nerve - ulnar nerve
  • Surgeon’s nerve - axillary nerve
  • Nerve of Bell - long thoracic nerve

questions.text: A microbiologist observes the following growth on a blood agar plate. Which of the following will not be the etiological agent?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a swarming type of growth on the agar plate. It will not be caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Swarming is the growth of motile bacteria in the form of a thin film on solid culture media. It is exhibited by the following:

  • Gram-positive bacilli - Clostridium tetani (option A), Bacillus cereus (option D)
  • Gram-negative bacilli - Proteus mirabilis (option C), Proteus vulgaris
  • Gram-negative halophilic bacteria- Vibrio parahaemolyticus 

Swarming can be inhibited by increasing the concentration of agar (6%), alcohol, sodium azide, boric acid, chloral hydrate, sulfonamide, and surface-active agents.

questions.text: In psychoanalytical terms, Hysteria is fixed at which phase of psychosexual development?
questions.solution:

  • The psychosexual theory was proposed by Sigmund Freud.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by inhibiting bacterial RNA polymerase?
questions.solution:
Rifampin acts by inhibiting bacterial DNA dependent RNA polymerase.

Rifampin enters M. tuberculosis bacilli in a concentration-dependent manner, achieving steady-state concentrations within 15 minutes. Rifampin binds to the β subunit of DNA-dependent RNA polymerase (rpoB) to form a stable drug-enzyme complex. Drug binding suppresses chain formation in RNA synthesis.

Other options:

  • Aminoglycosides: The primary intracellular site of action of the aminoglycosides is the 30S ribosomal subunit. Aminoglycosides interfere with the initiation of protein synthesis, leading to the accumulation of abnormal initiation complexes; the drugs also can cause misreading of the mRNA template and incorporation of incorrect amino acids into the growing polypeptide chains.
  • Macrolides: Macrolide and ketolide antibiotics are bacteriostatic agents that inhibit protein synthesis by binding reversibly to 50S ribosomal subunits of sensitive microorganisms.
  • Cephalosporins: Bactericidal agents which act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

questions.text: White infarcts are seen in all the following organs except:
questions.solution:
White infarcts occur with arterial occlusions in solid organs with end-arterial circulation like heart, spleen, and kidney, and where tissue density limits the seepage of blood from adjoining capillary beds into the necrotic area.

Red infarcts occur:

  1. with venous occlusions (e.g., testicular torsion)
  2. in loose, spongy tissues (e.g., lung) where blood can collect in the infracted zone
  3. in tissues with dual circulations (e.g., lung and small intestine) that allow blood to flow from an unobstructed parallel supply into a necrotic zone.
  4. in tissues previously congested by sluggish venous outflow
  5. when flow  is reestablished to a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis (e.g., following angioplasty of an arterial obstruction).
  • Infarcts are areas of ischemic necrosis most commonly caused by arterial occlusion (typically due to thrombosis or embolization); venous outflow obstruction is a less frequent cause.
  • Infarcts caused by venous occlusion or occurring in spongy tissues with dual blood supply and where blood can collect typically are hemorrhagic (red); those caused by arterial occlusion in compact tissues typically are pale (white).
  • Whether or not vascular occlusion causes tissue infarction is influenced by collateral blood supplies, the rate at which an obstruction develops, intrinsic tissue susceptibility to ischemic injury, and blood oxygenation.
