questions.text: The carotid angiography of a 30-year-old with a carotid body tumor shows splaying at the bifurcation of the carotids as seen in the image below. At what level do you expect to find this?
questions.solution:
The bifurcation of the common carotid artery is at the level of the upper border of thyroid cartilage (C3-C4 junction). Carotid body tumors present at the bifurcation of the CCA and cause the external carotid artery (ECA) and internal carotid artery (ICA) to spread out, or splay, which is called 'Lyre sign' as seen on carotid angiography.

The course of the common carotid artery (CCA):

  • The right and the left common carotid arteries differ in their origin:
    • The right CCA arises from the brachiocephalic artery
    • The left CCA arises directly from the arch of the aorta.
  • In the neck, it is enclosed within the carotid sheath along with the internal jugular vein and vagus nerve.
  • It ascends upwards up to the upper border of the thyroid cartilage (C3-4 junction) and divides into internal and external carotid arteries

Clinical significance of carotid bifurcation:

  • Chassaignac/carotid tubercle/transverse process of C6 vertebra: The pulsations of the common carotid artery can be felt by compressing the artery against this tubercle. 
  • Site of carotid body tumor
  • The most common site for carotid atherosclerosis. It can lead to stroke or transient ischaemic attack (TIA).
  • In carotid endarterectomy, the presence of high bifurcation predisposes to injury to the cranial nerves, commonly the hypoglossal nerve or marginal mandibular nerve. In such patients, carotid stenting is usually preferred to carotid endarterectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for estrogen therapy?
questions.solution:
Hypertension is not a contraindication for hormone replacement therapy (HRT). HRT can be initiated in patients with a history of hypertension, diabetes, or smoking; provided they are regularly monitored.

Contraindications of estrogen therapy:

  • Breast cancer, uterine cancer, or family history of cancer
  • Previous history of thromboembolic episode
  • Liver and gall bladder diseases
  • Uterine fibroids - as the fibroids may enlarge in size.

questions.text: Which of the following findings during an exercise tolerance test is not associated with multivessel coronary artery disease?

choices.text: Persistence of ST segment changes late into recovery phase
Failure to increase systolic BP by at least 20mmHg

questions.solution:
A failure to increase systolic blood pressure by 10 mm Hg, or a sustained decrease in systolic blood pressure of 10 mm Hg or more, is suggestive of multivessel (or left main) CAD.

Other abnormalities on exercise testing that are suggestive of multivessel CAD include:

  • Early-onset of ischemic ST-segment depression
  • ST-segment depression of ≥2 mm (0.2mV) involving 5 or more leads, or persisting ≥5 minutes into recovery
  • Exercise-induced ST-segment elevation is also consistent with multivessel CAD
  • Recent evidence suggests that ST-segment elevation of ≥1 mm in lead aVR may be a significant predictor of left main coronary artery disease, proximal left anterior descending (LAD) artery disease, or at least multivessel CAD

An exercise tolerance/treadmill test involves walking in place on a treadmill while monitoring the electrical activity of your heart. Throughout the test, the speed and incline of the treadmill increase. The results show how well your heart responds to the stress of different levels of exercise.

World Heart Day is observed annually on September 29th. The aim of this campaign is to beat the cardiovascular disease, it is something that matters to every beating heart. This year's theme is USE HEART FOR EVERY HEART.

questions.text: In a study, two groups of newborns are checked for differences in their birth weights based on whether mothers received supplements or not. Which of the following would be most appropriate test of significance?
questions.solution:
The unpaired t-test is used to test the difference between two groups of parametric variables or means when the samples are independent of each other. Here, birth weights (quantitative variable) of the two groups of newborns are being compared, which are independent of each other.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A full-term infant with a history of polyhydramnios in utero presents with respiratory distress soon after birth. On examination, the child has frothing of saliva and the resident suspects tracheoesophageal fistula. What is the most common type of fistula likely to be present in this child?
questions.solution:
Type C is the commonest variety of tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF). 

A tracheoesophageal fistula is an abnormal communication between the esophagus and trachea. Type C lesion is associated with proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF. The proximal blind pouch ends approximately at the distance of one or two vertebral bodies from the distal TEF.

Tracheoesophageal fistula is associated with VACTERL (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb) anomalies. 

Drooling of saliva, inability to pass a nasogastric tube and history of polyhydramnios suggest a diagnosis of oesophagal atresia with or without TEF. This can be confirmed with a chest X-ray image showing a coiled nasogastric tube in the oesophagal pouch as shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheo-esophageal Fistula/Esophageal Atresia

Abbreviations:

  • EA: Esophageal atresia
  • TEF: Tracheo-esophageal Fistula

questions.text: Pink tetralogy of fallot is present when there is__________
questions.solution:
In pink or acyanotic tetralogy of fallot, the patient is not visibly cyanotic. It is present when there is mild to moderate right ventricular outflow obstruction and a balanced shunt is present through VSD.

Tetralogy of Fallot: It is the most common cyanotic congenital heart disease. Four anatomical components of TOF include

  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Obstruction to right ventricular outflow - Pulmonic stenosis (PS)
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)
  • Overriding (or dextroposition) of the aorta

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding hydrops fetalis in Rh-negative pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Complication of hydrops in Rh-negative pregnancy:

Hydrops fetalis

  • As a result of fetal anoxemia, there is damage to the liver leading to hypoproteinemia which is responsible for generalized edema (Hydrops fetalis), ascites, and hydrothorax.
  • Fetal death occurs sooner or later due to cardiac failure.
  • Serial ultrasonography may detect fetal hydrops and anemia.
  • Important features
    • Polyhydramnios
    • Placental thickness >4 cm
    • Pericardial or pleural effusion
    • Echogenic bowel
    • Dilatation of cardiac chambers
    • Enlargement of spleen and liver

Congenital Anemia of the Newborn

  • This is the mildest form of the disease where hemolysis is occurring slowly.
  • Although anemia develops slowly within the first weeks of life, the jaundice is not usually evident.
  • The destruction of red cells continues up to 6 weeks after which antibodies are not available for hemolysis.
  • The liver and spleen are enlarged, as they are the sites of extramedullary erythropoiesis.

Icterus Gravis Neonatarum

  • This clinical entity is the effect of lesser form of Rh alloimmunization.
  • The baby is born alive without evidence of jaundice but soon develops it within 24 hours of birth.

questions.text: You notice the following lesion in the forearm of an otherwise normal newborn. The lesion is caused because of:

choices.text: A viral infection transmitted from mother to the fetus
A bacterial infection transmitted from the mother to the fetus
Vigorous in utero sucking upon the affected part
An autoimmune condition in the newborn

questions.solution:
The image shows Sucking Blisters.
Sucking blisters are caused due to vigorous in utero sucking on the affected part.

They are usually present upon the upper-limb.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient has come with sudden onset of chest pain and his CT scan shows the following picture. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan showing a double lumen and dilatation of the aorta is suggestive of an aortic dissection. 

In this condition, blood enters the space below the intima of the aorta. This results in the formation of a true lumen and false lumen. The true lumen is often the smaller of the two because of being compressed by the false lumen, as shown below.

The beak sign in aortic dissection is a reliable sign to identify the false lumen. It refers to the acute angle formed at the edge of the false lumen in aortic dissection in axial cross-section. It is formed by the borders of the outer aortic wall and the intimal flap, and maybe partially thrombosed (blunted beak).

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy had a gradually progressive plaque on a buttock for the last 3 years. The plaque was 15cms in diameter, annular in shape, with scarring in the center. The most likely diagnosis is _________
questions.solution:
• The above clinical history of progressive plaque on the buttocks with central scarring is suggestive of lupus vulgaris.
  • Lupus vulgaris is a chronic skin infection which is caused by M. tuberculosis.
  • It is a paucibacillary lesion in a previously sensitized host with good immunity.
  • In India, the most common site is buttocks or trunk.
  • In Europe, the most common lesion is in head and neck.
  • The characteristic lesion is a plaque with an irregular edge with islands of active lupus tissue.
  • On diascopy, apple jelly nodules are seen.

questions.text: A woman presented to the clinic with redness and itching over the left breast as shown in the image below.  Histopathology showed large pale vacuolated cells with round nuclei in the epithelium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and histology are suggestive of Paget's disease of the breast. 

Paget’s disease is a rare type of cancer involving the nipple-areolar complex, often with an underlying in-situ or invasive ductal carcinoma. It presents as a chronic, eczematous eruption of the nipple which may progress to ulceration. Paget disease of the breast is often mistaken for eczema. 

  Paget's disease Eczema
Laterality Unilateral Bilateral
Age group Menopausal women Lactating women
Edges Distinct Indistinct
Vesicles Absent Present
Nipple Usually destroyed Usually intact
Lump Usually present No underlying lump 

A nipple biopsy specimen of Paget's disease will show a population of cells that are identical to the underlying malignant cells. The presence of large, pale, vacuolated cells (Paget cells) with round or oval nuclei are pathognomonic for this condition.

Depending on the type and extent of underlying malignancy, it can be treated with lumpectomy or mastectomy.

Note: Histologically, Paget's disease can be confused with superficial spreading melanoma, particularly if they have incorporated melanin from adjacent epidermis. Paget's disease shows positive immunostaining with carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), while superficial spreading melanoma is positive for S-100 antigen.

questions.text: The Topographic Theory of Mind was described by_____
questions.solution:
Sigmund Freud described the topographic theory of mind in the year 1900 and has written a book named the interpretation of dreams.

According to the topographic theory of mind, the mind is divided into 3 levels:

  • Unconscious: Contents and thought processes are hidden from conscious awareness through the force of censorship or repression, and it is closely related to instinctual drives.
  • Preconscious: composed of those mental events, processes, and contents that can be brought into conscious awareness by the act of focusing attention. Although most persons are not consciously aware of the appearance of their first-grade teacher, they ordinarily can bring this image to mind by deliberately focusing attention on the memory.
  • Conscious: part of the mind in which perceptions coming from the outside world or from within the body or mind are brought into awareness.

Related Pearl: Contributions by Sigmund Freud

Contributions of Sigmund Freud to the field of psychiatry

  • Free association
  • Interpretation of dreams
  • Psychoanalysis
  • Psycho-sexual development 
  • Psychodynamic theory 
  • Topographic theory of the mind-unconscious, preconscious, conscious
  • Structural theory of mind- id, ego, superego
  • Cocaine in psychiatry

questions.text: The first ketone body formed during ketogenesis is?
questions.solution:
Acetoacetate is the first ketone body to be synthesized in ketogenesis.

Acetoacetate, acetone, and Beta-hydroxybutyrate are the ketone bodies.

Acetoacetyl Co-A is the substrate for ketogenesis.

Ketogenesis:

  • Two molecules of acetyl coA are condensed to form acetoacetyl co-A, in the presence of enzyme thiolase.
  • Acetoacetyl coA condenses with another molecule of acetyl co-A to form HMG coA, by the enzyme HMG coA synthase.
  • Enzyme HMG coA lyase splits the acetyl-coA from HMG coA leading to the formation of acetoacetate.
  • Acetoacetate may get decorboxylated to acetone or reduced to beta-hydroxybutyrate.

Related Pearl: Ketogenesis

questions.text: In the Lac operon model, how does the presence of lactose activate transcription?

choices.text: Lactose binds to the operator region and blocks the attachment of RNA polymerase to the promoter
Lactose binds directly to the promoter region and activates transcription
Lactose binds to repressor protein and inactivates it

questions.solution:
In the Lac operon model, lactose binds to the repressor protein and inactivates it, thus activating transcription. 

When lactose is present in abundance, a small amount of lactose is converted to allolactose. This compound binds to the repressor protein of the lac operon and creates a conformational change. As a result, the repressor cannot bind to the operator and transcription of the structural genes occurs. This is an example of negative regulation.

This can only occur when glucose is absent. In the absence of glucose, adenylyl cyclase is active. This generates sufficient quantities of cAMP which bind to catabolite activator protein (CAP).The cAMP–CAP trans-acting complex binds to the CAP-binding site, another regulatory region present upstream of the structural genes of the operon. This causes RNA polymerase to more efficiently initiate transcription at the promoter site. This is an example of positive regulation.

questions.text: All of the following derangements can be expected in a patient with acute pancreatitis except:
questions.solution:
Acute pancreatitis causes hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia.

The pancreatic enzymes cause autodigestion of the mesenteric fat leading to the release of free fatty acids. These free fatty acids combine with calcium to form calcium salts, causing low levels of circulating calcium.

Hypercalcemia may cause acute pancreatitis. Hypocalcemia is a complication of acute pancreatitis. 

Related Pearl: Laboratory Findings in Acute Pancreatitis

  • Elevated serum amylase and serum lipase
    • Serum amylase level rises immediately and peaks in few hours and returns to normal in 3–5 days
    • Serum amylase level lacks specificity
    • Serum amylase levels do not correlate with the severity of pancreatitis.
    • Serum lipase is more specific, and it is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours later
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia, hypoalbuminemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Elevated serum levels of hepatic enzymes like alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
  • Azotemia, due to prerenal acute renal failure in case of severe fluid loss

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive man presents with fever for 3 weeks, dry cough, and significant weight loss. He complains of retrosternal chest pain that is worse on inspiration. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a case of pneumonia in a HIV positive patient, along with the presence of fever, and non-productive cough with radiographic findings of diffuse interstitial infiltrates and symmetric perihilar involvement is Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP). A characteristic feature of PCP is retrosternal chest pain, which worsens on inspiration and is described as sharp or burning.

It is important to note that even though the incidence of PCP is the highest at CD4+ counts of <200/μL (80%), it can be seen in patients with higher counts.

Other options:

Option D: Tuberculosis (TB) should be considered as a possibility in cases of pneumonia in people living with HIV. However, the absence of hilar lymph node involvement, non-productive cough, and no extrapulmonary (pleural, pericardial, lymphatic) features are not consistent with tuberculosis.

TB can occur at any stage of HIV infection. In the early stages, pulmonary TB appears typically with upper-lobe infiltrates and cavitation. In advanced HIV infection, with CD4+ T-cell count below 200/μL, TB presents with diffuse interstitial infiltrates, minimal cavitation, pleural effusion, and lymphadenopathy. Extrapulmonary TB is fairly common in HIV, with it being documented in 40-60% of cases.

Option A: Staphylococcal pneumonia most commonly presents with a productive cough, and radiologically presents with pneumatoceles (cavitations)

Option B: Patients with pneumococcal pneumonia also present with fever, dyspnea, and productive cough. Imaging usually shows lobar involvement.

Related Pearl: Typical Pneumonia v/s Atypical Pneumonia

Extracellular organism  Intracellular organism

Dry cough

  • The most common cause of Community-acquired Pneumonia- Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • The most common cause of Atypical Pneumonia- Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
  • The most common cause of Nosocomial Pneumonia-

    • The single most common agent- Staphylococcus aureus (i.e., gram-positive cocci)

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset headache and photophobia. On examination, she is disoriented and febrile. The investigations and peripheral smear are given below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this disease?

Hemoglobin - 11.2 g/dl

Platelet count - 32,000/uL

Serum creatinine - 3.9 mg/dl

Blood urea nitrogen - 38 mg/dl

choices.text: It is caused by ADAMTS13 deficiency
20% patients  will have falsely positive  RA factor
Arrhythmias are a frequent cause of death
Mainstay of treatment is blood transfusion

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and image showing schistocytes (fragmented RBCs) in a woman are suggestive of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). Blood transfusion is not preferred in TTP as it can aggravate the condition.

TTP is a type of thrombotic microangiopathy that occurs due to deficiency or autoantibodies against the ADAMTS13 metalloprotease, which is responsible for cleaving von Willebrand factor multimers. In the absence of this protein, vWF multimers aggregate and form thrombi. It presents with a classical pentad of clinical features:

  1. Fever
  2. Thrombocytopenia
  3. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  4. Renal failure
  5. Neurological manifestations

It is treated with plasmapheresis and rituximab.

questions.text: A 28-year-old P1L1 woman presented with heavy menstrual bleeding and occasional spotting between cycles. What is the first investigation to be done for her?
questions.solution:
The first investigation to be done in a case of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) in the reproductive age group is urine β-hCG estimation. This is done to rule out pregnancy.

In the reproductive age group, anovulatory uterine bleeding is encountered less often. Therefore, pregnancy must be excluded. Pregnancy complications such as miscarriage, ectopic pregnancies, and molar pregnancies may present with AUB, hence these need to be ruled out by urine β-hCG levels. This is done for all women in the reproductive age group. 

Other investigations to be done for AUB are:

  • Pap smear - to rule out cervical cancer and preinvasive lesions (CIN).
  • Transabdominal ultrasound - to visualize the pelvic organs and lesions such as endometrial hyperplasia, polyps, fibroids, etc.
  • Transvaginal ultrasound - to visualize the pelvic organs. It is done after evaluating β-hCG. This is more comfortable for a patient compared to a transabdominal ultrasound as it doesn't require a full bladder.

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent kidney stones. Microscopic examination finding of the urine specimen is shown below. Which of the following is not seen in the urine of this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows hexagonal, translucent and white crystals suggestive of cystinuria. Histidine is not seen in the urine of this patient. 

Cystinuria is an autosomal-recessive disease due to a defect in renal PCT & intestinal amino acid transporter that is essential for reabsorptive transport of Cystine and the dibasic amino acids Ornithine, Lysine, and Arginine (COLA).

Diagnosis of cystinuria is by the cyanide–nitroprusside test. Initial treatment is with adequate hydration, alkalization of the urine with citrate supplementation or acetazolamide, and dietary modification to reduce salt and protein intake. If this fails then patients are usually started on chelation therapy with penicillamine.

questions.text: The Resident asks you to perform Allen's test in a patient before cannulating the Radial Artery. This is because Allen’s test is mainly used for _________

choices.text: Assessment of ulnar collateral blood flow
Assessment of radial collateral blood flow

questions.solution:
Allen's Test is mainly used to test the adequacy of ulnar collateral blood flow to the hand, which is usually done prior to radial artery cannulation.

Procedure:

  • The radial and ulnar arteries are occluded and the patient is asked to make a tight fist so as to exsanguinate the palm.
  • Then the patient is asked to open the hand and the occlusion over the ulnar artery is released.

Interpretation:

  • As occlusion of the ulnar artery is released, the colour of the open palm is observed. Normally, the color will return to the palm within 5 – 6 seconds.
  • If the palm remains pale for more than 6-10 seconds, it indicates reduced ulnar collateral flow.
  • The modified Allen’s test considers a threshold of 5 seconds.

Clinical significance:

  • In recent years, the studies have shown that, although the Allen test is often used to identify patients at increased risk for ischemic complications from radial artery cannulation, the predictive value of this test is poor.
  • It is also used for identifying patients acceptable for radial artery harvest or use for coronary angiography.

questions.text: How much is one equivalent of calcium (molecular weight = 40)?
questions.solution:
1 equivalent of calcium is 20 g.

One equivalent is 1 mol of an ionized substance divided by its valency.

For calcium in solution, 1 mol is going to be 40g and its valency is 2. Therefore, 1 equivalent of calcium is 40/2 = 20g.

questions.text:
A group of demographers studied the changes in the birth and death rates of two countries, A and B from the year 2001 to 2011. The collected data is given below. In which stages of the demographic cycle are countries A and B in respectively?

Country A:

  2001 2011
Birth rate 38.3 38.3
Death rate 13.7 10.2

Country B:

  2001 2011
Birth rate 12.4 12.3
Death rate 6.7 6.6
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, country A is in stage 2 and country B is in stage 4 of the demographic cycle. 

According to the given data, in country A, the high birth rate has remained unchanged with a decline in the death rate. This will result in an exponential increase in the population. This means country A is in the early expanding stage of the demographic cycle.

In country B, the low birth rate and death rates have remained unchanged. Thus, the population will attain a plateau phase and remain stationary. This means country B is in the low stationary stage of the demographic cycle.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding HHV?

choices.text: HHV 2 is the main cause of genital herpes infections
Infectivity of type 1 is more temperature sensitive than type 2
Type 2 strains are more neurovirulent in lab animals than type 1
HHV 2 tends to remain latent in sacral ganglion

questions.solution:
• Infectivity of human herpesvirus (HHV) type 2 is more temperature sensitive than type 1.
  • HHV 1 is usually isolated from lesions in and around the mouth and is transmitted by direct contact or droplet spread.
  • HHV 2 is the main causative agent for genital herpes and is transmitted venereally.
  • Type 2 strains replicate well in chick embryo fibroblast cells than type 1.
  • Type 2 strains are more neuro-virulent than type 1 in lab animals.
  • Infectivity of type 2 is more temperature sensitive than type 1.
  • The virus remains latent in the ganglia particularly of the trigeminal nerve (HHV type 1) and sacral (HHV2) nerves, which later gets reactivated to cause recurrent oral and genital lesions.

questions.text: In a patient with findings as shown in the image, which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: It is known as elephantiasis of the nose
It is seen in long standing cases of acne rosacea
It is commonly seen in middle aged women
It is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous glands

questions.solution:
The given image is diagnostic of rhinophyma. It is commonly seen in men past middle age.

Rhinophyma or potato tumour or elephantiasis of nose is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous glands. It is usually associated with long-standing cases of acne rosacea. Mostly seen at the tip of the nose and causes unsightly appearance and obstruction to breathing and vision. 

Treatment: Debulk of the tumor with carbon dioxide laser and the area is allowed to re-epithelialize. Sometimes the tumor is completely excised and skin is grafted over the raw area.

questions.text: Abdominal examination of a 28-year-old primigravida, who is in the second stage of labour, reveals retraction ring between the active upper segment and the distended lower segment. Which would best describe this ring?
questions.solution:
Bandl's ring refers to pathological retraction ring. It is formed in cases of obstructed labour.

The upper segment of the uterus contracts and retracts vigourously in an attempt to overcome the obstruction while the lower segment dilates.

With each contraction there is myometrial shortening so that the actively contracting upper segment becomes progressively thicker and shorter. The passive lower segment is progressively stretched and becomes thinner.

The junction between the two segments stands out prominently as a pathological retraction ring.

Schroeder's constriction ring is formed due to incordinate uterine action when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibres of the uterus. It is formed due to injudicious use of oxytocin and premature rupture of membranes (PROM).

Related Pearl: Constriction ring v/s retraction ring in uterus

Cause Undue irritability of uterus due to injudicious use of oxytocin Obstructed labor

Usually at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Location does not alter once formed.

Always at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Progressively moves upwards after formed.
Per abdomen Ring not felt Ring is felt
Per Vaginal Ring is felt Ring not felt

questions.text: The factor responsible for pubertal growth in females is :

choices.text: Pulsatile release of GnRH during sleep
Increased sensitivity of the Hypothalamo-Pituitary-Ovarian(HPO) axis to estrogen

questions.solution:
The pulsatile release of GnRH during sleep is the factor responsible for pubertal growth in females.  

The various events that happen are

  • HPO axis differentiates and develops during fetal life and becomes fully functional before birth but remains inactive after late infancy. 
  • Adrenarche happens in late childhood, i.e an increase in adrenal androgen production
  • Pubarche follows, resulting in the growth of axillary and pubic hair.
  • FSH & LH rise followed by a gradual rise of estradiol causing thelarche
  • Pulsatile secretion of GnRH increases and this stimulates the HPO axis, resulting in gonadarche and also in Pubertal growth.

 

Note:

Though the growth spurt is an effect of increased GH due to high estrogen levels, the onset of puberty per se is due to pulsatile secretion of GnRH and is the main underlying factor behind puberty and associated growth. Hence that is considered to be the more appropriate answer.

questions.text: When a nerve is cut, which of the following takes place first?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, myelin degeneration would be the best answer.

However, the earliest change in Wallerian degeneration after nerve injury is the degeneration of the axon distal to the site of injury (axonal degeneration) where there is a disruption of the retrograde and anterograde flow of signals within the axon.

Wallerian degeneration

  • If the axon is cut, the part distal to the cut degenerates; this process is called as Wallerian degeneration. 
  • Orthograde degeneration (Wallerian degeneration) occurs from the point of injury to the nerve terminal, interrupting neural transmission. 
  • After the injury, the membrane breaks down and the myelin sheath degenerates. The cell body of the injured neuron swells, the nucleus moves to an eccentric position, and the rough endoplasmic reticulum becomes fragmented (chromatolytic reaction).
  • The nerve then starts to regrow, with multiple small branches projecting along the path the axon previously followed (regenerative sprouting).
  • When the motor nerve to skeletal muscle is cut and allowed to degenerate, the muscle gradually becomes extremely sensitive to acetylcholine. This is called denervation hypersensitivity or supersensitivity.

questions.text: In which of the following types of asphyxia can one see the most marked congestion and cyanosis?
questions.solution:
The most marked congestion and cyanosis are seen in a case of traumatic asphyxia.

It is the mechanical fixation of the chest (sitting on the chest). It acts by restricting respiratory movements and thus prevents inspiration.

The four signs of asphyxia are as follows.

  • Petechial haemorrhages
  • Congestion and edema
  • Cyanosis
  • Engorgement of the right heart and abnormal fluidity of the blood.

These signs are non-specific. But in traumatic asphyxia, there is a marked demonstration of these signs. In no other condition, apart from postural dependency, is the degree of congestion and cyanosis so marked.

The image shows the marked congestion seen in traumatic asphyxia.

questions.text: In the assessment of a patient’s airway, which of the following cannot be used?
questions.solution:
BURP is not a method of assessment of airway.

BURP is a technique of external laryngeal manipulation of the airway during intubation for better visualization of the larynx. This involves Backward, Upward, Rightward Pressure on thyroid cartilage.

Various methods of airway assessments are

Mallampati classification: correlates tongue size to pharyngeal size.

Cormack and Lehane grading is based on laryngoscopy view

Wilson’s scoring is based on 5 factors: weight, upper spine mobility, jaw movement, receding mandible, and buck teeth.

BURP maneuver should not be confused with Sellick's maneuver (cricoid pressure), which involves the application of pressure to the cricoid cartilage, thus occluding the esophagus. This technique is used in rapid-sequence induction to reduce the risk of aspiration.

questions.text: Given below is a histological section of the thyroid gland. Identify the structure marked X in the image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked X is the C-cells or the parafollicular cells of the thyroid gland.

The C-cells are present between the follicular cells and the basement membrane or between the follicles. They secrete calcitonin.

The thyroid gland is covered by a fibrous capsule with septae dividing it into lobules. These lobules contain follicles lined by follicular cells. The shape of the follicular cells depends on the activity of the gland. They're squamous in the inactive state, cuboidal to columnar in the active state. The cavity of the follicle contains colloid which appears pink in H and E staining.

Option D: Hürthle cells are oncocytes with eosinophilic granular cytoplasm and a vesicular nucleus with a large nucleolus found in the thyroid arising from follicular cells. They are seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis, Hürthle cell adenoma and Hürthle cell carcinoma of the thyroid.

  • Most common nephropathy associated with malignancy.
  • The highest incidence of renal vein thrombosis.
  • Light microscopy shows uniform thickening of the basement membrane along with peripheral capillary loops. 
  • Immunofluorescence shows diffuse granular deposits of IgG and C3.

Other options:

Option b: Male to female ratio is 2:1

Option c: Electron microscopy shows subepithelial deposits (not subendothelial deposits)

Option d:  Associated with antibodies against M-type phospholipase A2 receptor on human podocytes (antibodies against Megalin are present in rats, not in humans)

questions.solution:

A cystocele is the herniation of the urinary bladder into the vagina. It is usually associated with uterine prolapse, and presents with the following features:

questions.text: A patient with a solitary, 2x3 cm, nodular thyroid swelling came to your clinic with a recent report that showed elevated T4 and normal TSH levels.  What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ultrasonography is the next best step in the evaluation of a euthyroid (normal TSH) patient with a solitary thyroid nodule. USG is a non-invasive and inexpensive way to stratify the risk of the nodule into benign or malignant tissue.

Benign nodules are easily compressible and can be seen to deform by applying pressure with the probe while performing USG. Malignant nodules tend to be hard and firm. 

Ultrasound findings of a nodule that are considered suspicious of malignancy include:

  • Microcalcifications
  • Hypervascularity
  • Infiltrative margins
  • Hypoechoic compared with surrounding parenchyma

questions.text: A 60-year-old male who is on warfarin prophylaxis for atrial fibrillation presents with massive uncontrolled haemorrhage following a fall from height. Which of the following blood components can be used for emergency reversal of warfarin therapy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Prothrombin Complex Concentrates (PCCs) are indicated for the emergency reversal of anticoagulant (warfarin) therapy in uncontrolled hemorrhage.

PCCs are highly purified concentrates prepared from pooled plasma. They contain factors II, IX and X. Factor VII may be included or produced separately.

Fresh frozen plasma and platelets are used in management of coagulopathy. Fresh frozen plasma is used if prothrombin time (PT) or partial thromboplastin time (PTT) >1.5 times normal. Platelets are transfused if platelet count <50 x103/ul.

However, in the presence of non-surgical haemorrhage these tests take time to arrange and may underestimate the degree of coagulopathy.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient has been given an intradermal injection of 0.1ml PPD (5 tuberculin units) over the forearm.   After 72 hrs, the site is examined as shown in the image below. What is the interpretation of the result obtained?

choices.text: Tuberculin test negative, suggesting immunity from TB
Tuberculin test positive, suggesting an active infection
Tuberculin test negative, suggesting a recent or past infection
Tuberculin test positive, suggesting a recent or past infection

questions.solution:
The above image shows an induration of >10 mm after 72 hrs of intradermal PPD injection suggesting a positive tuberculin test(TST), indicating recent or past infection. 

In TST, 0.1 ml of PPD (purified protein derivative) containing 5 TU (tuberculosis unit) is injected intradermally and induration is read after 48-72 hours. An induration of 10 mm or more is considered positive in patients from countries with a high prevalence of tuberculosis. Surrounding erythema is not considered. 

A positive tuberculin test indicates hypersensitivity to tuberculoprotein, denoting either latent infection with tubercle bacilli, or BCG immunization, or recent or past infection with or without clinical disease. 

False positives may be seen in infections with related mycobacteria and false negatives in miliary tuberculosis, severely immunosuppressed states, etc.

questions.text: The lining epithelium of the vagina is ______.
questions.solution:
The lining epithelium of the vagina is the non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium

The stratified squamous epithelia are subdivided into two types

  2. Non-keratinized epithelium - It is present over the surface that is subjected to abrasion but not drying. It is seen in
    • The lining of the oral cavity except the parts mentioned above

    • Part of the anal canal

    • Vestibule of the nasal cavities

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the major diagnostic triad of fat embolism syndrome (FES)?
questions.solution:
Fat globules in urine is a minor criterion in diagnosing fat embolism syndrome.

Fat embolism syndrome is caused by the release of fat globules from the bone marrow into the bloodstream. It usually occurs following long bone or pelvic fractures, and multiple fractures.

Along with platelet aggregates, the globules result in the following manifestations which make up the major diagnostic triad:

  • Respiratory insufficiency
  • Neurological impairment
  • Petechial rash

Related Pearl: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria
  • Petechial rash
  • Respiratory symptoms with radiographic changes
  • CNS depression.

Minor criteria

  • Tachycardia
  • Pyrexia
  • Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)
  • Renal abnormalities (oliguria, anuria, or lipiduria)
  • Acute thrombocytopenia
  • Acute decrease in hemoglobin
  • Fat globules in sputum
  • Increased ESR

2 major criteria OR one major criteria + four minor criteria suggest a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is found to be positive for SARS-CoV-2. On contact tracing, 30 people have been identified as close contacts but none of them shows any symptoms or signs. What is the time duration for which they must be quarantined?
questions.solution:
Quarantine is the limitation in freedom of movement of healthy contacts of cases, who have been exposed for a period that lasts as long as the maximal incubation period of the disease.

It is a primary level of prevention and falls under specific protection measures. The various types of quarantine are:

  • Absolute - Complete limitation of movement
  • Modified - Selective partial limitation of movement
  • Segregation - Observation of a group of persons in a population after separation

questions.text: Which of the following cardiac biomarkers do you expect to be elevated in a patient suffering from unstable angina?
questions.solution:
No cardiac biomarkers are elevated in unstable angina (UA).

UA is diagnosed in patients with symptoms suggestive of an ACS with no elevation of biomarkers. If cardiac biomarkers are elevated in these patients, then the diagnosis of MI is considered.

Acute coronary syndromes (ACS) includes:

  • Unstable angina(UA)
  • Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction(NSTEMI)
  • ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)

questions.text: In patients with chronic myeloid leukemia, which of the following are predominantly elevated in the peripheral smear?
questions.solution:
Myelocytes will be predominantly elevated in the peripheral smear of the patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

The clinical hallmark of CML is the uncontrolled production of mature and maturing granulocytes. All of the stages of development of granulocytes can be noted on the peripheral smear in varying numbers:

  • Myeloblast - large cells with a round or oval nucleus, cytoplasm is dark and has no granules
  • Myelocyte - nucleus is oval and is eccentrically placed.
  • Metamyelocyte - nucleus is like a kidney bean-shaped 
  • Band forms - nucleus is in the shape of C or U.
  • Segmented neutrophils- nucleus has 2-5 lobes.

All the cells except the myeloblast have a granular cytoplasm. Due to the varied appearance of the cells, it is called garden party appearance or college girl's appearance.

questions.text: A man who regularly uses contact lenses comes with complaints of blurred vision and ocular pain. Examination shows radial keratoneuritis as seen below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above presentation of blurred vision and pain, along with the findings of a radial keratoneuritis and ring lesion (seen in the image), suggests a probable diagnosis of acanthamoeba keratitis. 

It is caused by Acanthamoeba spp which are free-living protozoa found in soil, freshwater, and the upper respiratory tract. Contact lens wearers are the most prone to this infection.

Patients complain of blurring of vision and pain is often disproportionate to examination. There are characteristic perineural infiltrates, otherwise known as radial keratoneuritis, are pathognomonic and can be seen during early infection. As the infiltrates grow, they gradually coalesce to form the typical ring abscess.

Staining of the corneal scraping using periodic acid-Schiff or calcofluor white as well as culture is done to diagnose the disease. 

Management includes topical amoebecides, analgesics for pain, as well as debridement of the involved epithelium. Therapeutic keratoplasty is done for resistant cases. 

 The below image shows a hypopyon and typical ring abscess of amebic keratitis.

 

Other options:

Option A: Staphylococcal keratitis usually presents as photophobia, blurred vision, mucopurulent discharge and focal and well-defined white/yellowish-white infiltrate. There are features of anterior uveitis with hypopyon and keratic precipitates.

Option B: Candidal keratitis would present as a typical yellow-white densely suppurative infiltrate. Features of anterior uveitis can also be seen here. 

Option C: Herpes simplex keratitis presents as ocular discomfort, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity. HSV can cause characteristic epithelial (dendritic/geographic) keratitis or disciform keratitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor in patients with penile cancer?
questions.solution:
Inguinal lymph node status is the most important prognostic indicator in penile carcinoma.

The prognosis for tumors confined to the penis is good with 5-year survival rates in excess of 80%. With nodal involvement, the 5-year survival rate falls to around 40%.

questions.text: A patient presented with esophageal varices and liver span of 20 cm. All the following are the likely cause except
questions.solution:
All of the above diagnosis are likely except Postnecrotic cirrhosis.

This patient presents with features of portal hypertension (esophageal varices) and an enlarged liver (normal liver span=12-15 cm). Of all the given causes of cirrhosis, post necrosis cirrhosis is associated with a shrunken liver.

Postnecrotic cirrhosis is characterized by a shrunken liver with reduced liver span. Hemochromatosis, alcoholic liver disease, veno-occlusive disease and Budd Chiari syndrome are associated with enlarged liver and portal hypertension.

Causes of postnecrotic cirrhosis 

  • Idiopathic 
  • Viral infections(Hepatitis B & C)
  • Acetaminophen toxicity
  • Parasitic infection

questions.text: In a patient with bacterial vaginosis, which of the following microscopic features would not be seen?
questions.solution:
An abundance of polymorphs is not a microscopic finding of bacterial vaginosis because it is not an inflammatory condition. It occurs due to an alteration in the normal vaginal flora.

A swab of the discharge is taken from the vaginal wall and a smear is prepared. The microscopic evaluation is done using a gram stained smear. In bacterial vaginosis, this would reveal a clean background with an abundance of gram variable coccobacilli adhering to the epithelial cells. These are called clue cells. A few inflammatory cells, other pathogenic organ­isms, and a reduced number of Lactobacilli would also be seen. 

Shown below is the Gram-stained smear of vaginal discharge of a patient diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis. It reveals vaginal epithelial cells that have a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria. These are called clue cells.

questions.text: The given image shows a forearm flap harvested for the reconstruction of the oral cavity of a 45-year-old patient with squamous cell carcinoma. Identify the type of flap.
questions.solution:
The picture shows a radial forearm free flap. Fasciocutaneous radial forearm free flap is the most common free flap used in head and neck reconstruction. 

A flap defines the tongue of tissue whereas a pedicle is used to describe the base or stem with the vascular supply.

In a free flap, the blood supply is isolated, disconnected, and then reconnected using microsurgery at the new site. Other Eg for free flaps: free fibular flap, DIEP flap (Deep inferior epigastric perforators)

Option A: Axial flaps are much longer and are based on known blood vessels. Eg: Latissmus Dorsi flap, TRAM (Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous) flap.

Option B: An islanded flap is that in which the axial blood supply is swung round on a stalk.

Option D: A random flap includes three sides of a rectangle, bearing no specific relationship to where the blood supply enters. Eg: V-Y plasty, Z plasty, Limberg, or rhomboid flap.

questions.text: The biopsy of a resected inguinal mass from a patient shows marked fibrotic changes with prominent Leydig cells and hypoplastic Sertoli cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological features are strongly suggestive of cryptorchidism.

Cryptorchidism is histopathologically characterized by the following: 

  1. Testicular atrophy: thickening of the basement membrane, arrested germ cell development, marked hyalinization
  2. Tubules showing Sertoli cells but no spermatogenesis
  3. Increase in the interstitial Leydig cells. 

Cryptorchidism is the failure of the descent of the intra-abdominal testes into the scrotal sac.  It is the most common congenital abnormality of the genitourinary tract. The testes can arrest anywhere during descent, and the most common site is the inguinal region.

Phases of testicular descent:

  • Transabdominal phase: Testes come to lie in the lower abdomen or pelvis. This phase of descent is regulated by Mullerian-inhibiting substances.
  • Inguinoscrotal phase: Testes descend along the inguinal canal and reach the scrotal sac. This phase of the descent is regulated by androgen-induced calcitonin gene-related peptide from the genitofemoral nerve.

The exact pathogenesis remains unknown, however, deficiency in gonadotropins and Mullerian-inhibiting substance (MIS) and increased expression of estradiol in the placenta are thought to play a role. It is associated with testicular atrophy and dysfunction, which result in sterility. Cryptorchid testes carry a 3–5-fold higher risk for testicular cancer (usually seminoma).

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about pemphigus vulgaris except ______

choices.text: Desmoglein 1 is the principal antigen implicated in the disease
The bullae are flaccid and are filled with clear fluid
Penicillamine is the most common drug inducing pemphigus vulgaris

questions.solution:
In Pemphigus Vulgaris, desmoglein 3 is the principal antigen against which autoantibodies are produced.

Pemphigus Vulgaris is an immunobullous disease or a chronic blistering disease which occurs due to an autoimmune process, by the production of antibodies (usually IgG) against desmosomes (adhesion proteins).

Oral erosions usually precede the skin manifestations. Other mucosal lesions involve conjunctiva, larynx, pharynx, esophagus, etc.

The skin manifestations include flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid and erythematous base which rupture to produce painful erosions. These are mostly present over the face, scalp, upper chest, back, and neck.

Drug-induced Pemphigus: Penicillamine (Thiol group) is the most common drug implicated in Drug-induced pemphigus.

It usually occurs after 1 year of taking the drug and is seen in patients who are suffering from other autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis.

Non-thiol drugs which are associated with Drug-induced pemphigus are ACE Inhibitors and glibenclamide.

Phenol group (Cephalosporins, Rifampicin, Phenobarbital, and Aspirin) may also cause Drug-Induced Pemphigus.

questions.text: Enucleation is indicated in the treatment of retinoblastoma when the tumour involves____________
questions.solution:

Indication of enucleation in retinoblastoma:

  • Tumor involves more than half of retina.
  • Optic nerve involved.
  • Glaucoma is present & anterior chamber is involved.

 

Note: Optic nerve involvement is treated by Enucleation + Post op Radiotherapy + Post op Chemotherapy.

questions.text: An HIV-positive woman was rushed to the ICU following an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. There was no history of fever, night sweats or weight loss. MRI scan is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cerebral toxoplasmosis. MRI scan shows multiple ring-enhancing lesions.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is one of the most common AIDS-defining opportunistic CNS infections and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/μL. It is usually a reactivation of latent tissue cysts. 

It usually has multiple lesions in multiple locations which are associated with inflammation and central necrosis, and hence show ring enhancement on contrast MRI. Sometimes an eccentric nodular area of enhancement is seen within the ring; this so-called eccentric target sign is typical of cerebral toxoplasmosis. Surrounding edema is also present.

Treatment includes sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks. 

Primary prophylaxis: It is given to patients with IgG antibody to toxoplasma and CD4+ T cell count <100/μL. A single double strength tablet of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is given.

Secondary prophyaxis/maintanace therapy: It is given when CD4+ T cell counts <200 cells/μL. Sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin is given. It is discontinued if the CD4+ T cell counts are maintained >200/μL for 6 months.

Option A: Cryptococcal meningitis presents with fever, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, headache, and meningeal signs. Seizures and focal neurologic deficits are rarely seen. MRI findings include dilated perivascular spaces and basal ganglia pseudocysts. 

Option B: Primary CNS lymphoma also presents with seizures and focal neurological deficit. Symptoms of fever, night sweats and weight loss are present in 80% of the patients. On imaging, it is identified as a CT hyperdense enhancing supratentorial mass, with MRI T1 hypointense, T2 iso- to hypointense, vivid homogeneous enhancement as well as restricted diffusion. 

Option C: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, caused by JC virus, is characterized by demyelination in subcortical white matter reflected on MRI as multiple, non-enhancing white matter lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately represents the action of glucocorticoids on the function of osteoblasts and osteoclasts?
questions.solution:
Glucocorticoids inhibit osteoblasts and stimulate osteoclasts resulting in the development of osteoporosis.

Other causes of osteoporosis by corticosteroids:

  • Inhibition of gonadal steroidal hormones
  • Reduced gastrointestinal absorption of calcium
  • The secondary effect of decreased calcium absorption: increased parathyroid hormone leading to further resorption

The ribs and the vertebrae are the most frequent sites of fracture

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about tramadol?

choices.text: Maximum recommended daily dose is 400 mg
Tramadol-induced respiratory depression is reversed by naloxone
For mild-to-moderate pain, morphine is more effective than tramadol
Peak action is seen within 2-3 hours and lasts for about 6 hours

questions.solution:
For the treatment of mild-to-moderate pain, tramadol is as effective as morphine or meperidine. However, for the treatment of severe or chronic pain, tramadol is less effective.

Tramadol is a synthetic codeine analog that acts as a mu-opioid receptor agonist. It also acts by inhibiting the uptake of norepinephrine and serotonin. The action peaks within 2–3 hours of oral dosing. The duration of analgesia is about 6 hours.

The maximum recommended daily dose is:

  • 400 mg for adults
  • 300 mg in patients >75 years old
  • 200 mg for patients with low creatinine clearance

Adverse effects include nausea, vomiting, dizziness, dry mouth, sedation, headache and respiratory depression. Tramadol-induced respiratory depression is reversed by naloxone. Tramadol can exacerbate seizures in patients with predisposing factors. Tramadol should be avoided in patients taking MAO inhibitors, SSRIs, or other drugs that lower the seizure threshold.

Clinical relevance: Precipitation of withdrawal necessitates that tramadol is tapered prior to discontinuation.

questions.text: A P3 woman bleeds profusely after delivery of the placenta. You initiate oxytocin infusion. The patient continues to bleed and the uterus fails to contract despite bimanual compression. She becomes tachycardic and hypotensive. What is the next best step in her management?
questions.solution:
Balloon tamponade is the next step in the management of atonic PPH unresponsive to medical management and bimanual uterine massage. 

Option A: Tight intrauterine packing has become unpopular due to the dangers of concealed bleeding and infections. It can be used in low-resource settings while shifting the patient to tertiary care centers.

Option C: Uterine artery ligation is done when tamponade fails (Bakri balloon and compression sutures).

Option D: Hysterectomy is the last option when all the other treatment modalities fail. Usually, the uterus contracts and bleeding stops with ligation or embolization. However, hysterectomy is done sooner rather than later in cases of placenta accreta and uterine rupture.

questions.text: In individuals with a history of substance abuse and addiction, the marked structure is believed to trigger cravings on exposure to environmental cues. Which of the following is not true about the structure?

choices.text: It forms the base of the sylvian cistern
It lies between the frontal and temporal lobe
It receives somatosensory inputs from the entire body

questions.solution:
The structure marked by the arrow is the insular lobe. The insular cortex is not entirely agranular. The posterior part of the insular cortex is granular and the anterior part is agranular.

The insula forms the base of the Sylvian cistern and lies between the frontal and temporal lobes. It receives somatosensory, viscerosensory, homeostatic, and nociceptive information from the entire body. It receives inputs from the thalamus.

questions.text: A 25 year old man involved in a fight, injured his finger and the deformity is shown in the following image. X-ray is normal. The most appropriate management at this stage is:

choices.text: Surgical repair of the flexor tendon

questions.solution:
Based on the mechanism of injury and the deformity characterized by flexion at the distal interphalangeal joint, along with a normal radiograph, the likely diagnosis is mallet finger, which is managed by splinting the finger in hyperextension.

Mallet finger, also known as baseball finger, occurs when there is a sudden passive flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint, causing avulsion of the extensor tendon from its insertion at the base of the distal phalanx.

The terminal joint is held in a flexed position, and the patient is unable to straighten it. However, passive movement of the finger remains normal.

As it occurs due to soft tissue injury, a radiograph will not show any bony abnormality, unless it is associated with an avulsion fracture.

Mallet finger without bone injury is treated with a plastic splint, keeping the DIP joint hyperextended for eight weeks, followed by four weeks of night splinting.

The following image shows splinting of the mallet finger:

Surgery is considered only if there is a large fragment (>50%) and subluxation of the DIP joint.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presents with abdominal distension and bilious vomiting. An erect X-ray of the abdomen is done and shown below. The neonate is taken up for surgery and an apple-peel bowel with loss of dorsal mesentery is seen. Which type of ileal atresia has this feature?
questions.solution:
The given image showing a triple bubble appearance and associated finding of apple-peel bowel with loss of dorsal mesentery is a feature of type 3 ileal atresia.

Small bowel atresias present with intestinal obstruction soon after birth. Bilious vomiting is the dominant feature in jejunal atresia whereas abdominal distension is more with ileal atresia. 

Plain abdominal radiographs show a variable number of dilated loops of bowel and fluid levels according to the level of obstruction.

  • Jejunal/ileal atresia - Triple bubble appearance
  • Duodenal atresia - Double bubble appearance

A contrast study is the next best investigation to exclude other bowel anomalies. 

In jejunal/ileal atresia, the distal end of the dilated proximal small bowel is resected and a primary end-to-end anastomosis is possible. If the proximal bowel is extremely dilated, it may need to be tapered to the distal bowel before anastomosis. 

Classification of Jejunoileal atresia:

Type

Feature

Type 1

Mucosal web or diaphragm

Type 2

With an atretic cord between two blind ends of bowel with intact mesentery

Type 3 a

Complete separation of the blind ends of the bowel by a V-shaped mesenteric gap

Type 3 b

An apple peel or Christmas tree deformity with a large mesenteric gap

Type 4

Multiple atresias, with a string of sausage appearance

 

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text:
Which of the following features in a patient would prompt you to anticipate a difficult intubation?
  1. Mallampati class 4 airway
  2. Thyromental distance of 7.8 cm with neck extension
  3. Neck circumference of 17.5 inches
  4. Ability to extend neck at the atlantooccipital joint
  5. A history of previous difficult intubation
questions.solution:
The following are indicators of difficult intubation:

  • Mallampati class 3 and 4 airways
  • Thyromental distance <6cm with neck extension
  • Neck circumference >17 inches in men and 16 inches in women
  • An inability to extend the neck at the atlantooccipital joint
  • A history of previous difficult intubation.

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man is receiving massive blood transfusion following a fall from height. 4 hours after transfusion, he becomes breathless and oxygen saturation decreases. questions.text: Identify the grip in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Leopold's third maneuver (also called the Pawlik’s grip) is performed by grasping with the thumb and fingers, the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis. If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass will be felt.

Abdominal palpation- Leopold maneuvers: 

In the abdominal examination, the mother is made to lie supine and comfortably positioned with her abdomen barred. Leopold maneuvers can be performed throughout the latter months of pregnancy and during and between the contractions of labor. 

Leopold's maneuvers may be difficult if not impossible to perform and interpret if the patient is obese, if the amnionic fluid volume is excessive, or if the placenta is anteriorly implanted. 

With experience, it is possible to estimate the size of the fetus.

  1. 1st Leopold (fundal grip): identifies which fetal pole (cephalic or podalic) occupies the uterine fundus. The fetal head is hard and round and is more mobile and ballotable whereas the breech is felt as a large, soft and irregular mass.
  2. 2nd Leopold (lateral/umbilical grip): palms are placed on either side of the abdomen and gentle, but deep pressure is exerted. The back is felt as a hard and resistant structure. The fetal limbs are felt as numerous, small, irregular parts. By noting whether the back is directed anteriorly, transversely or posteriorly, the fetal orientation can be determined. 
  3. 3rd Leopold (pawlik's grip): it aids in confirmation of fetal presentation. In transverse lie, pawlik's grip is empty.
  4. 4th Leopold (pelvic grip): it helps to determine the degree of descent.

questions.text: Which of the following does the Laqshya initiative launched recently by the Government of India refer to?

choices.text: Initiative for providing free sanitary pads
Initiative to provide vaccination to under-5 children
Initiative for labour room quality improvement
Initiative to provide affordable healthcare to all

questions.solution:
The Laqshya initiative launched recently by the Government of India refers to the initiative for labour room quality improvement.

There is enough evidence to support the fact that improving the quality of care in labour rooms, especially on the day of birth, is crucial to maternal and neonatal survival.

Laqshya is expected to improve the quality of care being provided to the pregnant mother in the labour room and maternity operation theatres, thereby preventing the undesirable adverse outcomes associated with childbirth. This initiative is implemented in government medical colleges besides district hospitals, and high delivery load sub-district hospitals, and community health centres.

It plans to conduct quality certification of labour rooms and also incentivize facilities achieving the targets outlined. The goal is to reduce preventable maternal and new-born mortality, morbidity, and stillbirths associated with the care around delivery in labour room and maternity OT, and ensure respectful maternity care.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with a history of having ingested one of the seeds shown in the image below. Which of the following is not true?

choices.text: It acts by blocking the action of GABA in the spinal cord
Ingestion of one crushed seed causes fatality
Death is associated with postmortem caloricity

questions.solution:
The image shows seeds of Strychnos-nux vomica which contains strychnine. It is a competitive antagonist of glycine at the postsynaptic receptors in the motor neurons of the anterior horn of the spinal cord. This leads to increased activity in the motor neurons. 

The fatal dose is 15-30 mg of strychnine or one crushed seed. If death is preceded by a severe convulsion, as in strychnine poisoning, it causes an increase in the body temperature called postmortem caloricity. 

The toxin strychnine does not affect any receptors in the brain and the person remains conscious till death. Strychnine poisoning is characterized by conscious seizures. 

Related Pearl: Signs and Symptoms of Strychnine Poisoning

The clinical features of strychnine poisoning are:

  • Convulsions - clonic-tonic type
  • Reflex increased
  • Awful taste
  • Mind is conscious
  • Pupils dilated
  • Opisthotonos: arching back
  • Emprosthotonos: arching forward
  • Pleurothotonus: bending sideward
  • Risus Sardonicus - fixed contraction of the facial muscles resulting in a peculiar distorted grin.

Strychnine poisoning case may resemble tetanus.

Although a poison, in relatively low doses it can be used as a medical stimulant for respiration.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not used to diagnose a patient with suspected allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis?

choices.text: Culture of Aspergillus fumigatus from sputum

questions.solution:
The culture of Aspergillus fumigatus from sputum is not a diagnostic criterion for allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA). The sensitivity of sputum culture in ABPA is low.

ABPA is diagnosed serologically, based on the presence of:

  • Serum IgE > 1000 IU/ml.
  • Positive skin prick test or IgE levels against A. fumigatus extract.
  • Detection of Aspergillus-specific antibodies.
  • Eosinophilia >500 cells/μL.

questions.text: A 4-month-old child was brought with repeated epileptic spasms. The child had reached his normal milestone at the age of 2 months. But the parents noticed that he lost the ability to hold his head steadily and he recently could not track light or sound. What is the finding in the given EEG of this child?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is of infantile spasms, developmental regression and the EEG showing hypsarrhythmia is suggestive of West syndrome. 

Hypsarrhythmia is an abnormal interictal pattern that consists of diffuse, high voltage, slow waves with a chaotic background of irregular, multifocal spikes and sharp waves. During the clinical spasm, there is a marked suppression of the EEG background (the electrodecremental response).

Hypsarrhythmias are usually seen in epileptic spasms. These are characterized by a briefly sustained flexion or extension of predominantly proximal muscles, including truncal muscles.

West syndrome is a rare type of epilepsy syndrome that begins in infancy. It is characterized by a triad of:

  • Infantile spasm (also called salaam spells) is a convulsive disease characterized by brief, symmetric axial muscle contraction (neck, trunk, and/or extremities).
  • Developmental regression
  • Hypsarrhythmia (Himalayan wave pattern) on EEG

Treatment of West syndrome includes:

  • ACTH
  • Vigabatrin, if associated with tuberous sclerosis
