questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the ED due to choking. Examination showed decreased breath sounds on the right side. An inhaled foreign body lodged in the right bronchus is suspected. Which of the following is not an explanation for this presentation?

choices.text: Right lung is shorter and wider than the left
Right principal bronchus is more vertical than the left bronchus
Tracheal bifurcation directs the foreign body to the right lung
Right inferior lobar bronchus is in continuation with the principal bronchus

questions.solution:
The right principal bronchus (not the right lung) is wider, shorter (2.5 cm), and more vertical than the left. The right inferior lobar bronchus is the continuation of the bronchus intermedius which is in the continuation of the right principal bronchus. These differences explain why inhaled foreign bodies enter the right principal bronchus more often than the left.

The left principal bronchus is narrower, longer (5 cm) and less vertical than the right principal bronchus.

questions.text: The component of CHOP in the R-CHOP regimen are:
questions.solution:
CHOP is the acronym for a chemotherapy regimen used in the treatment of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. CHOP consists of:

  • (C)yclophosphamide, an alkylating agent which damages DNA by binding to it and causing the formation of cross-links
  • (H)ydroxydaunorubicin (also called doxorubicin or adriamycin), an intercalating agent which damages DNA by inserting itself between DNA bases
  • (O)ncovin (vincristine), which prevents cells from duplicating by binding to the protein tubulin
  • (P)rednisone or (P)rednisolone, which are corticosteroids.

Sometimes the chimeric anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody, rituximab, is added to this treatment regimen if the lymphoma is of B cell origin to form the R-CHOP regimen.

questions.text: A public health worker was brought with multiple transdermal dog bites. He tells you that he had received pre-exposure prophylaxis 6 months ago. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Wound washing and ARV with half dose of RIG
Wound treatment and ARV; RIG is not required

questions.solution:
This given clinical scenario of a patient with multiple transdermal dog bites would be categorised under category III. As the patient received pre-exposure prophylaxis 6 months ago, his line of management includes the following:
  1. Wound treatment with soap and running water for 15 minutes and application of antiseptic
  2. Anti-rabies vaccine 2 doses on day 0 and day 3, with either intradermal vaccine(0.1ml, 1 site) or intramuscular vaccine(1 vial, 1site).
There is no requirement for Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG), if previous pre-exposure prophylaxis or post exposure prophylaxis documentation is available. If documentation of PEP or PrEP is unavailable, patient should be treated as fresh case and given full PEP.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty with signs of dehydration due to severe vomiting. The intern gave the patient a parenteral medication, following which the patient developed grimacing and abnormal posturing. What could have been the inciting drug for this reaction?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes the adverse effects characteristic of metoclopramide. The most common adverse effects of metoclopramide involve the central nervous system because it crosses the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and blocks the central D2 receptors.

The adverse effects include:

  • Restlessness
  • Drowsiness
  • Insomnia
  • Anxiety
  • Agitation 
  • Extrapyramidal effects - acute reaction with high doses and long-term therapy. (due to central dopamine receptor blockade)
    • Dystonias
    • Akathisia
    • Parkinsonian features
    • Tardive dyskinesia 

Adverse events are more common among the elderly. Long-term use should be avoided unless absolutely necessary.

questions.text: You notice the following response on stroking one side of the spine. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this?

choices.text: The reflex elicited is known as galant reflex

Persistence of the reflex interferes with walking movements

questions.solution:
The image shows Galant Reflex also known as Lateral Trunk incurvation reflex.

It is elicited by holding the newborn in ventral suspension (face down) and stroking along the one side of the spine. The normal reaction is for the newborn to laterally flex toward the stimulated side.

Succinctly, the trunk moves towards the side of stimulus.

It is a spinal reflex,and its persistence interferes with development of normal walking movements and postures

questions.text: The space of Disse consists of all of the following except ______
questions.solution:
The space of Disse consists of all of the following mentioned above except Kupffer cells. They are present in the lining of the walls of the sinusoids, not in the Space of Disse (perisinusoidal space). 

Kupffer cells are also known as stellate macrophages or Kupffer-Borowicz cells. They are specialized macrophages present in the liver and are part of the mononuclear phagocyte system.

Space of Disse or the perisinusoidal space is present in the liver between the hepatocyte and a sinusoid. This space contains the blood plasma. The microvilli of hepatocytes extend into this space. This allows absorption of proteins and other plasma components from the sinusoids by the hepatocytes. This space may also have some fat cells.

questions.text: A lady diagnosed with breast carcinoma underwent chemotherapy and reports hair loss after two weeks. What is this pattern of hair loss known as?
questions.solution:
Alopecia after chemotherapy is known as anagen effluvium. 

Hair loss following chemotherapy usually occurs within 1–3 weeks after initiation of the therapy. In this type of hair loss, the anagen phase is abruptly terminated. This leads to the loss of dystrophic or broken hairs and the condition is called anagen effluvium. The hair loss is acute and diffuse. However, there is full recovery within a few months of stopping the causative drug. 

The most important drugs implicated in the order of decreasing frequency of association causing anagen effluvium:

  1. Anti-microtubule agents (paclitaxel)
  2. Topo-isomerase inhibitors (doxorubicin)
  3. Alkylating agents (cyclophosphamide)
  4. Anti-metabolites (5-fluorouracil)

Other options:

Option A: Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory condition that causes non-scarring hair loss. It is caused by a T‐cell‐mediated autoimmune mechanism. The characteristic initial lesion is a smooth, circum­scribed patch of hair loss. Short, easily extractable broken hairs are seen at the margins of the patch, known as exclamation mark hairs.

Option B: Telogen effluvium refers to an increase in the shedding of telogen club hairs due to premature termination of the anagen phase. It is an acute‐onset hair loss. It usually occurs 2–3 months following a triggering event such as high fever, surgery, sudden starvation, or hemorrhage.

Option D: Telogen gravidarum refers to the telogen hair loss that occurs 2–3 months after childbirth.

Related Pearl: Hair Cycle

Hair follicles undergo a repetitive sequence of growth and the rest is known as the hair cycle. Hair Cycle is usually described under three phases: Anagen, Catagen, and Telogen.

1. Anagen

  • The period of active hair growth is known as anagen and the duration of this phase is responsible for determining the final length of the hair.
  • The entry of a resting hair follicle into anagen is heralded by the onset of mitotic activity in epithelial cells overlying the dermal papilla at the base of the follicle (the secondary epithelial germ).
  • Under normal circumstances, 80–90% of hair follicles on the human scalp are in anagen at any one time.
  • Anagen can continue for several years.

Fig 1. Scalp hair follicle in the anagen II stage of development

Fig 2.  Anagen hair bulb. Co, hair cortex; Cu, hair cuticle; DP, dermal papilla; DS, dermal sheath; He, Henle layer; HM, hair matrix; Hu, Huxley layer; IRSCu, inner root sheath cuticle; Me, melanocyte; ORS, outer root sheath

2. Catagen

  • At the end of anagen, epithelial cell division declines and ceases, and the follicle enters an involutionary phase known as catagen.
  • During catagen, the proximal end of the hair shaft keratinizes to form a club-shaped structure and the lower part of the follicle involutes by apoptosis.
  • The basement membrane surrounding the follicle becomes thickened and corrugated to form the ‘glassy membrane’.
  • It lasts for about 10 days.

Fig 3.  Human hair follicle in mid-catagen. There is a prominent glassy membrane surrounding the regressing epithelial column. The dermal papilla is rounded and condensed. 

3. Telogen

  • It is the time period between catagen and the next anagen.
  • It lasts for about 3 months.
  • Club hair is eventually shed through an active process called exogen.
  • In the human scalp, hair follicles may remain in a state of latency, also known as kenogen, for a pro­longed period after the club hair is shed.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about  the nature of the sensory receptor given below:
questions.solution:
The sensory receptor shown in the above image is Pacinian corpuscle. The Pacinian corpuscle is a rapidly adapting receptor and is an encapsulated receptor.

When a stimulus of the same strength is continuously given to a sensory receptor, the frequency of the action potentials generated by the receptor gradually decreases. This phenomenon is known as receptor adaptation. Depending on whether the receptor stops responding to a stimulus rapidly or slowly, they are classified as rapidly adapting (phasic) or slow adapting receptors (tonic).

They are expanded on free nerve endings. They are encapsulated nerve endings.
Responds to steady stimulus Respond to rate of change of stimulus
With steady stimulus, tonic receptors keep responding steadily. With steady stimulus, receptor responds initially but stops or adapts rapidly.

questions.text: Results of various studies carried out to study the role of smoking in breast cancer are plotted below. Identify the plot.
questions.solution:
The image shown is that of a forest plot used for plotting the results of a meta-analysis.

Related Pearl: Forest Plot

  • A forest plot is used to present the results of a meta-analysis.
  • It is also called blobbogram.

Interpretation of forest plots: 

  • The rectangles represent the single studies
  • The size of the rectangle is proportional to the sample size
  • The horizontal line on either side - confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results
  • The vertical solid line - the “line of no effect", which represents the odds ratio or relative risk. If it is the odds ratio, then the vertical line would be at 1. No difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1). 
  • The location of the result - whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not
  • A diamond shows the overall pooled result where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged
  • Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.
  • The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analysed measure of effect.

Let's understand with an example - 

  • For study A- it has a wide horizontal line that crosses the line of null effect with a black box that is to the right of the vertical line. This most likely demonstrates a small scale study with few participants where the point estimate result favours the control used in the study. But because the study contains the null value in its 95% confidence interval, it is likely to have a p-value >0.05 and not be statistically significant.
  • For study B- it has quite a narrow line that does not cross the line of null effect with a black box that is to the left of the vertical line and is bigger than study A. This most likely demonstrates a larger study with more participants compared to study A, where the result favours the intervention used. Because the 95% confidence interval does not contain the null value, this study is likely to have a p-value <0.05 and hence the differences observed in the study can be regarded as statistically significant.

questions.text: Which hormone is the first to fall in Sheehan syndrome?
questions.solution:
Growth hormone (GH) is the first to fall in Sheehan syndrome. The hormones are affected in the order of GH → Prolactin → LH and FSH → ACTH → TSH

Sheehan syndrome refers to postpartum pituitary necrosis following severe postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). During pregnancy, the pituitary gland undergoes hypertrophy with increased blood supply. This makes it susceptible to ischemia and infarction when there is severe hypovolemia.

The clinical presentation depends on the amount of damage to the pituitary.

  • Mild - can go unnoticed for many years
  • Moderate - develops over months
    • Lactation failure
    • Failure to resume menses
    • Mild fatigue and anorexia
  • Severe - endocrine emergency that develops within few days
    • Hypotension and shock
    • Severe hypoglycemia
    • Lactation failure

GH deficiency is very common in Sheehan’s syndrome because somatotrophs are located in the lower and lateral regions of the pituitary gland, and are most likely to be damaged by ischemic necrosis of the pituitary.

questions.text: Which among the following is the fastest acting antithyroid drug?
questions.solution:
Potassium iodide is the fastest acting antithyroid drug.

Iodides:

Iodides have several actions on the thyroid. They inhibit organification and hormone release and decrease the size and vascularity of the hyperplastic gland. In susceptible individuals, iodides can induce hyperthyroidism (Jod-Basedow phenomenon) or precipitate hypothyroidism.

Improvement in thyrotoxic symptoms occurs rapidly, within 2–7 days, hence used as iodide therapy in thyroid storm.

Note: Other agents take 5 days to several weeks to act.

questions.text: A patient with secondary amenorrhea and infertility is diagnosed to have Asherman syndrome. Hysteroscopic evaluation revealed 30% adhesions of the endometrial surfaces, but no agglutination of the uterine wall. How would you classify this patient?

choices.text: Cannot be classified with the given information

questions.solution:
This patient would be classified as a case of moderate Asherman syndrome as 30% adhesions of the endometrial surfaces are present.

Asherman syndrome (uterine synechiae) is classified as follows:

  • Minimal: <25% adhesion involves the uterine cavity, flimsy adhesions involving the fundus and tubal ostia.
  • Moderate: 25–70% adhesion of the endometrial surfaces, but no agglutination of the uterine wall.
  • Severe: 75% adhesions with agglutination and thick adhesions.

Asherman syndrome can present in the following ways:

  • Secondary amenorrhea
  • Oligomenorrhoea
  • Dysmenorrhoea
  • Habitual abortions
  • Infertility

The causes of Asherman syndrome are:

  • Dilatation and curettage (D&C)
  • Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), spontaneous abortions, recurrent abortions
  • Uterine packing in postpartum haemorrhage
  • Uterine infection
  • Tubercular endometritis

questions.text: Which of the following triplet codons encodes the amino acid selenocysteine?
questions.solution:
UGA encodes for selenocysteine and is also a stop codon.

Usually, the stop codons are involved in the termination of protein synthesis. However, the UGA anticodon may be utilized for encoding selenocysteine by a complex tRNA called tRNAsec. The protein synthetic apparatus can identify a selenocysteine-encoding UGA anticodon, by the presence of the selenocysteine insertion element (SECIS) in the untranslated region of mRNA.

Selenocysteine is incorporated into the growing polypeptide directly during the translation process (co-translational), unlike the other products which are usually formed by post-translational modifications.

Related Pearl: Start and stop codons

Start codon: AUG - Methionine

Stop codons:

  • UGA- Selenocysteine (21st Amino acid )
  • UAG- Pyrrolysine (22nd Amino acid)
  • UAA

questions.text: The patient presents with pigmentation of the face as shown in the image below and gradually increasing backache and stiffness. The X-ray image of the spine is shown. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical images show the accumulation of blackish discoloration on the face and the X-Ray shows calcification of the intervertebral discs. These findings are associated with alkaptonuria.

Alkaptonuria is a condition caused due to the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase. This results in the accumulation of homogentisic acid.

  • Homogentisic aciduria (patient’s urine contains elevated levels of homogentisic acid, which is oxidized to a dark pigment on standing)

questions.text: Which of the following methods is not useful for controlling epistaxis caused by over anticoagulation?
questions.solution:
Tranexamic acid, an antifibrinolytic agent, has not been shown to help in cases of over anticoagulated patients.   

Agents that work include Fresh frozen plasma, clotting factor extracts, and vitamin K. Vitamin K takes more than 6 hours to work, and it can delay anticoagulation for 7 days after warfarin is started.  

If the international normalized ratio is greater than 4, the warfarin should be stopped, and fresh frozen plasma should be given.  Clotting factor extracts should be given with extreme caution because of the risk of thromboembolic complications.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency department with confusion, drowsiness, and multiple episodes of vomiting. His family members say that he was diagnosed with bipolar disorder several years ago and has been on medication ever since. Further evaluation reveals a serum calcium level of 16 mg/dl. What should be the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a hypercalcemic crisis. The next best step in management is saline hydration. Typically 200-500 ml/hour fluids are given to correct dehydration and titrated to maintain a urine output of >100 ml/hour.

Hypercalcemic crisis is a medical emergency associated with serum calcium >14 mg/dl. It is often caused by conditions causing an acute rise in calcium levels such as malignancies or lithium overdose.

It presents with oliguria, severe dehydration, gastrointestinal symptoms, and altered consciousness. It can lead to cardiac arrest and coma.

Initial medical management of hypercalcemia involves the following:

  • Fluids are the mainstay treatment
  • Bisphosphonates
  • Cinacalcet
  • Denosumab
  • Calcitonin

questions.text: A victim of a house fire is brought to you for autopsy. On examination, you find an intracranial collection of blood. It is brown and friable and the adjacent brain tissue shows discoloration. The carboxyhemoglobin level in the extradural blood is found to be the same as in the peripheral blood. What is the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: A or C, depending on further pathological examination

questions.solution:
The diagnosis in the given scenario is that of a heat hematoma.

Heat hematoma is an artifact that mimics EDH (extradural hemorrhage). This occurs when the head has been exposed to severe external heat sufficient to burn the scalp and skull. The blood may be extruded from the diploë and venous sinuses into the extradural space to produce a heat hematoma. This false hematoma is brown and friable, and the adjacent brain tissue shows hardening and discoloration from the heat.

There is often a significant level of carboxyhemoglobin in the body if the death occurred when the fire was in progress. This should be of the same concentration in the heat hematoma as in the peripheral blood. If the victim suffered a head injury before the fire started (indicating an extradural hemorrhage), then there should be little or no carboxyhemoglobin in the hematoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the treatment of the condition depicted below?

choices.text: Physiotheraphy is successful when the restriction of motion is less than 30 degrees
The most common surgical method is subcutaneous tenotomy
Tenotomy is delayed until fibromatosis has evolved completely
Surgery  done after 5 years of age corrects the secondary deformities better

questions.solution:
The condition depicted above is congenital torticollis (wryneck) and the secondary deformities are less corrected if surgery is done after 5 years of age.

Congenital muscle torticolis (CMT) is a condition associated with fibromatosis in the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The mass is usually present by birth, attains its maxium size in one or two months and disappears by one year of age.

Exercise therapy:

Only conservative treatment is indicated in infacncy. The parents are instructed to rotate the child's chin towards the shoulder on the affected side and tilt the head to the opposite side.

Criteria for physiotheraphy:

  • Restriction of motion is to be less than 30 degrees
  • No facial asymmetry is to be present.

Surgical therapy:

If the mass does not resolve within one year, it may become permanently fibrotic and contracted leading to torticollis, and a surgical intervention may be required. Ideally the surgery is performed just before school age.

  • Subcutaneous tenotomy is the most commonly done surgery. It is done in younger children. The technique involves tenotomy of the distal part of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

 

  • Open tenotomy is asurgical method where additional incision of the deep cervical fascial layer is done.
Age at which open tenotomy is performed Probable effects
Before 1 year Tethering of scar to deeper tissues
1 - 4 years Less satisfactory correction of the tilt of head and facial asymmetry 
After 5 years Secondary deformites are less corrected

The open tenotomy is of two types: Unipolar release and Bipolar release, depending on whether the sternocleidomastoid is release from one or both of its attachments.

Unipolar release may lead to tethering of the scar to deeper tissues, usually in young children. Therefore it is done in children older than 4 years of age.

Frekel's modified bipolar release and Z-plasty of the muscle is done in children with severe deformity or after a failed operation.

questions.text: Dawn phenomenon is clinically suspected when a patient shows which of the following findings?

choices.text: Early morning hyperglycemia with hypoglycemia at 3 am
Early morning hypoglycemia with normal blood glucose levels at 3 am
Early morning hyperglycemia with normal blood glucose levels at 3 am
Early morning hypoglycemia with hyperglycemia at 3 am

questions.solution:
Dawn phenomenon refers to normal blood glucose levels at 3 am followed by early morning hyperglycemia.

This occurs due to an early morning surge in plasma growth hormone and cortisol levels, which have an insulin-antagonistic action. In normal individuals, this is countered by increased early morning insulin secretion. However, in diabetic patients, insulin secretion is disrupted which results in the unopposed action of growth hormone. Hence, there will be resulting hyperglycemia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the given virus?

choices.text: Incubation period is less than 24 hours
Patients are susceptible to reinfection even after complete cure
It is eliminated from semen within 2 weeks

questions.solution:
The above image is of the Ebola virus showing the bowl of spaghetti appearance. Patients with Ebola virus disease are susceptible to reinfection even after complete cure.

Ebola virus:

  • It is the cause of an emerging disease called Ebola virus disease and is widespread in Africa.
  • It belongs to the Filoviridae family.
  • Incubation period: 2 to 21 days.
  • Transmission is through contact with infectious bodily fluids or organs of animals like chimpanzees and monkeys.
  • Human to human transmission is through blood or body fluids of an infected symptomatic person.
  • It can remain in semen for up to 3 months, although sexual transmission has not been reported yet.
  • Symptoms include fever; intense weakness; vomiting; diarrhea; rashes; and, in extreme cases, internal and external bleeding.
  • Current treatment is mainly supportive.
  • Patients are susceptible to reinfection even after complete cure.

questions.text: What is the most common CNS manifestation associated with Whipple’s disease?
questions.solution:
The most common CNS manifestation associated with Whipple’s disease is progressive dementia.

Other important CNS manifestations in Whipple's disease are:

  • Personality and mood changes
  • Progressive supranuclear ophthalmoplegia
  • Focal neurologic presentations
  • Oculomasticatory myorrhythmia - an unusual combination of rhythmic eye and jaw movements which is pathognomonic of Whipple's disease.

Whipple's disease associated with CNS symptoms has a poor prognosis.

Note: Opsoclonus myoclonus syndrome is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with neuroblastoma.

questions.text: The maximum expiratory flow-volume (MEFV) curves shown in the figure below were obtained from a healthy man (purple curve) and a 57-year-old man with shortness of breath (green curve). What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The green curve in the above image and the case scenario denotes that the diagnosis is likely to be emphysema.

Maximum expiratory flow volume (MEFV): When a person expires with great force, the expiratory airflow reaches a maximum flow beyond which the flow cannot be increased anymore, even with greatly increased additional force.

In obstructive airway disease like Emphysema, it is usually much more difficult to expire than to inspire because the closing tendency of the airways is greatly increased by the extra positive pressure during expiration. Due to the obstruction of the airways and because they collapse more easily than normal airways, the maximum expiratory flow rate is greatly reduced (But, total lung capacity and residual volume is increased) which is shown in the green curve below. 

Other options given above will cause constricted lungs where the lungs cannot expand to a normal maximum volume. Hence, even with the greatest possible expiratory effort, the maximum expiratory flow rate will be reduced. (Note: here both the total lung capacity and the residual volume are reduced), which is shown as the blue curve in the graph below.

Following graph shows the MEFV of restrictive and obstructive lung diseases.

questions.text: In a Chi-square test for the following data, the degrees of freedom will be:
questions.solution:
In this scenario,contingency table has 3 rows and 4 columns. Hence, the degree of freedom, df = (3 – 1) (4 – 1) = 6.

In a Chi-square test for a contingency table, the degrees of freedom (df) = (r-1) (c-1), where r is the number of rows and c is the number of columns.

Related Pearl: Degrees of Freedom

  • In general, degrees of freedom (df) is equal to the number of values minus the numbers of parameters estimated on the way to the obtaining a particular estimate. For example, if we want to estimate the variance between the heights of two people A and B, we would use the values of 2 heights to estimate 1 parameter. Thus, the degrees of freedom in this case would be 2 – 1 = 1.
  • For a Chi-square contingency table, the df = (r-1) (c-1), where r is the number of rows and c is the number of columns.

questions.text: A patient is confused, opens his eyes on painful stimuli,  flexes one limb on painful stimuli, and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. His Glasgow Coma Score is ________
questions.solution:
The GCS in this patient is 11.

  • The score for verbal response: 4, because he is confused.
  • The score for eye-opening: 2, because his eyes are opening to only painful stimuli.
  • The score for best motor response: 5, because he can localize pain. 

Therefore, the GCS score is (4+2+5) = 11.

  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a case of pyramidal tract lesion?
questions.solution:
Hyperreflexia, muscle atrophy, and spasticity are all features of the upper motor neuron(UMN) disease. Rigidity is a feature of extrapyramidal tract lesion such as rubrospinal or vestibulospinal tracts lesion.

Rigidity should not be confused with spasticity seen in UMN lesion. In rigidity, resistance is same in all directions, whereas in spasticity resistance is more in one direction than other. Further, rigidity is not velocity dependent (does not vary with the speed of movement of the muscle groups), while spasticity is velocity-dependent (i.e. more noticeable with fast movements).

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for a patient with generalized epilepsy syndrome having mixed seizures?
questions.solution:
Valproate is the drug of choice in generalized epilepsy syndrome having mixed seizures. It is particularly effective in absence, myoclonic and atonic seizures. 

Valproate is usually first given alone (monotherapy) and if ineffective, another drug such as lamotrigine may be added.

In generalized epilepsy, drugs such as phenytoin, carbamazepine, and oxcarbazepine can increase the number of seizures. They can also provoke new seizure types - myoclonic or absence seizures. Hence, they are avoided.

Ethosuximide is the drug of choice in typical absence seizures and is not used for GTCS.

questions.text: All are true regarding mesothelioma except:
questions.solution:
Mesotheliomas are not bilaterally symmetrical.

Mesothelioma is a rare asbestos exposure-related tumor of mesothelial cells.

It usually arises in the visceral or parietal pleura.

It develops around 20 to 40 years after exposure which is around late middle age.

Mesotheliomas are preceded by pleural fibrosis and plaque formation.

Morphologic appearance of mesothelioma includes an epithelial pattern, a sarcomatous pattern and a biphasic pattern.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with muscle weakness, vomiting, and seizures accompanied by focal neurological deficits. Her developmental milestones were normal during the previous visits. Laboratory tests show lactic acidosis and microscopic findings of muscle biopsy are shown below.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with microscopy showing ragged red fibres is suggestive of MELAS (mitochondrial encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke).

It is a mitochondrial inherited condition due to complex I or complex IV deficiency. Patients have normal development previously and then present with symptoms of lactic acidosis and stroke (seizures with focal neurological deficits).

The microscopy of muscle biopsy with modified Gomori trichrome staining shows ragged red fibers (arrowhead) as shown below.

Other mitochondrial inherited diseases:

  • Leigh’s disease
  • Leber hereditary optic neuropathy
  • Kearns–Sayre syndrome
  • Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia
  • Pearson syndrome

questions.text: A 36-year-old pregnant lady was referred to the surgery OPD at 12 weeks of gestation with a lump in her right breast for the past 1 month. On examination, a lump of 2 x 1 cm size was palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. Which of the following investigations would you initially advise her for the assessment of the breast lump?
questions.solution:
Ultrasonography (USG) is the preferred initial investigation in pregnant women who present with a breast lump. It can differentiate between solid and cystic lesions of the breast and is able to detect abnormal axillary lymph nodes. USG is preferred in women with dense breast tissue such as:

  • Pregnant women
  • Lactating women
  • Young women (less than 40 years old) 

Conventional Mammography/ Tomosynthesis with 2D mammography is less useful in pregnant women due to the increased density of breast tissue.

MRI is not the initial investigation used for the assessment of breast lumps. It can be used in cases where metastasis or spread to other breasts is suspected.

questions.text: Which among the following is an early radiographic finding in spinal tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
The reduction of disc space between the vertebrae is an early radiographic finding in spinal tuberculosis. This indicates the destruction of the intervertebral disc due to spinal tuberculosis.

The infection first involves the vertebral bodies and the intervertebral disc. Hence, the early radiographic features include rarefaction/osteopenic appearance of the involved vertebrae and reduction of disc space between the vertebrae.

In later stages, the infection leads to para-vertebral abscess formation and vertebral destruction. These features can be seen on a radiograph as bird’s nest abscess and anterior wedging of vertebrae respectively.

When the disease is in the healing phase, the sclerotic appearance of vertebrae can be seen.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is not used for delivery of the aftercoming head in breech?
questions.solution:
Delivery of the aftercoming head in breech is not done with the help of Keilland's forceps. These forceps are used for the rotation of the fetal head. It is not used anymore.

The methods used for delivery of the aftercoming head include the following:

Burns-Marshall manoeuvre: When the occiput is seen under the pubic symphysis, steady traction is given on the feet. The baby is swung in an arc towards the mother's abdomen. Simultaneous suprapubic pressure is given and the head is born by flexion.

Malar flexion and shoulder traction (modified Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique):

The baby is placed on the supinated left forearm (preferred) with the limbs hanging on either side. The middle and the index fingers of the left hand are placed over the malar bones. The ring and little fingers of the pronated right hand are placed on the child’s right shoulder. The index finger is placed on the left shoulder and the middle finger is placed on the suboccipital region.

Traction is now given in a downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch. The assistant gives suprapubic pressure during the period to maintain flexion. The fetus is carried in an upward and forward direction toward the mother’s abdomen releasing the face and brow. Lastly, the trunk is depressed to release the occiput and vertex.

The image below shows Piper's forceps, identified by its distinct perineal curve.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has been experiencing worsening headaches and new-onset seizures. MRI with contrast was done and is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given MRI finding is suggestive of glioblastoma. Post-contrast MRI in the case of glioblastoma multiforme, demonstrates a large heterogeneous mass that crosses the corpus callosum into both frontal lobes. 

They have a preferential spreading along the condensed white matter tracts such as corticospinal tracts and corpus callosum and can give rise to the so-called butterfly glioma, to involve the contralateral hemisphere. The term butterfly refers to the symmetric wing-like extensions across the midline. 

There is also evidence of a previous left-sided craniotomy and biopsy tract down to the lesion.

Glioblastoma is the second most common adult primary intracranial neoplasm. It carries the worst prognosis (WHO grade IV).

questions.text: Normal renal threshold (g/L) and transport maxima (mg/min)  for glucose respectively are _______, _________
questions.solution:
The actual renal threshold is about 200 mg/dL (i.e., 2 g/L ) (1g/L=100mg/dl) and the transport maximum for glucose is 375 mg/min.

For substances that are actively reabsorbed or secreted, there is a limit to the rate at which the solute can be transported, which is referred to as the transport maximum. This limit is due to saturation of the specific transport systems involved. 

Normally, measurable glucose does not appear in the urine because essentially all the filtered glucose is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule.

The transport maximum for glucose is about 375 mg/min, whereas the filtered load of glucose is only about 125 mg/min. With large increases in GFR and/or plasma glucose concentration that increase the filtered load of glucose above 375 mg/min, the excess glucose filtered is not reabsorbed and passes into the urine.

When the plasma glucose concentration is 100 mg/100 ml and the filtered load is at its normal level (125 mg/min) there is no loss of glucose in the urine. However, when the plasma concentration of glucose rises above about 200 mg/100 ml, increasing the filtered load to about 250 mg/min, a small amount of glucose begins to appear in the urine. This point is termed as the threshold for glucose.

Splay is due to separation between filtered load and exceretion. It occurs due to different transport maximums of different nephrons.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about vaginal changes in a normal pregnancy?

choices.text: Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium

questions.solution:
There is an increase in the metabolism of glycogen in the vaginal epithelium during normal pregnancy.

The changes in the vagina during pregnancy include:

  • Increased vascularity and hyperemia resulting in a violet/purplish color characteristic of Chadwick's sign
  • Vaginal epithelium undergoes marked proliferation (option D) with the extension of the squamocolumnar junction downwards
  • Vaginal pH decreases and becomes more acidic (option C) and varies from 3.5-6.0.
  • Increase in the number of Lactobacillus acidophilus (option A). It metabolizes the glycogen stores and causes an increased production of lactic acid. Therefore, the pH becomes acidic.
  • Increased volume of cervical secretion during pregnancy results in the production of thick white vaginal discharge.

questions.text: The patient exhibited an unsteady "drunk like" gait and the physician noted that he swayed while entering the examination room. Which region of the cerebellum was most likely affected by the bleed?
questions.solution:
Flocculonodular Lobe is involved in the unsteady "drunk like" gait of the patient.

Cerebellum has three parts based on function.

  • Vestibulocerebellum (or flocculonodular lobe): The oldest part of the cerebellum which contains nodulus in the vermis and the flanking flocculus. It has vestibular connections and is concerned with equilibrium and gait.  Loss of it can cause disturbance of equilibrium and postural movements, especially during rapid movements.
  • Spinocerebellum: The region that receives proprioceptive input from the body as well as a copy of the “motor plan” from the motor cortex. By comparing the plan with performance, it smooths and coordinates movements that are ongoing. Superior vermis is a part of spinocerebellum. Loss of it can cause problems with coordination.
  • Cerebrocerebellum: They are the newest from a phylogenetic point of view, reaching their greatest development in humans. They interact with the motor cortex in planning and programming movements.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman has been scheduled for hip replacement surgery. She has a history of non-valvular atrial fibrillation resulting in a stroke 2 months back and is on warfarin since then. Which of the following is the correct advice regarding warfarin?

choices.text: Stop warfarin 4-5 days preoperatively and check INR
Stop warfarin 4-5 days preoperatively and continue LMWH till a day before surgery
Stop warfarin on the day of surgery

questions.solution:
Since the patient has increased thromboembolic risk (stroke), warfarin is stopped 4-5 days pre-operatively and LMWH (low molecular weight heparin) is used till the day before(24 hours) surgery. 

In patients at high risk for thrombosis (e.g., those with certain mechanical heart valve implants or with atrial fibrillation and a prior thromboembolic stroke), warfarin should be stopped and replaced by UFH or LMWH to minimize the risk. 

Patients at lower risk for thrombosis may have warfarin discontinued 4-5 days preoperatively and then reinitiated after successful surgery. 

Warfarin may be continued in patients posted for cataract surgery without a bulbar block.

questions.text: Individuals with fluoride intake above which of the following are at risk of developing crippling fluorosis?
questions.solution:
Individuals with fluoride intake > 10 mg/L are at risk of developing crippling fluorosis.

Complications of fluorosis seen with corresponding levels of fluoride intake are:

  • Dental fluorosis - 1.5 mg/L
  • Skeletal fluorosis - 3-6 mg/L
  • Crippling fluorosis - > 10 mg/L

Genu valgum may occur in people who consume jowar (sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

The Nalgonda technique is used for the defluoridation of water bodies. It involves the addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration.

questions.text: As per the Medicare Service Persons and Damage to Property in Medicare Service  Institutions Act, violence against a registered medical practitioner is considered as:
questions.solution:
As per the Medicare Service Persons and Damage to Property in Medicare Service Institutions (Prevention of Violence and Damage or Loss to Property) Act, violence against a registered medical practitioner is considered a cognizable and non-bailable offense.  

As per this law, enacted by many Indian states, violence against registered medical practitioners, registered nurses, medical and nursing students, and paramedical and other auxiliary workers carries a penalty of imprisonment and fine.  

Violence means activities of causing any harm, injury, or endangering the life or intimidation, obstruction, or hindrance to any medicare service person while discharging their duty in the medicare service institution or causing damage or loss to the property.

The period of imprisonment may extend from 3 to 10 years in certain states.

questions.text: You are conducting a cohort study in a group of headload workers to identify the risk factors for developing low back pain in future. This type of study falls under which of the following?
questions.solution:
Cohort studies fall under non-experimental (observational) analytical studies.

Classification of epidemiological studies:

  1. Observational studies: allow nature to take its own course, the investigator measures but does not intervene. It is further classified into:
    • Descriptive studies: limited to describing the occurrence of a disease in a population.
    • Analytical studies: go further by analyzing the relationship between health status and other variables. It includes:
      • Ecological studies
      • Cross-sectional studies
      • Case-control studies
      • Cohort studies
  2. Experimental studies or interventional studies: it involves an active attempt to change a disease determinant or the progress of a disease, and is similar in design to experiments in other sciences.
    • Randomized controlled trials
    • Field trials
    • Community trials

questions.text: Regarding the given box-whisker plot, the true statement is:
questions.solution:
The given box-whisker plot represents a positively (or right) skewed distribution.  In a positively skewed distribution, the mean > median > mode.

To further understand and correlate the fact, have a look at the following images:

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

Related Pearl: Box and Whisker Plot

  • A box and whisker plot is used to show variation in a set of data.
  • They can summarize data from various sources and display it in a single graph.
  • A box and whisker plot is usually based on median, quartiles and percentiles.
  • It is also called a box plot.
  • In the box plot as shown in the image, a simple box is divided into two by the median value. Above and below it are the whiskers. The top and bottom ends of the whiskers are the highest and lowest value of that group. 
  • A box plot can help in identifying outliers and the interquartile range (IQR), as shown in the image below.

questions.text: Which of the following bases can't be salvaged to the corresponding nucleotide?
questions.solution:
Uracil cannot be salvaged to its corresponding nucleotide.

Pyrimidine bases cannot be salvaged to their corresponding nucleotides. Purine bases that are salvaged are adenine, hypoxanthine, and guanine.

Salvage pathway - This pathway involves the conversion of purines to nucleosides and later to mononucleotides. It requires less energy than de novo synthesis. It usually occurs in places where de novo synthesis of purines is absent like brain, erythrocytes, etc. The enzymes that catalyze this reaction are : 

  • Adenine phosphoribosyltransferase (APRT)
  • Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT).

Related Pearl: Purine salvage deficiencies: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome and Adenosine deaminase deficiency(SCID)

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency(SCID):

Adenosine deaminase enzyme deficiency is one of the major cause of SCID. It is also called as Glanzmann–Riniker syndrome.

SCID patients are usually affected by severe bacterial, viral, or fungal infections early in life and often present with interstitial lung disease, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome:

It is due to deficiency of the enzyme Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase(HGPRT). It is an X-linked recessive disease.

Clinical features:

  • Intellectual disability
  • Self-mutilation
  • Aggression
  • Hyperuricemia 
  • Gout

Treatment:

  • Allopurinol
  • Febuxostat

questions.text: Which of the following type of schizophrenia has the best prognosis
questions.solution:
Catatonic type of schizophrenia has the best prognosis among all types of schizophrenia. Simple>disorganised schizophrenia has the worst prognosis.

Types of Schizophrenia:

  • Hebephrenic schizophrenia (disorganized) - has a poor prognosis, is the second most common type of schizophrenia. Early onset. It is characterised by disorganised behaviour and thoughts, emotional defect is seen. Somatic passivity is seen more commonly.
  • Paranoid schizophrenia - is the most common type of schizophrenia, it is characterised by delusions of persecution, grandeur, and control etc. can be associated with hallucination. Most common in 3rd decade. Amphetamine abuse can cause similar symptoms.
  • Catatonic schizophrenia - increased motor activity, posturing for a long duration of time in awkward postures. It has the best prognosis.
  • Simple schizophrenia - is characterised by only negative symptoms and there is no positive symptoms. Has poor prognosis (simple>hebephrenic).

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman had an autonomic neuropathy that disrupted the sympathetic nerve supply to the pupillary dilator muscle of her right eye. While having her eyes examined, the ophthalmologist placed a sympathomimetic drug in both her eyes. The right eye became much more dilated than the left  eye. This suggests that:

choices.text: The sympathetic nerve to the right eye had regenerated
The parasympathetic nerve supply to the right eye remained intact and compensated for the loss of the sympathetic nerve
The left eye also had nerve damage and so was not responding as expected

questions.solution:
Denervation supersensitivity develops in the muscle after the nerve supplying it is cut. Since the nerve to her right dilator pupillae is damaged, the right eye becomes excessively sensitive to the sympathomimetic drug. So, the right eye becomes much more dilated than the left.

Denervation Supersensitivity:

  • When the motor nerve to skeletal muscle is degenerated, the muscle gradually becomes extremely sensitive to acetylcholine. This is called denervation hypersensitivity or supersensitivity.
  • Normally nicotinic receptors are located only in the vicinity of the motor endplate where the axon of the motor nerve terminates. When the motor nerve is severed, there is a marked proliferation of nicotinic receptors over a wide region of the neuromuscular junction.
  • Denervation supersensitivity also occurs at autonomic junctions. Smooth muscle, unlike skeletal muscle, does not atrophy when denervated, but it becomes hyperresponsive to the chemical mediator that normally activates it.
  • This hyperresponsiveness can be demonstrated by using pharmacologic tools rather than actual nerve section. Prolonged use of a drug such as reserpine can be used to deplete transmitter stores and prevent the target organ from being exposed to norepinephrine for an extended period. Once the drug usage is stopped, smooth muscle and cardiac muscle will be supersensitive to subsequent release of the neurotransmitter.

Option a) If the symapthetic nerve would have regenerated, both right and left eye would have been equally sensitive to the drug and so, would have dilated equally.

Option b) Parasympathetic nerves supply the spinchter pupillae muscle. So, if stimulated they would constrict the eye not dilate it. Also, the drug added was a sympathomimetic agent. So, parasympathetic nerves are not stimulated in the first place

Option d) If the left eye was damaged, it would also have denervation supersensitivity. Again, both eyes would dilate equally, but more than that of normal.

  • Blue color indicates left ear.
  • ] indicates BC and threshold is <25dB. BC is normal which means the sensorineural pathway is normal.
  • × indicates AC and threshold is >15 dB and hence AC is abnormal.
  • So, it indicates conductive deafness.
  • The air-bone gap is a feature of conductive hearing loss.
  • Hence, the chart is suggestive of left-sided conductive deafness.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap

questions.text: The myogram below shows a slow onset and a longer after-discharge. Which type of reflex does it represent?
questions.solution:
The figure shows the typical myogram recorded from a muscle involved in a crossed extensor reflex. This myogram demonstrates the relatively long latency before the reflex begins and the long after-discharge at the end of the stimulus.

  • When a painful stimulus is applied to the body, the flexor withdrawal and the crossed extensor reflexes are stimulated.
  • About 0.2 to 0.5 seconds after the flexor reflex in one limb, the opposite limb begins to extend. This reflex is called the crossed extensor reflex.
  • After the painful stimulus is removed, the crossed extensor reflex has an even longer period of after-discharge than does the flexor reflex. This prolonged after-discharge results from reverberating circuits among the inter-neuronal cells.

Compare the myograms of a flexor reflex with a crossed extensor reflex.

In the flexor reflex, the contraction occurs immediately after applying the stimulus and the after-discharge is smaller.

questions.text:
Arrange the following events of pre-embryonic development in order, from the earlier stage to the later stage.
  1. Cavitation
  2. Compaction
  3. Implantation
  4. Cleavage
questions.solution:
The correct order of the listed events of the pre-embryonic period is cleavage - compaction - cavitation - implantation.

Events of the pre-embryonic phase of development:

  1. Fertilization
  2. Cleavage - Formation of blastomeres; the cells are loosely arranged until the 8-cell stage.
  3. Compaction - After 3 cleavages, the blastomeres are held together by tight junctions.
  4. Differentiation - The compacted 8-cell stage divides to form a 16-cell morula.
  5. Cavitation - Formation of the blastocyst with inner cell and outer cell mass.
  6. Hatching of the blastocyst - Release of the blastocyst from the zona pellucida.
  7. Implantation - Attachment of developing embryo to the uterine endometrium.
  8. Cell mass differentiation - Differentiation of the embryoblast (inner cell mass) into columnar epiblast cells and cuboidal hypoblast cells.
  9. Bilaminar disc formation - Formation of the bilaminar disc suspended by the connecting stalk. It has two layers (epiblast and hypoblast) and two cavities (amniotic and yolk sac).

questions.text: A woman has come to your clinic for a checkup following tubal ligation by Pomeroy technique. Which portion of the tube is ligated in this technique?
questions.solution:
Isthmus of the fallopian tube is ligated in Pomeroy technique. It is the most popular technique of tubal ligation.

Midline, paramedian or transverse abdominal incision is made 2 inches above the pubic symphysis (1 inch in puerperal sterilisation). The fallopian tube is identified, made into a loop and tied at the base. The loop is then excised.

The operation is simple and requires a short period of hospitalization. The failure rate is only 0.4% and it is mainly due to spontaneous canalization. It is surgically reversible.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child was brought with complaints of perianal itching which is worse in the night.  The scotch tape method demonstrates eggs as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of perianal itching and the scotch tape microscopy showing the eggs are suggestive of infestation with pinworm (Enterobius vermicularis).

The eggs of pinworm are plano-convex in shape, colorless, non-bile stained, and float in the saturated salt solution. The eggshell is double layered and relatively thick.

Enterobius vermicularis, or pinworm, is a nematode infesting the cecum, appendix and ascending colon in humans. Enterobiasis occurs commonly in children. They present with pruritus ani which is worse at night. Nocturnal enuresis may also be seen. Since pinworms are not released in feces, eggs are demonstrated through the NIH swab method and the scotch tape method.

The NIH swab (National Institutes of Health, USA) consists of a glass rod, at one end of which a piece of transparent cellophane is attached with a rubber band. The cellophane part is used for swabbing by rolling over the perianal area. It is returned to the test tube and sent to the laboratory. The cellophane piece is detached, spread over a glass side, and examined microscopically. The image given below shows the NIH swab.

 

In scotch tape method, the tape is firmly pressed against the anal margin, covering all sides. The tape is transferred to a glass slide with sticky side down. Then a drop of toluene is added for clearing and examined under the microscope.

 

The below image shows the life cycle of Enterobius vermicularis.

questions.text: A woman whose obstetric score is G2 P1 L1 had an LMP of Jan 9th 2017. Calculate the EDD according to Naegele’s rule.
questions.solution:
As per Naegele’s rule, the EDD (expected date of delivery) of this woman is October 16, 2017.

Naegele’s rule states that EDD is obtained by adding 7 days and subtracting 3 months from the LMP (the 1st day of the last menstrual period). Another method is adding 9 months and 7 days to LMP. Less than 5% of births follow Naegele's rule. 

It is based on a 28-day regular cycle. If the cycle is shorter/longer than 28 days, corrected EDD is calculated as follows:

  • For a 35-day cycle, add another 7 (35-28=7) days to the calculated EDD to get the corrected EDD.
  • For a 25-day cycle, subtract 3 (28-25=3) days from the calculated EDD to get the corrected EDD.

Naegele’s rule cannot be followed in IVF pregnancies. Considering the human embryo takes 266 days to develop, EDD is calculated in IVF pregnancies by the following method:

  • Same day as fertilization (day 0): EDD = date of transfer + 266 days 
  • 3 days after fertilization (day 3): EDD = date of transfer + 263 days
  • 5 days after fertilization (day 5): EDD = date of transfer + 261 days

questions.text: A middle-aged man from south India presented to the OPD with a swelling in his left foot that is unresponsive to antibiotics. On examination, multiple discharging sinuses were noted. The discharge contained brown granules that were soft in consistency. Which of the following is likely the causative agent?
questions.solution:
A swelling with multiple discharging sinuses with brown granules that is unresponsive to the antibiotics is suggestive of eumycetoma caused by Madurella mycetomatis.

Mycetoma is a chronic, granulomatous infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissues, fascia and bone, which most often affects the foot or the hand. It can be divided into three types- eumycetomas, actinomycetomas, and botryomycosis. Infection follows traumatic inoculation of the organism into the subcutaneous tissue from soil or vegetable sources. Within host tissues, the organisms develop to form compacted colonies (grains) 0.5–2 mm in diameter, the color of which depends on the organism responsible. It results in tumefactions, deformities, and draining sinuses discharging these grains or granules.

Laboratory Diagnosis:

  • A. Direct Examination: The presence of grains in pus collected from draining sinuses or in biopsy material is diagnostic.
  • B. Culture Samples should also be cultured, at both 25–30°C and 37°C, on brain-heart infusion agar or blood agar for actinomycetes and on Sabouraud agar (without cycloheximide) for fungi.

Treatment: The management of eumycetoma is difficult, involving surgical debridement or excision and chemotherapy. Actinomycetoma on the other hand, responds well to rifampicin in combination with sulfonamides or cotrimoxazole.

Other options:

Option A: Actinomadura madurae causes actinomycetoma which would respond to antibiotics.

Option B: Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis which is characterised by lesions along the route of lymphatics.

Option C: Fonsecaea pedrosoi causes chromoblastomycosis which would not have discharging sinuses.

questions.text: A child suffers severe injury because of road traffic accident. The lower limb could not be salvaged and the child is taken for amputation.  Which of the following is not true in this scenario:

choices.text: Transfemoral amputation is preferred in children instead of knee disarticulation
Children tolerate artificial limbs much better than adults
The child needs frequent changes in the size of artificial limb
The amputation in child needs frequent revisions

questions.solution:
Knee disarticulation is preferred in children than transfemoral amputation.

In children, the distal growth plate contributes to 75% of the growth of the femur. Transfemoral amputation in children may lead to the presence of a very short stump in adulthood. Hence a knee disarticulation or transtibial amputation is preferred in children. 

The advantages of knee disarticulation over transfemoral amputation are:

  • The growth plate is preserved.
  • The length of the stump is maintained.
  • The stump is sturdy and provides good end weight bearing.
  • There is no risk of terminal bone overgrowth.
  • The prosthetic suspension is improved secondary to metaphyseal flaring.

Children tolerate artificial limbs better and get used to wearing it more quickly.

As the child grows, there are frequent changes in the size of the artificial limb and also the overgrowth of bone occurs because of which it needs frequent revisions.

questions.text: False about Wilm's tumor is?

choices.text: WAGR & Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are associated with chromosome 11p defect
Most common finding is asymptomatic abdominal mass
Most common renal neoplasm of childhood

questions.solution:
90% of Wilms tumors are due to somatic mutations and are not inherited. The 10% that is inherited shows an autosomal dominant pattern. It is the most common renal neoplasm of childhood.

Clinical feature: Most common clinical finding is asymptomatic abdominal mass. Hematuria, hypertension, fever, weight loss, tumor rupture causing acute abdomen are other presentations of the disease. The most common site of metastasis of Wilm's tumor is lungs.

Microscopy: The classic triphasic combination of blastemal (small, round blue cells), stromal, and epithelial cell types is observed in most lesions, although the percentage of each component is variable.

Nephrogenic rests are precursor lesions of Wilms tumors.

  • Wilm's tumor is associated with WAGR syndrome - Wilms tumor, aniridia, genital anomalies, and mental retardation. Individuals with WAGR syndrome have constitutional (germline) deletions of 11p13.
  • Wilms tumor is associated with Beckwith- Wiedemann syndrome (BWS), characterized by neonatal hypoglycemia, macrosomia, macroglossia, hemihyperplasia, omphalocele, embryonal tumors such as Wilms tumor, visceromegaly, adrenocortical cytomegaly, renal abnormalities, and ear creases/pits. BWS is an example of a disorder of genomic imprinting. The genetic locus that is involved in these patients is in band p15.5 of chromosome 11 distal to the WT1 locus.
  • Denys-Drash syndrome (DDS), have an even higher risk (approximately 90%) of Wilms tumor.
  • WAGR syndrome and DDS are associated with WT1 inactivation, whereas Beckwith-Wiedemann arises through imprinting abnormalities at the WT2 locus.

questions.text: Which of the following works by disrupting the cell membrane?
questions.solution:
Lysol works by disrupting the cell membrane. 

Lysol is a phenol compound, which is obtained by distillation of coal tar. Phenols cause cell membrane damage and inactivate membrane-bound oxidases and dehydrogenases. This causes lysis and release of cell contents. Low concentrations of phenol can precipitate proteins. They are not inactivated by organic matter and are thus useful disinfectants. 

The mechnisms of action of other disinfecting agents are:

  1. DNA damage
    • Ionizing radiation
    • Ultraviolet light
    • Hydrogen peroxide
    • DNA reactive chemicals like acriflavin. 
  2. Protein modification
    • Alcohol
    • Chlorine
    • Iodine
    • Heavy metals (e.g. thiomersal)
    • Hydrogen peroxide
    • Formaldehyde
    • Glutaraldehyde
    • Ethylene oxide
    • Acids and alkalis

questions.text: Which of the following is the simplest measure of the burden of a disease in a community?
questions.solution:
The proportional mortality rate is the simplest measure to estimate the burden of a disease in a community.

It is commonly used for broad disease groups and when population data is not available.It is of limited value in making comparisons between populations and in identifying risk groups.

questions.text: Which of the following is false?

choices.text: Information in the Dorsal Column Pathway (DCP) deccusates in the internal arcuate fibres
Sensation from the genital region is projected to the medial surface of the post-central gyrus
The DCP is not somatotopically mapped at the level of the spinal cord
The Spinothalamic tract (STT)  is somatotopically represented at the level of the spinal cord

questions.solution:
Within the dorsal columns, fibers arising from different levels of the cord are somatotopically organized.

Specifically, fibers from the sacral cord are positioned most medially and those from the cervical cord are positioned most laterally.

This arrangement continues in the medulla with lower body (eg., foot) representation in the gracilus nucleus and upper body (eg, finger) representation in the cuneate nucleus.

The medial lemniscus is organized dorsal to ventral representing from neck to foot.

The Somatotopic organization continues through the thalamus and cortex.

Other options:

Option a: The fibers of the dorsal column pathway decussate in the lower medulla.

Option b: The sensation from the genital region is projected to the medial surface of the postcentral gyrus. The sensory homunculus shown in the image below represents various body parts and the corresponding site in postcentral gyrus which receives the sensory information.

Option d: The somatotopic representation means that the fibers carrying information to or from each part of the body are organized and specifically represented in a particular region of the spinal cord and/or brain throughout the entire pathway. The topographic organization is seen in information carried by the sensory system (dorsal column and ventrolateral STT, and sensory homunculus), motor system (motor homunculus, descending tracts), visual system (retinotopic) and auditory system (tonotopic).

questions.text: You are the intern on duty and you receive patients who have been in a road traffic accident. For which of the following patients will you urgently call the orthopaedic resident on call?

choices.text: Patient with a fractured arm with capillary refill time of less than 3 seconds in his fingers
Patient with a fractures arm with a 10 cm long incision over the arm
Patient with a fractured arm with capillary refill time of 5 seconds in his fingers

questions.solution:
Capillary refill time indicates limb perfusion and if it is more than 3 seconds, it indicates inadequate limb perfusion.

Delayed capillary refill time could be due to either vascualar injury by direct trauma or compartment syndrome.

Both of these conditions should be considered as surgical emergency and the blood flow should be restored at the earliest.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the contents of the broad ligament?

choices.text: Ovarian vessels in its infundibulopelvic part
Ureter is present the lower portion
Ovarian ligament in its anterior fold

questions.solution:
The ovarian ligaments are contained in the posterior fold of the broad ligament.

The broad ligament contains the following parts:

  • Mesosalpinx - it lies between the fallopian tube and ovarian ligament. It contains the pelvic vessels - anastomoses between uterine and ovarian arteries. The ovary is attached via ovarian ligament through the posterior folds to the mesovarium. 
  • Mesometrium - it contains the ovarian vessels within the infundibulopelvic ligament.

The ureter is present in the inferomedial part of the broad ligament. It is related to the uterine artery here and may be damaged during hysterectomy.

Note: Broad ligament is not a support of the uterus.

Related Pearl: Contents of the Broad ligament

  • One tube - Fallopian tube
  • Two ligaments:
    • Round ligament of uterus
    • Ovarian ligament
  • Two arteries:
    • Uterine artery
    • Ovarian artery
  • Two nerve plexus:
    • Uterovaginal plexus
    • Ovarian plexus
  • Three embryological remnants:
    • Epoophoron (Wolffian body)
    • Paroophoron (Wolffian body)
    • Gartner’s duct (Wolffian duct)
  • Other structures:
    • Lymph vessels and lymph nodes
    • Fibrous connective tissue

questions.text: The virus causing Apollo conjunctivitis is:
questions.solution:
Enterovirus 70 causes Apollo conjunctivitis.

Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis (a.k.a Apollo conjunctivitis):

  • It is due to picornaviruses, namely, coxsackie A24 and enterovirus 70.
  • It occurs in a pandemic form producing violent inflammatory conjunctivitis with lacrimation and photophobia. Subconjunctival haemorrhages and enlarged preauricular lymph nodes are common. Cornea is usually affected.

Other options:

  • Herpes simples virus causes herpetic conjunctivitis. Usually seen in children infected by contagion from carriers of the virus. Acyclovir 3% or vidarabine 3% eye ointment or trifluoro-thymidine 1% drops are often necessary.
  • Adenovirus serotypes 8 and 19 (also 3 and 7) cause epidemic keratoconjunctivitis. Adenovirus serotypes 3, 4 and 7 cause conjunctivitis associated with pharyngoconjunctival fever. Acyclovir is ineffective against adenovirus infection.
  • Newcastle virus causes Newcastle conjunctivitis. Clinically indistinguishable from conjunctivitis of pharyngoconjunctival fever. History of contact with diseased fowls is often present.

Note : Following the epidemic of this new hemorrhagic conjunctivitis in Ghana in 1969, it was nicknamed locally as "Apollo 11 disease" as it coincided with the time of Apollo 11 landing on the moon.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding secondary lactose intolerance?
questions.solution:
