questions.text: A young woman presented to your clinic with complaints of painful menstruation and postmenstrual spotting. On examination, you note tender nodules in the posterior fornix and a fixed retroverted uterus. Which of the following is the gold standard investigation to confirm the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of dysmenorrhea with tender nodules in the posterior fornix and a retroverted uterus is suggestive of endometriosis. The gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of this condition is a visual inspection by laparoscopy, preferably with histological confirmation. It is also the investigation of choice for the condition.

Role of laparoscopy in endometriosis:

  • Detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis
  • Locate the site of endometriosis and staging
  • To take biopsy
  • To surgically treat endometriosis by ablation

Other investigations for endometriosis include:

  • Estimation of CA-125 levels - raised in endometriosis.
  • Estimation of MCP-1 (Monocyte chemotactic protein) levels - raised in the peritoneal fluid of women with endometriosis.

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty with the following finding. A positive Nagler's reaction confirmed the presence of lecithinase-producing organisms. What is the principle behind this test?
questions.solution:
Nagler’s reaction is an example of a neutralization test. It is done for the detection of lecithinase toxin produced by C. perfringens.

The alpha-toxin of C. perfringens has phospholipase activity. When grown on a medium containing egg yolk phospholipid, an area of opacity around the bacterial colonies is seen (Nagler's positive). The presence of antitoxin can inhibit this.

Other examples of neutralization tests are:

  • Plaque inhibition test- neutralization of bacteriophages 
  • Schick test- neutralization of diphtheria toxin by antitoxin
  • Anti-streptolysin O test- for beta-hemolytic Streptococci.

questions.text: The method of choice for the diagnosis of Kala Azar is:
questions.solution:
The rapid dipstick test has become the mainstay in serological diagnosis of Kala Azar and is the method of choice for the diagnosis of the disease.

Laboratory diagnosis of Kala Azar:

  • Rapid diagnostic test: rK39 Rapid diagnostic test and Kala azar dipstick test strip.
  • Parasitological diagnosis: Demonstration of LD bodies- confirmatory.
  • Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance.
  • Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, Direct agglutination test, ELISA, Indirect Fluorescent Antibody Test
  • Leishmanin (Montenegro) test: Induration of 5mm or more is considered positive, usually positive 4-6 weeks after onset in cutaneous leishmaniasis, valuable for distinguishing immune from non immune subjects and endemicity.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented to the OPD with foul-smelling nasal discharge and obstruction. On examination, crusts are present bilaterally and on the removal of the crust, bleeding is present. Which of the following is least likely to cause this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bilateral atrophic rhinitis. Only deviated nasal septum causes unilateral atrophic rhinitis. The others cause bilateral atrophic rhinitis.

Etiology of atrophic rhinitis: 

Primary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Hereditary- Involves more than one member of a family
  • Endocrinal- More common in females, starts at puberty and regresses after menopause
  • Racial- More common in mongoloid and caucasian races
  • Nutritional deficiency- Vitamin A, D, iron deficiencies
  • Autoimmune- Antigens of the nasal mucosa
  • Organism- Klebsiella ozaenae.

Secondary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy and rhinoscleroma
  • Long-standing purulent sinusitis
  • Radiotherapy to nose
  • Excessive surgical removal of turbinates
  • Diphtheroids, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, staphylococci and streptococci.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

Atrophic rhinitis is more common in females and usually starts at puberty. It is a bilateral condition.

  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia).
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding antigenic drift?

choices.text: There is a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure
It accounts for major epidemics of influenza
The new antigens formed are totally unrelated to the previous antigens
Antibodies to the predecessor viruses do not neutralise the new variants

questions.solution:
Antigenic drift causes a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure.

Antigenic drift accounts for periodic epidemics, not major epidemics of influenza. This property forms the basis for the development of annual influenza vaccines. The new antigens formed are similar to the previous antigens and antibodies to the predecessor viruses can neutralise the new variants to some extent. 

Antigenic variation is a property of influenza viruses by which it alters the surface antigenic structure (hemagglutinin and neuraminidase) and thus avoids a host immune response. It is of two types - antigenic shift and antigenic drift.

  Antigenic shift Antigenic drift
Antigenic structure Abrupt, drastic change Gradual, sequential change 
Periodicity  10 - 20 years 2 - 3 years   
Epidemiological effect Pandemics and major epidemics  Periodic epidemics and sporadic cases
Genetic cause Large genetic re-assortment Accumulation of point mutations
Antibodies to predecessor strains Do not neutralize the new variant Neutralizes the new variant to varying degrees
Clinical relevance  Animal-origin viruses infecting humans e.g. Swine flu, COVID-19

Annual influenza vaccine development

Common cold - People can get flu more than once

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with chest pain on the left side radiating to the arm and jaw on the same side. Cardiac troponins are found to be raised. What is the diagnosis based on this ECG?
questions.solution:
The given ECG is of posterior wall MI.

The ECG findings in posterior wall MI include,

  • Reciprocal ST depressions in leads V1 to V3. Posterior wall ischemia is indirectly recognized in this way
  • Tall and broad R waves (>30ms) in V2 and V3
  • Dominant R waves (R/S ratio > 1) in V2
  • Upright terminal portions of the T waves in V2 and V3
     

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: A 14-year-old rape victim presents with 26 weeks of pregnancy. What should not be done?

choices.text: A female doctor should examine the patient
Vaginal swab examination is not necessary
No need to confirm pregnancy by UPT
Termination of pregnancy with her consent by a Gynaecologist

questions.solution:
According to the MTP Act 2021 amendments, pregnancy beyond 24 weeks of gestation cannot be terminated. Also, the guardian's written consent is required in the case of a minor girl.

  • Up to 20 weeks of pregnancy, any qualified practitioner can perform an abortion. However, he must have undergone compulsory training.
  • Between 20-24 weeks of pregnancy, the opinion of a second practitioner must be obtained to justify performing the abortion.
  • The woman to be wanting an abortion should be above 18 years of age to consent. If not, consent can be obtained from the parents or guardian when she is a minor or mentally unsound.

In the cases of sexual assault of a female child, a female doctor is appointed for the examination (Option A). In case, such a doctor is unavailable, then the head of the institution can nominate a woman for that purpose. These examinations are carried out in the presence of a parent or guardian.

Vaginal swab samples are typically collected within 96 hours (ideally up to 72 hours), as the chances of detecting evidence decrease significantly after this period. (Option B)

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: A G2P1 obese woman was diagnosed with arrest of descent during labour. Identify the following manoeuvre performed for this patient.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of shoulder dystocia and the manoeuvre shown above is the McRoberts manoeuvre. This is the most effective intervention and should be the first manoeuvre to be performed in shoulder dystocia. 

McRoberts manoeuvre:

  • Flexion and abduction of the maternal hips (positioning the maternal thighs on her abdomen).
  • The pelvic rotation which occurs due to the straightening of the sacrum tends to free the impacted anterior shoulder of the baby. 
  • Suprapubic pressure may be used simultaneously.
  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most common nerve to get injured during this manoeuvre.

If the first line of management fails, proceed with internal rotational manoeuvres such as Rubin's and Wood corkscrew in McRoberts position.

Rubin's manoeuvre:

  • Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves dislodging the easily accessible shoulder towards the anterior aspect of the chest from under the pubic symphysis by 30-45° while staying in the McRoberts' position. 
  • Pressure is applied on the scapular aspect (posteriorly) of the shoulder.

Wood corkscrew manoeuvre:

  • Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves dislodging the posterior shoulder by 180° in a corkscrew fashion to lie beneath the pubic symphysis while staying in McRobert's position.
  • Pressure is applied on the clavicular aspect (anteriorly) of the shoulder.

questions.text: A 33-year-old primigravida presented at term with non-engagement of the fetal head. She is suspected to have cephalopelvic disproportion at the level of inlet. Which of the following does not form the boundary of the involved structure?
questions.solution:
The structure involved in cephalopelvic disproportion at the level of inlet is the pelvic inlet. Ischial tuberosity does not form a boundary of the pelvic inlet.

Boundaries of the pelvic inlet:

  • Posterior - sacral promontory
  • Lateral - arcuate line on the inner surface of the ilium and the pectineal line on the superior ramus.
  • Anterior - pubic symphysis

 Boundaries of the pelvic outlet:

  • Posterior - tip of the coccyx
  • Lateral - ischial tuberosities and the inferior margin of the sacrotuberous ligament
  • Anterior - pubic arch

Clinical significance:

Cephalopelvic disproportion can occur when any of the inlet or outlet diameters are shortened by more than 0.5 cm, thus leading to the fetal head not getting engaged during labor. A primigravida presenting with a non-engaged head at term should raise suspicion of a contracted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion.

questions.text: False statement about Hirschsprung’s disease is______

choices.text: It involves both the myenteric plexus and Meissner’s plexus
It is seen in infants only.
It can also involve the small intestine.

questions.solution:
Hirschsprung’s disease can also occur in older children.

Hirschsprung’s disease:

  • Hirschsprung’s disease is a developmental disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus.
  • Incidence: 1 in 5000 live births.
  • Boys are four times more frequently affected than girls.
  • Sites affected: Rectosigmoid (80%) > Splenic or transverse colon (17%) > Entire colon with variable extension to small bowel (8%).
  • The abnormal/aganglionic bowel is the constricted distal segment, whereas the normal bowel is the proximal dilated portion.

questions.text: A primigravida who is 9 weeks pregnant, with low mood, loss of appetite, anhedonia, and insomnia for the past 2 weeks was referred to the psychiatry department.  Which of the following drugs would you prescribe her?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of depression. Desipramine is the safest to use amongst the given options, for depression during pregnancy. 

Antidepressants and pregnancy:

Tricyclic Antidepressants (TCA): 

  • Cross the placenta.
  • Imipramine - not safe, due to high anticholinergic and hypotensive properties
  • Desipramine, nortriptyline - recommended
  • Neonatal withdrawal effects are frequent and mild

Mono Amine Oxidase Inhibitors (MAO-I):

  • Should be avoided in pregnancy, as they increase the risk of hypertensive crisis
  • Associated with pulmonary hypertension in newborns

Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRI):

  • Associated with preterm delivery and spontaneous abortions
  • Paroxetine - shows cardiac abnormalities in newborns
  • Citalopram, Sertraline - safer drugs
  • Neonate shows serotonin toxicity and withdrawal symptoms

Note: Antipsychotic drugs like olanzapine, quetiapine, and risperidone are considered safe during pregnancy.

questions.text: A psychologist gives the following card to a patient and asks him to describe what he sees. Which of the following is being assessed here?
questions.solution:
The picture given is of Rorschach's inkblot test, which is a projective personality test that focuses on the unconscious aspects of personality.

Projective tests are based on the principle that when presented with an ambiguous stimulus, such as an inkblot or an image, the patient's responses will reflect fundamental aspects of his or her personality. The ambiguous stimulus is a screen on which the individual projects his or her own needs, thoughts, or conflicts.

Commonly used projective tests are:

  • Thematic apperception test
  • Rorschach's inkblot test
  • Sentence completion test
  • Draw a person test

In Rorschach's inkblot test, 10 bilaterally symmetrical inkblots are shown to the participants. The test is administered in two phases:

  • Free association phase- participant's response to the cards is recorded
  • Inquiry phase- participants explain why they formed the impression.

Related Pearl: Personality tests

Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI-2)

Uses Characteristics

The most commonly used objective personality test.

Useful for primary care physicians because no training is required for administration and scoring 

Evaluating the attitude of the patient toward taking the test

Objective test

Patients answer 567 true(T) or false(F) questions about themselves.

Clinical scales include depression, paranoia, schizophrenia, and hypochondriasis.

Validity scales identify trying to look ill (faking bad or malingering) or trying to look well (faking good) 

 

Rorschach Test

Uses Characteristics

The most commonly used projective personality test. 

Used to identify thought disorders and defense mechanisms

Projective test 

Patients are asked to interpret 10 bilaterally symmetrical inkblot designs (e.g., Describe what you see in this figure)

 

 

Thematic Apperception Test (TAT)

Uses Characteristics

Stories are used to evaluate unconscious emotions and conflicts

Projective test

Patients are asked to create a verbal scenario based on 20 drawings depicting ambiguous situations (e.g., Using the picture, make up a story that has a beginning, a middle, and an end)

questions.text: The center for vertical gaze is ________
questions.solution:
The Rostral Interstitial Nucleus of Cajal is the center for vertical gaze.

Vertical eye movement initiation in the frontal lobes is mediated by the impulses generated via the vertical gaze center called Rostral interstitial Nucleus of Cajal. This nucleus is a prominent group of cells present within the Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus (MLF) in the midbrain.

Pontine Paramedian Reticular Formation(Option A) is the center for horizontal gaze. Classically, initiation occurs in the premotor cortex frontal eye fields from where impulses for horizontal movement pass to the contralateral paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF).

Both horizontal and vertical gaze are saccadic types of conjugate eye movements. Conjugate eye movements, also known as versions, are binocular movements in which the eyes move synchronously in the same direction.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of short stature and absence of menses. On examination, breasts are Tanner's stage 1. What is the most common cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of delayed puberty. The most common cause of this condition is constitutional. 

Puberty is considered to be delayed if:

  • Breast development doesn't occur by 13 years in girls.
  • Testicular enlargement doesn't occur by 14 years in boys.

 Causes of delayed puberty:

  • Constitutional or physiological delay (most common)
  • Chronic anovulation - PCOS
  • Anatomical:

    • Gonadal agenesis
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome 
  • Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism - E.g., Premature ovarian failure
  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism - e.g., Kallman syndrome

Precocious puberty is considered if signs of puberty are seen in children less than 8 years of age. 

Causes of precocious puberty:

  • Idiopathic (most common)
  • Central
  • CNS tumors
  • Infections
  • Tumors producing
    • Estrogen
    • Testosterone
    • hCG
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient came to OPD with the complaints of glare during night drives. He had undergone cataract surgery 1 year back. The best-corrected visual acuity is RE = 6/12 and  LE = 6/9. No improvement with pinhole. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of a post cataract surgery patient coming with symptoms of glare and reduced visual acuity which doesn't improve on pinhole testing is suggestive of posterior capsular opacification (PCO).

Pinhole testing is done to differentiate between the various causes of reduced visual acuity.On pinhole testing if the visual acuity remains the same or worsens it is suggestive of either a macular disease or posterior capsular opacification.

Posterior capsular opacification also known as secondary cataract or After cataract is a late postoperative complication that follows extracapsular extraction of the lens.

Different types of after cataract include:

  • Elschnig’s pearls: where the subcapsular epithelial cells proliferate and develop into vacuolated soap bubble like clusters along the posterior capsule
  • Soemmering’s ring: A peripheral dense ring is formed behind the iris and is enclosed between layers of the capsule.
  • Dense membranous after cataract: formed in the pupillary area impairing the vision.
  • Thin membranous after cataract (thickened posterior capsule)

Treatment of after cataract is by:

  • Nd-YAG laser capsulotomy of the posterior capsule whose principle is photodisruption.
  • Surgical posterior capsulotomy.

The below given image is of Elschnig’s pearls type of after catarct.

 

Option A: Cystoid Macular edema (CME) is a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer of the retina following a break in the blood-retina barrier. In CME, on fundoscopy a honeycomb appearance and on fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA)  flower petal pattern can be seen.

The below given image shows the flower petal pattern on FFA as seen in CME

 

Option B: Pseudophakic bullous keratopathy is a postoperative complication of cataract surgery where the patient presents with corneal edema. This occurs due to a surgical or chemical insult to the corneal endothelium during the cataract surgery. It is treated by penetrating keratoplasty.

Option C: Age related Macular degeneration (ARMD) also known as senile macular degeneration is a chronic and progressive bilateral degenerative disorder of the macula that affects older individuals >50 yrs. ARMD is classified as dry and wet ARMD where the hallmarks are presence of drusen and choroidal neovascularization respectively. 

Drusen are extracellular eosinophilic deposits between RPE and Bruch’s membrane. Clinical features include loss of central vision, distorted vision (lines seen as wavy) and sudden painless loss of vision as seen in wet ARMD. questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be stopped abruptly without any withdrawal symptoms?
questions.solution:
Fluoxetine can be stopped abruptly without any withdrawal symptoms.

Fluoxetine is the longest-acting SSRI. Fluoxetine has plasma t1/2 of 48-72 hours. It is metabolized to an active product, norfluoxetine, which may have plasma concentrations greater than those of fluoxetine. The elimination half-life of norfluoxetine is about three times longer than fluoxetine (180 hours) and contributes to the longest half-life of all the SSRIs. Therefore, the level of the drug in the body falls slowly at a rate to which the brain can adapt when the dosage is reduced.

Paroxetine and sertraline are short-acting SSRIs and are associated with a discontinuation syndrome characterized by dizziness, and paresthesias beginning 1 or 2 days after stopping the drug and persisting for 1 week or longer.

Venlafaxine is a SNRI. All the SNRIs have been associated with a discontinuation syndrome.

questions.text: The exercise-induced hyperventilation during vigorous exercise is produced due to the receptors present in ______
questions.solution:
The exercise-induced hyperventilation during vigorous exercise is produced due to the receptors present in carotid bodies.

When exercise becomes more vigorous, buffering of the increased amounts of lactic acid that are produced liberates more CO2, and this further increases ventilation. The additional increase in ventilation produced by the acidosis depends on the carotid bodies and does not occur if they are removed. 

Note:  The abrupt increase at the start of exercise is presumably due to psychic stimuli and afferent impulses from proprioceptors in muscles, tendons, and joints.

questions.text: You are asked to remove a Foley’s catheter after a procedure but you are unable to deflate the balloon. The surgeon himself tries to remove it after cutting the sidearm but is unsuccessful as well. What should be the next step of management?

choices.text: CT-guided rupture of bulb of Foley's
Inject ether to dissolve the balloon and pull it out
Inject water to over distend the balloon until it bursts and remove the catheter
Inflate with 20ml of water and under USG guidance, locate and prick the balloon

questions.solution:
USG-guided rupture of the balloon percutaneously after inflating it with 20ml water should be the next step of management.

The failure of the balloon to deflate may be caused by:

  • Faulty valve mechanism 
  • Blockage of the inflation channel by debris
  • Crystallization of the fluid within the balloon (when saline is used)

The next best step in the management of a retained Foley's catheter is to further inflate the balloon with 20mL of water, following which the inflated balloon is ruptured percutaneously with a needle under USG guidance. 

A suprapubic approach is used in males, while in females, either a transurethral or transvaginal route can be used. A cystoscopy should be done to ensure that all fragments are removed.

Other methods of approach include cutting the sidearm of the catheter, thereby disabling the valve mechanism, or advancing a ureteric stylet or fine-gauge wire through the inflation port to dislodge debris or puncture the balloon. But these are often unsuccessful.

Option A: CT is not routinely used in most settings with retained Foley's.

Option B: Injection of ether through the balloon port causes the rupture of the balloon within seconds. But this technique causes significant bladder irritation.

Option C: Balloons should not be overinflated until they rupture. This may cause severe pain and could cause bladder rupture.

Related Pearl: Foley's Catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the outer diameter in millimetres, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm.

questions.text: While performing the following pediatric emergency procedure being performed on the model of an infant, which of the following indicates a wrong technique?

choices.text: Compression : Breath ratio should ideally be 30:2
Fingers should be lifted off the chest to allow effective recoil between compressions
Efficiency of chest compression should be assessed with brachial pulse periodically
Alternatively, the two thumb technique is equally effective

questions.solution:
The image shows infant CPR. Fingers should not be lifted off the chest between compressions.

The thumbs or the tips of fingers should remain in contact with the chest during compression and release.

Ideally, there should be 30 chest compressions and 2 breaths in a minute.i.e 100-120 compressions per minute (use 15:2 ratio if second rescuer arrives)

In infants, the brachial pulse should be assessed. (For children aged one to adolescence, the pulse should be checked at the carotid artery)

The two-finger technique and two thumb technique are considered to be equally effective.

questions.text: A patient presented with intermenstrual bleeding for the past 6 months. Which of the following types of fibroid is usually associated with this symptom?
questions.solution:
Intermenstrual bleeding is common with submucous fibroids. Metrorrhagia or intermenstrual bleeding refers to bleeding that occurs during the middle of the menstrual cycle.

Metrorrhagia in a woman over 40 years warrants a dilatation and curettage procedure to rule out endometrial cancer. This is associated with fibroids in 3% of cases.

Polymenorrhoea in a patient with fibroids occurs when she has polycystic ovaries or pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

Progressive menorrhagia is seen in intramural and submucous myoma due to increased vascularity, endometrial hyperplasia, and an enlarged uterine cavity.

Note: Further the distance of the fibroid from the cavity, lesser is the possibility of menorrhagia. For this reason, subserous and pedunculated fibroids do not cause menorrhagia.

questions.text: TRUE statement concerning etomidate is

choices.text: Has been used to treat hypercortisolemia
To be avoided in neurosurgical procedures due to risk of raised intracranial pressure

questions.solution:
• Etomidate can be used in the treatment of endogenous hypercortisolemia. This is due to its ability to inhibit the enzyme 11β-hydroxylase, which results in decreased biosynthesis of cortisol.
  • Etomidate has the highest incidence of Postoperative nausea and vomiting.
  • Etomidate can be safely used in neurosurgical procedures such as giant aneurysm clipping. It is also the anesthetic induction agent of choice to reduce increased ICP when maintenance of cerebral or coronary perfusion pressure is important.
  • Of all induction agents, etomidate is the most cardiac stable induction agent and is the agent of choice in CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE, cardiomyopathy, cerebral vascular disease or hypovolemia.

questions.text: Capsule of hip joint is separated from sciatic nerve by?
questions.solution:
The capsule of the hip joint is separated from the Sciatic nerve by tendons of obturator internus and Gemelli.

The capsule is separated from a branch of medial circumflex femoral artery and quadratus femoris by tendon of obturator externus.

Clinical consideration: 

During hip joint surgery, deep dissection needs detachment of obturator externus tendon to access the articulating head of the femur.After detaching, obturator tendon can be used as a flap to cover sciatic nerve posterior to it, this reduces the chance of sciatic nerve injury.

questions.text: Which of the following types of morbidly adherent placenta is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows placenta increta. 

Morbidly adherent placenta occurs due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer. It is of three types:

  • Placenta accreta - villi are attached to the myometrium.
  • Placenta increta - villi invade deep into the myometrium.
  • Placenta percreta - villi penetrate through the entire myometrium and to or through the serosa. 

Based on the adherence of placental lobules, all three types of morbidly adherent placenta can be:

  • Total - involving all lobules of the placenta 
  • Focal - involving a single lobule or part of a lobule of the placenta

Morbidly adherent placenta can lead to torrential post-partum hemorrhage. It is managed via C-section and peripartum hysterectomy.

questions.text: How would you classify the following injury?
questions.solution:
The physeal injury depicted in the given diagram is classified as Salter-Harris type II.

In a type II fracture, the fracture line passes through the metaphysis into the epiphyseal plate. This results in a metaphyseal fragment called the Thurston-Holland fragment. The epiphysis is spared.

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with sudden onset of a headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating. He had several such episodes in the past. During these episodes, his BP is found to be high. A 24-hour urinary metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
The most likely etiology is pheochromocytoma. Patients commonly present with a classical triad of palpitation, headache and profuse sweating. The presence of this triad in association with hypertension and elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine makes pheochromocytoma a likely diagnosis.

questions.solution:
The image shows minimal change disease in which effacement of foot process can be seen. Hepatitis B is not seen in association with minimal change disease.

Secondary causes of minimal change disease:

questions.text: The following graph displays which physiological law of the heart?
questions.solution:
The diagram displays the Length-Tension relationship for a cardiac muscle explaining the Starling law of the heart.

In the body, the initial length of the fibers is determined by the degree of diastolic filling of the heart, and the pressure developed in the ventricle is proportional to the volume of the ventricle at the end of the filling phase (Starling law of the heart).

  • The developed tension increases as the diastolic volume increases until it reaches a maximum, then tends to decrease.
  • The decrease is due to beginning disruption of the myocardial fibers and not due to a decrease in the number of cross-bridges between actin and myosin as seen in skeletal muscle.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male was transferred to the emergency room after a car accident. Twenty-four hours after admission, the patient manifested tachycardia, dyspnea, and hypoxemia. After the autopsy, the diagnosis of fat embolism was made. Which of the following special stains on autopsy was used for the microscopy of a cryostat section from the lung?
questions.solution:
The oil red O (ORO) stain can identify neutral lipids and fatty acids in smears and tissues. A frozen section must be done so that the tissue need not go through routine processing. Oil red O stains the lipid in the vacuoles in the pulmonary vasculature.

  • Fixatives containing alcohols, or routine tissue processing with clearing, will remove lipids.
  • ORO is a rapid and simple stain.
  • It can be useful in identifying fat emboli in lung tissue or clot sections of peripheral blood.

Uses:

  • Diagnose renal cell carcinoma, sebaceous gland tumors of the skin, lipid-rich carcinomas.
  • Identify fat emboli in lung tissue or clot sections of peripheral blood.

questions.text: Which enzyme gives signals for termination of RNA transcription?
questions.solution:
RNA polymerase II gives signals for the termination of RNA transcription. Proteins catalyzing RNA processing, termination, and polyadenylation appear to load onto RNA polymerase II soon after initiation.

Termination of transcription can be:

  • ρ dependent: When the termination signals are met, ρ factor binds to RNA. ρ factor has ATP dependent helicase activity. It detaches the RNA from the DNA.
  • ρ independent: In the 3' end of RNA, there is a series of U. RNA detaches from DNA due to weaker A=U at the end.

questions.text: According to JNC, which of the following should not be given in hypertensive non-black population with diabetes?
questions.solution:
According to JNC, beta-blockers are not given in hypertensive non-black population with diabetes.

Eighth Joint National Committee (JNC-8) guideline on managing hypertension in adults.

  • The JNC-8 calls for treatment to lower blood pressure (BP) to 150/90 mm Hg in those age 60 and older, and to 140/90 for adults less than 60.
  • In the population age 18 and older with diabetes, the guidelines recommends initiating drug treatment to a goal of systolic BP<140 mmHg, and a diastolic goals of <90 mmHg. The same applies to patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
  • In the general nonblack population, including those with diabetes, the initial antihypertensive treatment should include either a thiazide, calcium channel blocker (CCB), angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEI), or angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB).
  • In the general black population, including those with diabetes, initial antihypertensive treatment should include a thiazide-type diuretic or CCB.
  • In adults with CKD, initial (or add-on) antihypertensive treatment should include an ACEI or ARB to improve kidney outcomes. This applies to all CKD patients with hypertension regardless of race or diabetes status.

Note : African Americans have exceptionally high rates of hypertension and hypertension related complications. It is commonly reported that the blood pressure lowering efficacy of renin angiotensin system (RAS) inhibitors like ACEIs and ARBs is attenuated in African Americans due to a greater likelihood of having a low renin profile. Therefore these agents are often not recommended as initial therapy in African Americans with hypertension. However, the high prevalence of comorbid conditions, such as diabetes, cardiovascular and chronic kidney disease makes treatment with RAS inhibitors more compelling.

questions.text: A man brings his wife to the psychiatric OPD, reporting concerns about her recent behaviour. She complains of irritability, distractibility, and reduced need for sleep. Her husband observes that she has an elated mood, talks excessively, and struggles to manage her daily activities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of decreased sleep, elation, talkativeness, irritability, and distractibility present for at least 1 week is characteristic of mania.

Diagnostic criteria for mania:

A. Distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated/irritable mood, abnormally and persistently increased activity/energy, lasting at least 1 week or any duration if hospital­ization is necessary.

B. During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy/activity, three (or more) of the following symptoms and four (or more) if irritable have been present to a significant degree:

  1. Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity
  2. Decreased need for sleep
  3. More talkative than usual
  4. Flight of ideas
  5. Distractibility
  6. Increase in goal-oriented activity or psychomotor agitation
  7. Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences

C. The episode is severe enough to cause marked social or occupational impairment or to necessitate hospitalization.

D. The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication, other treatment) or to another medical condition.

Related Pearl: Mania Vs Hypomania

Mania Hypomania
Symptoms for at least 1 week Symptoms for at least 4 days
Marked impairment in social or occupational functioning No impairment in social or occupational functioning
May need hospitalization Doesn't need hospitalization

questions.text: Treatment for most of the patients of thoracic outlet syndrome is _______.
questions.solution:
Most of the patients are managed conservatively: exercise to strengthen the shoulder girdle muscles, for postural training, and for instruction in work practice and ways of preventing shoulder droop and muscle fatigue. Analgesics for pain.

Operative treatment is indicated in case of severe pain, if muscle wasting is obvious and vascular complications present. It includes removal of the first thoracic rib as the most effective treatment in this syndrome as it deals with both supraclavicular and infraclavicular etiological factors.

Scalenotomy is indicated only in cases of scalenus anticus syndrome.

questions.text: A psychiatry resident is evaluating a chronic alcoholic patient admitted to the ward. When asked about his day, he correctly remembered that he was wheeled out of the ward, but then went on to tell a story of a trip he made to the nearby park, which did not occur. He also made up random names as he went on talking about his children. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of confabulation. It is one of the features of Korsafkoff’s psychosis. Confabulation is filling up gaps in memory with false stories.

Korsakoff’s psychosis is a chronic amnestic syndrome that can follow Wernicke's encephalopathy due to thiamine deficiency (secondary to alcoholism). The cardinal features are impaired mental syndrome and anterograde amnesia. Only 20% of patients recover with treatment (whereas in Wernicke's encephalopathy there is complete reversal with treatment).

Clinical features:

  • Impaired mental syndrome - especially recent memory
  • Striking inability to form new memories - severe anterograde amnesia
  • Retrograde amnesia is less severe.
  • Present with confabulation as an attempt to cover the memory deficit
  • There is a lack of insight and no intellectual functional loss.
  • Overall intact intelligence
  • Implicit learning (e.g., learning procedures) is preserved.
  • Long-term and immediate memory is normal.

Treatment: Thiamine is given 100mg orally two to three times daily for 3 to 12 months.

questions.text: Blunting of calyceal fornices on voiding cystourethrogram is first seen in
questions.solution:
Blunting of calyceal fornices on voiding cystourethrogram is seen in  Grade III vesicoureteral reflux.

VUR severity is graded based on the appearance of the urinary tract on a contrast voiding cystourethrogram.

It is classified into 5 grades (Grade I to V):

Grading of vesicoureteral reﬂux:

  • Grade I: VUR into a non-dilated ureter
  • Grade II: VUR into the upper collecting system without dilation
  • Grade III: VUR into the dilated ureter and/or minimal blunting of calyceal fornices
  • Grade IV: VUR into a grossly dilated ureter and blunting of calyceal fornices
  • Grade V: Massive VUR, with significant ureteral dilation and tortuosity and loss of the papillary impression

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child presents with fever and fatigue of 2 months duration. On examination, he has generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement. Lab investigations show LDH- 644mg/dl, TLC - 41900/mm3, Hb -9.7g/dl and Plt- 104000/uL. Marrow is hypercellular and aspirate is as shown below. The cells are myeloperoxidase negative and often contain periodic acid-Schiff–positive cytoplasmic material. All the following are favourable prognostic markers for the condition except:
questions.solution:
Age younger than 2 years in ALL is associated with worse prognosis largely because of the strong association of infantile ALL with translocations involving the MLL gene.

Factors associated with a worse prognosis:

  1. Age younger than 2 years
  2. Presentation in adolescence or adulthood
  3. Peripheral blood blast counts greater than 100,000, which probably reflects a high tumor burden

Favorable prognostic markers include

  1. Age between 2 and 10 years
  2. A low white cell count
  3. Hyperdiploidy
  4. Trisomy of chromosomes 4, 7, and 10
  5. The presence of a t(12;21)

questions.text: The following image shows the resulting wound cavity from a  bullet.  Which of the following explains the shape of the wound cavity?
questions.solution:
The shape of the wound cavity can be explained by yawing of the bullet. 

Yawing is a common phenomenon seen with bullets (not with spheres).  It is used to describe a bullet traveling in an irregular fashion .

The angle between the trajectory and the long axis of the bullet increases due to destabilising forces until it reaches 90 degrees , i.e., the bullet’s long axis is perpendicular to the trajectory. The yawing motion then continues until 180 degrees and the bullet will remain in this stable position where the base is the leading part.

The path of a projectile in a dense medium therefore shows three distinct sections, depending on the respective cross-sectional area:

  • Narrow channel
  • Increased cavities
  • Tail end

Related Pearl: Types of bullets:

1. Ricochet bullet: Bullet first strikes an intermediate object and then after being reflected strikes the target. It produces a key hole entry wound .

2. Yawning bullet: Travels in an irregular fashion.

3. Tandem (Piggy Back) Bullet Effect: Two bullets are ejected one after the other; first bullet failed to leave the barrel and is ejected by subsequently fired bullet. This occurs due to defect in the weapon or due to faulty ammunition or with loaded firearms unused for several years. Tandem cartridge (also called duplex cartridge) is a single cartridge containing two bullets. 

 

4. Frangible bullet: Fragments on hitting the target.

5. Dum Dum bullet: Tip is chiseled out, fragments extensively on impact.

6. Tumbling bullet:  Rotates end on end during its motion. This produces an atypical entry wound .  

7. Souvenir bullet:  Bullet left in the body for a long time and covered with dense fibrous connective tissue.

8. Tracer bullet: This type of bullet leaves a visible mark or trace while in flight so that the gunner can observe the strike of shot. Rear portion of bullet is filled with mixture of barium nitrate, strontium nitrate and powdered magnesium which is ignited by the burning powder. Mixture burns and sheds red sparks which makes the projectile visible to naked eye which enables shooter to make aiming corrections.

9. Incendiary bullet: It is filled with white phosphorous and ignites the target.

From left to right : Blank with frangible wooden bullet, ball, tracer and incendiary bullets

questions.text: To assess the vitamin B1 nutritional status in a patient, measurement of which of the following can be used?
questions.solution:
Measurement of erythrocyte transketolase provides an index of vitamin B1 nutritional status.

Transketolase is an enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway and requires Mg2+ and thiamine diphosphate (vitamin B1) as cofactors. In thiamine deficiency, the RBC transketolase activity is reduced. When thiamine diphosphate is added in-vitro to erythrocyte lysate, activation of apo-transketolase is suggestive of B1 deficiency.

Other enzymes requiring thiamine as a cofactor are:
  • Branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase
  • Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Transketolase
Options A and B: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase and 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase are involved in the oxidative phase of the hexose monophosphate (HMP) pathway. Both enzymes require NADP+ and contribute to the formation of NADPH and ribose.
 
Option D: The vitamin B6 nutritional status is by measuring the RBC transaminase activity by adding pyridoxal phosphate in vitro. Direct measurement of the plasma concentrations of the vitamin (pyridoxal phosphate) can also be done.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with burning pain and numbness in his hands, heat intolerance and decreased visual acuity. Further evaluation reveals skin angiokeratomas and a decreased renal function. Which of the following is the mode of inheritance of the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Burning pain and numbness in hands, heat intolerance, decreased visual acuity with skin angiokeratomas and a decreased renal function is suggestive of Fabry’s disease which is inherited as an X-linked recessive disorder.

Fabry’s disease is a lipid storage disorder due to a deficiency of α-galactosidase A, resulting in the accumulation of globotriaosyl-ceramide in tissues. Young boys present with Fabry crises (burning pain in the hands, feet and proximal extremities), angiokeratomas (reddish blue telangiectatic skin lesions between the umbilicus and knees), corneal and lenticular opacities, renal failure and cardiomyopathy.

Note: All sphingolipidoses are inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, except Fabry’s disease.

Most of the common metabolic disorders are autosomal recessive disorders, except:

1. Autosomal dominant disorders:

  • Familial hypercholesterolemia

2. X-linked recessive disorders:

  • Hunter syndrome
  • Fabry disease
  • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome
  • OTC deficiency

questions.text: While studying the patient data on hypersensitivity reactions over the last 2 months, you are tasked with classifying the cases by type. Who among the following patients falls under type II hypersensitivity?

choices.text: Eczematous reaction on the hand of an HCW wearing powdered gloves
A patient with heat intolerance, sinus tachycardia, and proptosis
Glomerulonephritis in a patient with systemic lupus erythematosus

questions.solution:
Heat intolerance, sinus tachycardia, and proptosis of the eye suggest a diagnosis of Grave's disease. It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction that results in the binding of anti-thyroid-stimulating hormone (anti-TSH) antibodies to TSH receptors and stimulates the thyroid cells to produce thyroid hormones.

Type II hypersensitivity reactions involve combining the of IgG antibodies with the antigenic determinants on the surface of cells leading to cytotoxic effects.

Other options:

Option A: Berylliosis is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction.

Option B: Eczematous reaction on the hand of an HCW wearing powdered gloves (contact dermatitis) is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction.

Option D: Glomerulonephritis in a patient with SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus) is a type III hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes in urea cycle is a hydrolase?
questions.solution:
Arginase in urea cycle is a hydrolase type of enzyme. Hydrolytic cleavage of arginine is catalysed by liver arginase. It releases urea and ornithine. Ornithine then reenters liver mitochondria and participates in additional rounds of urea synthesis.

questions.text: Vitiligo is most commonly associated with which of the following autoimmune disorders?
questions.solution:
Amongst autoimmune diseases, the strongest association of vitiligo is with thyroid disease.

One of the theories for the etiology of vitiligo is based on the clinical association of vitiligo with a number of autoimmune disorders like -

  • Thyroid disease (hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism)
  • Pernicious anemia
  • Addison disease
  • Diabetes Mellitus
  • Hypoparathyroidism
  • Alopecia areata

Vitiligo is a localized depigmentation that occurs due to a progressive loss in the melanocytes in the basal layer of skin. It is classified as

  • Segmental vitiligo- which appears as unilateral maculae in a segmented or band-shaped pattern
  • Non-segmental vitiligo- which appears as bilateral maculae distributed in an acrofacial pattern or scattered symmetrically over the entire body. Non-segmental can either be focal vitiligo or undetermined/unclassified vitiligo.

According to a recent Vitiligo Global Issue Consensus Conference, the term ‘vitiligo’ can be used as an umbrella term for all non‐segmental forms of vitiligo (including several variants: acrofacial, mucosal, generalized, universal, mixed, and rare variants of vitiligo). The classification is shown below


Vitiligo (Non segmental)
  • Acrofacial
  • Mucosal (>1 one mucosal site)
  • Generalized
  • Universal
  • Mixed (associated with SV)
  • Rare variants
Segmental vitiligo
  • Uni-, bi-, or pleuri-segmental

Undetermined/

unclassified vitiligo
  • Focal
  • Mucosal (one site in isolation)

The lesions become apparent between 20-30 years of age. Hypopigmented macules in vitiligo are commonly found in the hips, dorsum of the hands/fingers, feet, elbows, knees, and ankle areas. These are the areas of repeated friction. Koebner phenomenon is seen, which is the development of lesions at the site of trauma on the uninvolved skin.

Vitiligo universalis, which is complete vitiligo, or trichrome vitiligo where there are areas of depigmentation, hyperpigmentation, as well as areas of normal skin may be seen rarely.

Under the Wood's lamp examination the depigmented areas emit a bright blue-white fluorescence and appear sharply demarcated. 

Treatment involves cosmetic camouflage and the use of sunscreen. The topical application of corticosteroids is the first line of treatment. Topical calcineurin inhibitors like pimecrolimus and tacrolimus have also shown to be successful. Psoralen photochemotherapy, khellin and selective ultraviolet B therapy are used as second-line treatment. In patients who do not respond to this treatment, surgical grafting techniques can be used, where the melanocytes from a normal pigmented area are transferred to a non pigmented area. In patients with extensive vitiligo where only a few pigmented areas are left, depigmentation can be done.

Poor prognostic factors for vitiligo:

  • Positive family history 
  • Mucosal vitiligo 
  • Lesions over bony prominences
  • Isomorphic Koebner's phenomenon 
  • Non-segmental vitiligo

Leucotrichia, longer duration, and higher age at onset do not correlate significantly with progression.

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: Histopathology of a patient who had pulmonary edema shows the following. The cells seen within the alveolar spaces are:
questions.solution:
• Heart failure cells are hemosiderin-laden macrophages.
  • In cardiac failure, red cells and plasma proteins extravasate into the edema fluid within the alveolar spaces, where they are phagocytosed and digested by macrophages, which store the iron recovered from hemoglobin in the form of hemosiderin.
  • These hemosiderin-laden macrophages (also known as heart failure cells) are telltale signs of previous episodes of pulmonary edema.

questions.text: A housewife from rural Tripura with a past history of infectious mononucleosis presents with complaints of double vision and a neck swelling that has progressively increased in size. She also gives a history of nasal discharge and is annoyed that her husband is recently complaining of a change in her voice. What is the most likely speech pattern observed here?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario of exposure to EBV, progressive cervical lymphadenopathy, nasal discharge, diplopia (involvement of cranial nerve VI), and change in voice is suggestive of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. The most likely speech pattern, in this case, is rhinolalia clausa or denasal speech, due to obstruction of the nasopharynx by the tumor.

Rhinolalia clausa is the lack of nasal resonance for words resonated in the nasal cavity and is usually seen due to blockage of nose or nasopharynx

Other nasal symptoms of nasopharyngeal carcinoma are:

  • Nasal obstruction
  • Nasal discharge
  • Epistaxis

Option B- Rhinolalia aperta (hypernasal voice) is seen in Velopharyngeal insufficiency.

Option C- Puberphonia is the persistence of prepubertal voice into adolescence or adulthood. 

Option D- Muffled and thick speech, often called “hot potato voice” is seen in peritonsillar abscess or quinsy.

questions.text: An HIV positive patient was suffering from multi-drug resistant tuberculosis. He died of respiratory failure due to lobar pneumonia. Which of the following options is the most appropriate for the line I (a) of the death certificate?
questions.solution:
Lobar pneumonia is appropriate for line I (a) of the death certificate. Line I (a) consists of the immediate cause of death such as the disease/condition. Immediate cause is the immediate/terminal event leading to death

In this patient:

  • I(a) - Disease directly leading to death: Lobar pneumonia
  • I(b) - Antecedent cause: MDR tuberculosis.
  • II- HIV

Respiratory failure is a mode of dying in this patient. It is not the cause of death.

Terminal events like circulatory failure and respiratory failure, are modes of dying. They should not be written as the immediate cause of death in the death certificate because they are just signs of death.

Simply put, respiratory failure is 'how he died' whereas lobar pneumonia is 'why he died'. Therefore, lobar pneumonia (why he died) is the cause of the death.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding axonal transport?

choices.text: Slow orthograde axonal transport occurs at 100 mm/day
Kinesins are required for orthograde axonal transport
Viruses exploit retrograde transport for invasion

questions.solution:
Slow orthograde transport occurs at a speed of 0.5 to 10 mm/day.

AXONAL TRANSPORT

  • Protein synthesis occurs in the cell body of neuron and proteins and polypeptides are transported to axonal endings by the axoplasmic flow.
  • Axonal transport can be Orthograde or Retrograde.
  • Orthograde transport 
    • Can be either fast or slow axonal transport and it occurs along microtubules that run along the length of the axon away from the cell body.
    • Fast axonal transport occurs at about 400 mm/day, and slow axonal transport occurs at 0.5 to 10 mm/day.
    • Molecular motor involved in orthograde transport is kinesin.
  • Retrograde transport,
    • In the opposite direction (from the nerve ending to the cell body), occurs along microtubules at about 200 mm/day. Synaptic vesicles, nerve growth factor (NGF) and some viruses (Eg: herpes simplex, rabies, and polio) are transported back to the cell body. 
    • Molecular motor involed in retrograde transport is dyenin.

questions.text: The ring structure given below is that of ________.
questions.solution:
The ring structure shown in the diagram is a pyran ring.

Pyran is a six-membered heterocyclic non-aromatic ring, consisting of five carbon atoms and one oxygen atom and containing two double bonds.

The ring structures of monosaccharides, such as glucose and fructose, belong to two categories:

  • Pyran (6-member ring): Pyranose
  • Furan (5-member ring): Furanose
  • Glucose exists predominantly as a pyranose ring
  • Fructose exists predominantly as a furanose ring

 

Note: The empirical formula for carbohydrates is (CH2O)n , where n≥ 3.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented with a history of seizures. Imaging revealed the presence of a tumor in the frontal lobe. Surgery was done, and the biopsy specimen is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a frontal lobe tumor, presenting with seizures and the histopathology image showing the ‘fried egg appearance’ of tumor cells, points to the diagnosis of oligodendroglioma.

Oligodendroglioma is a subtype of infiltrating glioma. It is comprised of cells that resemble oligodendrocytes. The tumors are composed of sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. This gives it the ‘fried egg appearance.’ The tumor cells that infiltrate the cortex usually collect around the neuron, and this is known as perineural satellitosis. There is a delicate network of anastomosing thin-walled capillaries between the tumor cells, resembling 'chicken wire.'

Oligodendrogliomas are most commonly detected in the fourth and fifth decades of life. Patients may have had several years of antecedent neurologic complaints, often including seizures. The lesions are found mostly in the cerebral hemispheres, mainly in the frontal or temporal lobes. It is treated with a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy. 

Other options:

Option A: Glioblastoma is a synonym for grade IV astrocytoma. Infiltrating astrocytomas and glioblastomas are usually seen in the cerebellum, brainstem, or spinal cord. Histologically, glioblastoma appears like an anaplastic astrocytoma with serpiginous foci of palisading necrosis and microvascular proliferation. 

Option C: Ependymomas in adults occur in the spinal cord and near the ventricles, particularly the fourth ventricle. The microscopic appearance shows both true rosettes and perivascular pseudorosettes.

Option D: Schwannomas are benign tumors often arising directly from peripheral nerves. On microscopy, they are comprised of dense areas called Antoni A areas and loose areas referred to as Antoni B areas. Antoni A areas are eosinophilic and contain spindle cells arranged in intersecting fascicles with nuclear palisading. The central nuclear-free zones are called Verocay bodies. Schwannomas are a component of NF-2.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

Related Pearl: Chronic granulomatous disease

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is due to the defect in NADPH oxidase. This interferes with the killing of bacteria by oxidative burst. Hence, the patients are at increased risk of infection from catalase-positive bacteria.

 It can be:

  • X linked - Defect in one of the membrane-bound components (gp91phox) or
  • Autosomal recessive - Cytoplasmic components (p47phox and p67phox)

Diagnosis of CGD includes:

  • Nitroblue tetrazolium test - This is the standard for phagocyte oxidase activity measurement. The colorless compound NBT is reduced to blue formazan by the activity of the functional phox enzyme system. Normally, more than 95% of the granulocytes will be positive. The NBT is negative in CGD due to absence of phox enzyme activity.
  • Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test - The most accurate diagnostic test for CGD. Normally functioning phagocytic cells oxidize DHR to the strongly fluorescent compound rhodamine which is quantified by flow cytometry.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a side effect of salbutamol?
questions.solution:
Hypoglycemia is not a side effect of salbutamol. It causes hyperglycemia.

The side effects of salbutamol are due to the stimulation of extrapulmonary β2 receptors. They are more common after oral or intravenous administration. The side effects seen are:    

  • Muscle tremor
  • Tachycardia
  • Hypokalemia 
  • Restlessness        
  • Hypoxemia         
  • Increase in free fatty acid, insulin, glucose, pyruvate, and lactate

questions.text:
A young asthmatic boy was rushed to ED with confusion and gasping for breath. His ABG analysis is as shown. What is the acid-base disorder?

pH- 7.25

pCO2- 70 mmHg

HCO3‾- 26 mEq/L

pO2- 45 mmHg
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute severe asthma. The acid-base disorder is respiratory acidosis, partially compensated.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: pH is decreased. This signifies acidosis. In acidosis, either pCO2 is increased or plasma HCO3- is decreased.  

Step 2: In this case, pCO2 is increased by 30 mmHg. This signifies respiratory acidosis. 

Step 3: Plasma HCO3- is increased by 26-24 = 2 mEq/L. This signifies compensation is taking place.

In acute conditions, for every 10mmHg rise in pCO2 expected rise in plasma HCO3- is 1mEq/L. In this case, pCO2 has risen by 30 mmHg, so the expected rise in HCO3- is 3 mEq/L.

However, plasma HCO3- has risen only by 2 mEq/L, which implies compensation is only partial.

questions.text: An ENT senior resident posted in a remote village comes across a patient in whom he suspects otosclerosis. Which of the following tests can be used if he wants to clinically confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gelle’s is a tuning fork test done to clinically confirm otosclerosis in the olden days.

It is based on the fact that in a normal ear if pressure is increased in the external ear the stapes footplate will get medialized and will stop conducting sound. But, in an ear with otosclerosis of the footplate, there will be no movements and the patient will continue to hear the sound. Thus, Gelle’s test is considered positive in normal persons and in those with sensorineural hearing loss. It is negative when the ossicular chain is fixed or disconnected.

Stenger’s test is done to rule out malingering.

Schwabach is a tuning fork test that compares the bone conduction of the patient with that of the examiner.

Rinne’s is a tuning fork test that compares bone conduction with air conduction.

questions.text: Therapeutic index is used for assessing which of the following factors?
questions.solution:
Therapeutic index is used to assess the safety of the drug administered.

Therapeutic index = TD50/ED50 

  • TD50 (Median toxic dose) = Dose required to produce a toxic effect in 50% of animals tested.
  • ED50 (Median effect dose) = Dose required to produce a therapeutic effect in 50% of the individuals.

Option B: Efficacy is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug. It expresses the effect produced by the receptors when bound by a certain drug.

Option C: Potency refers to the concentration (EC50) or dose (ED50) required to produce 50% of maximum effect where EC50 is the concentration of agonist resulting in a half-maximal response.

Option D: Median toxic dose is the dose required to produce a toxic effect in 50% of animals tested. Lethal dose is the dose required to kill 50% of animals tested.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding medico-legal autopsy?

choices.text: Magistrate is the authorizing officer in case of exhumation
In India, all registered medical practitioners can perform an autopsy

questions.solution:
In the case of a medicolegal autopsy, consent of the relatives is not required.

For conducting a medicolegal autopsy:

  • Legal authorization is a must
  • Magistrate is the authorizing officer in case of exhumation
  • Preferably, a forensic pathologist or medicolegal expert does the autopsy. However, in India, due to the lack of adequate qualified experts, all registered medical practitioners can perform this with authorization by the state.

Note: Clinical/ pathological autopsy requires consent from the relatives of the deceased.
